The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.head: No. 82.
div.p:
L. S.
BE IT REMEMBERED that on the twentieth day of January in the nineteenth year of the Independence of the United States of America, Edmund Hogan of the ≈øaid Di≈øtrict hath depo≈øited in this Office the Title of a Book, the right whereof he claims as Proprietor in the words following, to wit‚Äî The Penn≈øylvania State Trials; containing the Impeachment, Trial, and Acquittal of Francis Hopkin≈øon, and John Nichol≈øon, E≈øquires, the former being Judge of the Court of Admiralty, and the latter the Comptroller-General of the Commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania. Vol. I. ‚ÄîVire≈øque acquirit eundo. Virg. in conformity to the Act of the Congre≈øs of the United States, intituled An Act for the encouragement of learning by ≈øecuring the copies of maps, charts, and books to the authors and proprietors of ≈øuch copies during the times therein mentioned.

closer.signed: SAMUEL CALDWELL, Clerk of the Di≈øtrict of Penn≈øylvania.

div.head: Dedication.
To the only legitimate ≈øovereign of the UNITED STATES, THE PEOPLE.
div.p: Inasmuch as all power originated with, and is inherent in the People, which hath been a≈øsumed for many ages by individuals commonly called kings, princes, tetrarchs, &c. of which power the≈øe ≈øelect beings have ≈øeldom failed to make a bad u≈øe; and inasmuch as during the reigns, and particularly within the vortex of the dominion of tho≈øe per≈øons, books of the ≈øame tendency with the following had frequently been dedicated to them, or to ≈øome great per≈øonage who occa≈øionally gave liberal portions of the loaves and fi≈øhes to the writers, or buoyed them up by their influence and patronage.

I have therefore thought proper to dedicate my work to you, in preference to any ≈øingle individual; not from the expectation of patronage, not from the de≈øire of reward, but from a ≈øincere impre≈øsion in your favour, from a con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of your supremacy, excellence and maje≈øty, and a wi≈øh to contribute my little ≈øtock to the general good: I hope ≈øuch of you as will peru≈øe the following ≈øheets will judge for your≈øelves, and as in every other ca≈øe let facts and rea≈øon be your only authorities:

closer.signed: I am, Citizens, Your well-wi≈øher, EDMUND HOGAN.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: IT is commonly expected that the Author or Editor of every work would furni≈øh the public with ≈øome account of the performance in the Preface; this will not be done here at length, as the work is before you and will an≈øwer for it≈øelf. It may be remarked that the Preface would be a ≈øuitable place to give a ≈øketch of the lives of the two gentlemen, who≈øe trials are here publi≈øhed, to this it can be an≈øwered that the Editor never ≈øaw Mr. Hopkin≈øon, now decea≈øed; and it would be very improper to write any thing re≈øpecting the life of the other gentleman, who is yet on the ≈øtage: But the works of Mr. Hopkin≈øon are publi≈øhed, and his character is well known to be not inferior to any, and having very few of equal merit among the literati of the pre≈øent century. By the pre≈øent publication it will al≈øo appear, that he, like other people, had political enemies, who were equally di≈øappointed at his acquittal in the year 1780, as others have ≈øince been at the acquittal of Mr. Nichol≈øon in the year 1794.

The documents herein publi≈øhed have been regularly compared with authentic copies laid before the Senate, who≈øe permi≈ø≈øion to copy them the Editor had obtained during the interval from the 23d of March to the adjournment in April.

If any errors have crept into the work, let the reader be a≈ø≈øured that great pains have been taken to prevent them, and that a work of this ≈øize and
con≈øequence cannot fail of being attended with many difficulties; that this was a new field of argument, and that every error communicated to the Editor from any of the Speakers, or from tho≈øe concerned ≈øhall be duly attended to, and rectified in the next edition.

From the difference in the length of the work in the two trials, the latter of which the Editor attended throughout, and took down in ≈øhort hand; and the former be only collected and compiled from papers, ≈øome in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of private gentlemen, and others with the public, the reader will judge how nece≈ø≈øary this work is to the e≈øtabli≈øhment of a complete hi≈øtory of the State-Trials of the Commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, before the period pa≈ø≈øes when it can only be gathered from partial writers on one ≈øide or the other: As an evidence of the importance of this work, the Editor will be excu≈øed for introducing the following judicious report to the Senate of Penn≈øyl≈øylvania, by their committee a few days before the adjournment in April 1794.
"The committee to whom was referred the petition of Edmund Hogan, report‚Äî

"That in their opinion the work in which the petitioner is engaged is entitled to encouragement from the Legi≈ølature, to hand down to po≈øterity the doings of their forefathers, and to re≈øcue from oblivion the mo≈øt important tran≈øactions of the day in which we live, unembarra≈ø≈øed with quotations from ob≈øolete, Briti≈øh or exotic ≈øtatutes and corrupt precedents, will certainly command the ≈ømiles of every enlightened Legi≈ølator, of every Patriot, and is worthy the efforts of genius. In order therefore to further the de≈øigns of the petitioner, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in the execution of his laudable undertaking, and to promote the diffu≈øion of u≈øeful and important knowledge throughout
„Äà‚óä„Äâ commonwealth, recommend that the following re≈øolution be adopted‚Äî

"Re≈øolved, That the Governor of this commonwealth do ≈øub≈øcribe in the name of the ≈øtate for _____ copies of Edmund Hogan's work, entitled "State Trials," to be di≈øtributed throughout the different counties in ≈øuch manner as the Legi≈ølature may direct."

It is a≈ø≈øerted in a note, at the bottom of page 209, that the oral te≈øtimony given in the hou≈øe, when the articles of impeachment were brought forward again≈øt Mr. Nichol≈øon, was not committed to writing; part of this te≈øtimony appearing in pages 185 and 188, the Editor thinks it proper to ≈øtate, how that part of it had been pre≈øerved, altho' unknown to the managers: ‚ÄîHe was employed by the proprietor of the Mail, a daily paper then publi≈øhed in the city, to collect intelligence, and for that purpo≈øe had been permitted, as many others had been before and ≈øince, to fit in a convenient place in≈øide the bar of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, where he collected the te≈øtimony alluded to in Sept. 1793. About the ≈øame time he entertained ≈øome notions of publi≈øhing the following trial, in which he was encouraged by a number of re≈øpectable ≈øub≈øcribers. The managers, in their letter to Mr. Nichol≈øon, mu≈øt mean, what really was the ca≈øe, that "the te≈øtimony was not committed to writing or pre≈øerved" BY ORDER OE THE HOUSE.

div.p: AN ACCOUNT OF THE IMPEACHMENT AND TRIAL OF THE LATE FRANCIS HOPKINSON, ESQUIRE, JUDGE OF THE COURT OF ADMIRALTY FOR THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY FRANCIS BAILEY, AT YORICK'S HEAD, No. 116, HIGH-STREET. M,DCC,XCIV.

div.head: AN ACCOUNT OF THE IMPEACHMENT AND TRIAL, &c.

On WEDNESDAY the 22d of November, A. D. 1780, and in the 4th year of the Independence of the UNITED STATES, it appears from the minutes of the HOUSE OF ASSEMBLY of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, That a Paper was pre≈øented to the Speaker, entitled, A general Sketch of charges to be exhibited again≈øt FRANCIS HOPKINSON, E≈øquire, Judge of Admiralty; and a variety of depo≈øitions and other papers, exhibited as proofs to ≈øupport the ≈øaid charges; which were by order read, and laid on the table for con≈øideration: and are as follow, being copies from originals.
div.p: CHARGE 1.

THAT having a power by law to appoint an agent for unrepre≈øented ≈øhares belonging to ab≈øent ≈øeamen, and others, he offered and propo≈øed to appoint Mr. Blair M'Clenachan, agent for a number of ≈øuch ≈øhares belonging to ≈øeamen, who had ≈øailed on board the privateer Holker, upon the condition, that he the ≈øaid Blair M'Clenachan would make a pre≈øent of a ≈øuit of cloaths; and, this condition not being complied with, he appointed others in his ≈øtead. For proof ≈øee papers No. 2 & 3, and evidence to be ≈øummoned. Declared to be ≈øupported by the evidence.

2. Receiving pre≈øents from per≈øons intere≈øted in the condemnation of prizes, previous to their condemnation;
particularly a ca≈øk of wine from on board the prize brigantine Glouce≈øter, pre≈øented to him by the captors before any condemnation, ≈øale or di≈øtribution.
See papers No. 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 & (Z.)
N. B. The date of (Z) compared with tho≈øe of No. 4 & 5, will ≈øhew that the wi ‚Ä¢ e was delivered before condemnation.
Not ≈øupported.

3. Conniving at, and encouraging the ≈øale of prizes before condemnation, contrary to law, and maliciou≈øly charging the Mar≈øhal with the crime of ≈øuch conduct before the honourable the Supreme Executive Council; in the in≈øtance of the prize ≈øhip Charlotte.
Evidences to be ≈øummoned in ≈øupport of this charge; and ≈øee paper (A) 3d article thereof.
Not ≈øupported.

4. I≈ø≈øuing a writ of ≈øale, of the cargo of a prize, declaring in the ≈øame writ that it was te≈øtified to him, that the ≈øame cargo was in danger of wa≈øte, ≈øpoil, and damage, when in fact and in truth no ≈øuch te≈øtimony or return was ever given, or made to him;‚Äîin the in≈øtance of the cargo of the prize ≈øhip Allion.
See papers 9, 10, 11, 12.
Supported.
N. B. In corroboration of the charges, ≈øeveral witne≈ø≈øes may be produced, who will not appear without being called for, by authority.

div.head: MONDAY, the 27th November.
div.p: THE paper entitled, A general ≈øketch of charges to be exhibited again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Admiralty; received the 22d in≈øtant, and the ≈øeveral depo≈øitions, &c. accompanying the ≈øame, were read the ≈øecond time, and referred to a committee of three: the gentlemen appointed were Mr. Campbell, Mr. J. Smith, and Mr. Gallraith, who are directed to reque≈øt a conference with the Supreme Executive Council thereon.

div.head: THURSDAY, November 30.
div.p: A LETTER from the Honorable Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this State, was read, reque≈øting to be furni≈øhed with a copy of the charges exhibited again≈øt him on the 22d in≈øtant: Ordered that the clerk furni≈øh Mr. Hopkin≈øon with a copy of the charges afore≈øaid.
Mr. Hopkin≈øon received the following letter that evening.‚Äî

body.p: "YOUR letter of this day I laid before the A≈ø≈øembly, and the Clerk was ordered immediately to furni≈øh you with copies of all the papers relating to the ≈øubject you mentioned. I have the honor to be, with ≈øentiments of re≈øpect and e≈øteem,

div.head: FRIDAY, December 1.
div.p: A MEMORIAL from Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Admiralty of this ≈øtate, was read, ≈øtaring, that as certain charges have been exhibited again≈øt him for mi≈øconduct in his office, he therefore prays that he may not be ≈øuffered to lie long under cen≈øure, but that a hearing or a trial in the manner the Hou≈øe may judge mo≈øt eligible, may be directed as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible.
Ordered, That it be referred to the committee appointed the 27th ult. to take into con≈øideration the charges exhibited again≈øt him, &c.

The committee appointed to confer with the Supreme Executive Council on the charges exhibited again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the court of Admiralty of this ≈øtate, reported their performance of that ≈øervice, &c.
Whereupon,
Ordered, That the Hou≈øe will re≈øolve it≈øelf into a committee of the whole Hou≈øe, on Monday next, at four o'clock in the afternoon, to take into con≈øideration the charges afore≈øaid.
Ordered, That the parties be directed to attend at the time afore≈øaid, in the A≈ø≈øembly room, with their re≈øpective evidences, when they will be heard on the charges afore≈øaid.

div.head: MONDAY, December 4.
div.p: ON motion,

Re≈øolved, That the Hou≈øe will to-morrow re-con≈øider the order of Friday la≈øt, a≈ø≈øigning this afternoon for the con≈øideration of the charges again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Admiralty, &c.

div.head: TUESDAY, December 5.
div.p: UPON a re-con≈øideration of the order of Friday la≈øt, relative to the con≈øideration of certain charges exhibited again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this State, for mal-admini≈øtration in his office, it was,
Re≈øolved, That the witne≈ø≈øes in ≈øupport of the charges afore≈øaid, be heard before the Hou≈øe to-morrow morning at eleven o'clock, the order afore≈øaid to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

body.p: "I BEG leave to inform you that the General A≈ø≈øembly have re-con≈øidered their order of Friday la≈øt, and determined to hear the evidences only in ≈øupport of the charges exhibited again≈øt you. Eleven o'clock to-morrow morning is the time appointed, when your pre≈øence will probably be nece≈ø≈øary.

body.trailer: FRANCIS HOPKINSON, E≈øq

div.head: WEDNESDAY, December 6.
div.p: THE order of the day was called for and read.

The Hou≈øe agreeably thereto, proceeded to hear the evidence in ≈øupport of certain charges exhibited again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this State, for mal-admini≈øtration in his office.
On motion,
Ordered, That the doors be ≈øhut during the examination of witne≈ø≈øes on the charges afore≈øaid,
Mr. Hopkin≈øon appearing in the Hou≈øe, acknowledged the papers marked A, and No. 12, to be his hand-writing: They proceeded to hear the witne≈ø≈øes and to read the depo≈øitions accordingly.
The Judge of Admiralty's Memorial again≈øt the Mar≈øhal. Read in A≈ø≈øembly 22d November, 1780.

body.head: Marked (A.) To His Excellency the Pre≈øident and Honorable the Executive Council for the State of Penn≈øylvania.‚Äî
The Memorial of Francis Hopkin≈øon, Judge in the Court of Admiralty for the State of Penn≈øylvania,
body.p: THAT from a ≈øen≈øe of duty to the public and regard to the ≈øtation he has the honor to fill, he finds him≈øelf under a nece≈ø≈øity of preferring a complaint to your honors again≈øt the conduct of the Mar≈øhal of the ≈øaid Court.
He founds his complaint on the following charges, viz.

1. Neglect of duty, in that the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal hath made no returns of the writs i≈ø≈øued by the Court for the≈øe eighteen months pa≈øt (two in≈øtances only excepted) and hath made no returns whatever of accounts‚Äî≈øales; as by law and cu≈øtom he ought to do.
2. For contempt of the Court, in not giving his attendance at the ≈øittings thereof, as his duty requires.
3. In pre≈øuming to ≈øell ve≈ø≈øels and property before condemnation, not having the authority of the Court, or con≈øent of the Judge for ≈øo doing.
4. In refu≈øing to obey a writ of the Court.

5. In not exhibiting to the Judge, although thereto required, the bills of charges he brings again≈øt prizes, as by law he ought to do; in order that the Judge may examine, and if occa≈øion requires, tax the ≈øame for the avoiding inju≈øtice and oppre≈ø≈øion.
As the≈øe ≈øeem to be breaches of duty in very important in≈øtances, your memoriali≈øt prays that the ≈øaid Mar≈øhall may be removed from his office, and another appointed in his place.

body.head: No. 9.
body.p: Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of the State of Penn≈øylvania, to Matthew Clark≈øon, E≈øq Mar≈øhal of the ≈øaid State, Greeting.

WHEREAS it is te≈øtified unto me that the cargo on board the ≈øhip or ve≈ø≈øel called the Albion, lately ≈øent into this port, and libelled again≈øt as prize, by Samuel Walker, qui tam, &c. is in great danger of wa≈øte, ≈øpoil and damage. The≈øe, therefore, are to authori≈øe and command you forthwith to ≈øell at public vendue, all and ≈øingular the goods, wares and merchandize, laden and found on board the ≈øaid ≈øhip at the time of her capture; and you are to detain and keep in your ≈øafe cu≈øtody the monies ari≈øing from the ≈øaid ≈øales, ready to abide the further order of this court‚Äîand how you ≈øhall have executed this writ, make return to me at a Court of Admiralty to be held at my Chambers in Philadelphia, the twenty-fir≈øt day of Augu≈øt, in≈øtant, together with this writ. Given under my hand, and the ≈øeal of the ≈øaid Court, the ≈øeventh day of Augu≈øt, Anno Domini, 1780.

body.head: To Matthew Clark≈øon, E≈øq Mar≈øhall, &c.
No. 12.
body.p: "SOME doubts having ari≈øen as to the propriety of ≈øuffering prize-goods to be ≈øold by public vendue, unle≈øs the ≈øame ≈øhall on in≈øpection be found in a peri≈øhing condition, I have directed William Hey≈øham and William Budden to examine the ≈øituation of the cargo on board the prize-≈øhip Albion, which cargo you have adverti≈øed for ≈øale this afternoon.

"Me≈ø≈ørs. Hey≈øham and Budden have made a report to me, that they have carefully examined the ≈øaid cargo, being Liverpool ≈øalt, and that they find the ≈øame in good order and well conditioned, and in no immediate danger of ≈øuffering by wa≈øte or otherwi≈øe.

"You are therefore hereby directed not to proceed in a public ≈øale of the ≈øaid ≈øalt, but re≈øerve the ≈øame to be di≈øpo≈øed of, as the Court ≈øhall order after trial of the ≈øaid ≈øhip Albion and her cargo.

div.p: The paper marked Z, is an order from the Judge to ≈øell and di≈øtribute the brig Glouce≈øter and cargo, dated the 30th Augu≈øt, 1780, under his hand and ≈øeal, and directed to the Mar≈øhal. Inclo≈øed is a bill of co≈øts in the ca≈øe of the Recovery, amounting to ¬£.34:8:0 ≈øpecie, multiplied by 40, as the rate of depreciation for paper-money at that period. Omitted here as immaterial.

body.head: No. 11.
body.p: "THE Mar≈øhal applies to me, in con≈øequence of a letter from you, and ≈øome conver≈øation ≈øince, re≈øpecting the ≈øale of the ≈øalt on board of the Albion.

"The law is clear in it's directions; and I have advi≈øed him to repre≈øent to the Judge the indi≈øpen≈øible nece≈ø≈øity of having it returned upon oath that the cargo is really peri≈øhable or damaged, ≈øo that it will not keep without further injury; previous to any ≈øale. This ≈øtep I pre≈øume will be taken, and if the facts will warrant a ≈øale, it will go on; otherwi≈øe not.

closer.signed: I have the honor to be, Your Excellency's mo≈øt obedient, Humble ≈øervant, JONAT. D. SERGEANT."

body.trailer: His Excellency Pre≈øident REED.

body.head: No. 10.
body.p: "I OBSERVE an adverti≈øement to ≈øell by auction in your name.

"That others ≈øhould make a mi≈øtake of this nature, would not be much wondered at; but that an officer
of the ≈øtate ≈øhould adverti≈øe a violation of it's laws, mu≈øt have a very odd appearance. You will do well to re-con≈øider the Acts of A≈ø≈øembly, and not proceed unle≈øs you are very clear in ≈øo doing.

closer.signed: I am in ha≈øte. But with due e≈øteem, Sir, your obedient, Humble ≈øervant, JOS. REED,"

body.trailer: MATTHEW CLARKSON, E≈øq Mar≈øhal, &c. (Copy.)

body.head: No. 2.
body.p: Mr. M. Clark≈øon, ≈øworn in ≈øupport of the fir≈øt charge, ≈øaith,

That ≈øome time in the month of May la≈øt, Mr. H. brought Mr. M'C. to his hou≈øe, to talk over certain di≈øputes that happened between him the ≈øaid M'C. and the officers of the Court of Admiralty. That we conferred fully on the ≈øubject‚Äîand ≈øeveral explanations took place, concerning matters mi≈øconceived between the ≈øaid B. M'C. and Dep. The event was a reconciliation that appeared cordial‚Äîthe Judge te≈øtified his a≈ø≈øent to ≈øaid reconciliation, having been before offended with Mr. M'Clenachan.

Mr. M'C. went away, and the Judge remained. A conver≈øation commenced between Dep. and Judge; Dep. mentioned that a number of ≈øhares were unrepre≈øented, that the Judge by law might appoint agents for. That as Mr. M'C. had made con≈øiderable advances to tho≈øe people who≈øe ≈øhares were unrepre≈øented. Dep. ≈øaid it would be an act of kindne≈øs to appoint M'C. ≈øuch agent, as it would put it in his power to ≈øave the money advanced,‚Äîand thought it would be a good te≈øtimony of the afore≈øaid reconciliation being effected.
The Judge con≈øented, and ≈øaid he would appoint M'C. and gave me leave ≈øo to inform M'C. and added, that ≈øuch appointments were lucrative to the receivers‚Äîand many had been done by him (the Judge) to owners of privateers; for which he had received no recompen≈øe. That Judge apprehended that on this occa≈øion the profits to Mr. M'C. would be a ≈øufficient rea≈øon for him the ≈øaid M'C. to make him the Judge, a pre≈øent of a ≈øuit of cloaths, and Judge de≈øired Dep. would mention it to Mr. M'C. Dep. afterwards ≈øaw M'C. and informed him, that the Judge had agreed to appoint him agent as afore≈øaid. M'C. a few days after mentioned to Dep. that in con≈øequence of the promi≈øe of the Judge, he had paid ≈øome of the ≈øaid ≈øeamen, who≈øe ≈øhares were unrepre≈øented, more money. Dep. made no mention of the Judge's expectations of a ≈øuit of cloaths, con≈øidering it too delicate a matter.

Judge frequently a≈øked deponent whether he ≈øaid any thing about ≈øaid cloaths. Dep. evaded the an≈øwer, by ≈øaying he had no convenient opportunity. Thus the matter re≈øted for two weeks or three, when being at the Coffee-hou≈øe, I met the Judge there; he informed me that the letters of agency were made out‚Äîbut that Me≈ø≈ørs. Meade and Fitz≈øimons were appointed in≈øtead of M'C. Dep. felt ≈øurpri≈øed at the information, and remon≈øtrated with the Judge having de≈øired me, and mentioned the promi≈øe he (the Judge) had made of appointing M'C.‚Äîand that Dep. ≈øaid, he had informed M'Clenachan of his intended appointment.

A few days after, Judge came to Dep. hou≈øe, and conver≈øed on what had pa≈ø≈øed, and attempted to vindicate him≈øelf, and ≈øaid that one thing he was mo≈øt ≈øorry for,
viz. the reque≈øt to apply for the ≈øuit of cloaths, as by ≈øo doing he had put him≈øelf in his the Dep. power. Dep. told him that it depended on him≈øelf, that he was not di≈øpo≈øed to do any injury to him. Dep. and Judge then parted.
Cro≈øs examined. Dep. rather thinks no per≈øon was pre≈øent at the conver≈øation about ≈øuit of cloaths.

Judge took the Dep. to one ≈øide on the conver≈øation at the Coffee-hou≈øe. Dep. never told M'C. of the Judge's reque≈øt. Dept. don't know that the Judge received any reward from Meade and Fitz≈øimons.
Dept. told his brother of the Judge's reque≈øt ≈øame day and Mr. Hazard, and don't know that it is cu≈øtomary for the officers of the Court to receive pre≈øents, as he never received any him≈øelf.

body.head: No. 3.
body.p: "Gerardus Clark≈øon maketh oath that he had ≈øeen the foregoing depo≈øition, and that he, the deponent, was informed of the tran≈øaction therein mentioned, ≈øoon after it happened, by his brother Matthew Clark≈øon, that on conver≈øing with the Judge on the ≈øubject, a few days after, he, Judge Hopkin≈øon, informed the deponent that he, the Judge, had promi≈øed the Mar≈øhal that Blair M'Clenachan ≈øhould have the agency; but that as he had ≈øeen Blair M'Clenachan frequently ≈øince, and he Mr. M'Clenachan had taken no notice of him, he ≈øaw no rea≈øon why he Mr. M'Clenachan, ≈øhould have his favors, and therefore gave them to ≈øomebody el≈øe.

body.head: No. 4.
body.p:
"THERE being an immediate call for a quarter ca≈øk of the wine in the brigantine Glouce≈øter for particular u≈øe, ≈øhould e≈øteem it a favor if an order would be
≈øent by the bearer to Capt. M'Pher≈øon for the delivery of one ca≈øk; for Blair M'Clenachan, Agent for the Holker,

closer.signed: CHARLES MILLER, Agent for the Fair American and crew.
closer.dateline: To MATTHEW CLARKSON, E≈øq Mar≈øhal. Philadelphia, Augu≈øt 12th, 1780.

body.head: No. 5.
body.p: Augu≈øt 15th, 1780. I do hereby acknowledge to have received the within mentioned quarter ca≈øk of wine, Mr. Clark≈øon will plea≈øe to charge the ≈øame to the privateers Fair American and Holker according to their re≈øpective ≈øhares, it being ≈øent as a pre≈øent to the honorable Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Admiralty by con≈øent of the agents for ≈øaid privateers.

William Watkin maketh oath, that he, the deponent, was fir≈øt prize ma≈øter on board the Fair American in her late cruize, that on her taking the prize brig Glouce≈øter ≈øome time in Augu≈øt, he the deponent was put on board of her as prize ma≈øter, and brought her up to Philadelphia ≈øoon after; that Mr. Charles Miller, one of the owners and an agent for the concerned in the Fair American, applied to the deponent at the upper part of Hamilton's wharf, and told him that he would be glad he the deponent could get at a ca≈øk of wine of the fir≈øt quality; that they wanted it for a particular purpo≈øe, for the Judge of the Admiralty; that Mr. Miller a≈øked Dept. if he could get at it; Depont. ≈øaid he doubted it becau≈øe Capt. M'Pher≈øon was put on board by the Mar≈øhal, but he would try: that Mr. Miller ≈øaid the ca≈øk was for the Judge of the Admiralty; for nothing could be done without it to procure di≈øpatch; that Mr. Miller de≈øired Dept. to ≈øpeak to Capt. M'Pher≈øon, and ≈øee if he would not let it go without an order from the Mar≈øhal.
Dept. an≈øwered, that he (Mr. Miller) had better try him≈øelf; Mr. Miller ≈øaid he thought Capt. M'Pher≈øon would not do it for him, but would be more likely to do it for the deponent: That Capt. M'Pher≈øon refu≈øed to do it without the Mar≈øhal's order, though the deponent by Mr. Miller's order, told Capt. M'Pher≈øon that he Mr. Miller and Mr. Blair M'Clenachan, would be accountable for it. That hereupon Dept. acquainted Mr. Miller of Capt. M'Pher≈øon's refu≈øal, and he (Mr. Miller) wrote a note to the Mar≈øhal, and that he believes a note now ≈øhewn him, and ≈øigned Charles Miller, agent for the Fair American and crew, to be the ≈øame; that an order came ≈øoon after from the Mar≈øhal, and thereupon a ca≈øk of wine of the fir≈øt quality was taken from on board the brig Glouce≈øter and delivered to a porter, with orders to carry it to the Judge in Third ≈øtreet.

closer.dateline: Sworn 16th November, 1780, before me WILLIAM RUSH.

body.head: No. 7.
body.p: Capt. Matthew Hender≈øon maketh oath that he was on Hamilton's wharf ≈øoon after the before mentioned ca≈øk of wine was gone as he was told; that Dept. a≈øked Capt. William Watkin if he had broke bulk; that Capt. Watkin appeared angry, and ≈øaid no; only a quarter ca≈øk that we have taken and ≈øent to the Judge of the Admiralty, to expedite bu≈øine≈øs, and prove that nothing could be done without bribery; it was ju≈øt like England.

closer.dateline: Sworn 16th November, 1780, before me WILLIAM RUSH.

body.head: No. 8.
body.p:
James Clarke maketh oath that he (the Dept.) was employed by Capt. Watkin to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the delivery of the cargo of the prize brig Glouce≈øter; that he knows
of the ≈øending the quarter ca≈øk of wine and ≈øaw it go; that he under≈øtood from Mr. Charles Miller, that it was going as a compliment to the Judge of the Admiralty; that the rea≈øon he gave was that they had a peri≈øhing cargo on board, and wanted liberty from the Judge to di≈øcharge before the time limited by law.

closer.dateline: Sworn 16th November, 1780, before me WILLIAM RUSH.

div.p: William Lewis being duly affirmed, ≈øaith, That ≈øeveral months before the removal of the Mar≈øhal of the Admiralty of Penn≈øylvania from his office, Mr. Hopkin≈øon, Judge of the ≈øaid court mentioned to this affirmant, ≈øome di≈øputes which had ari≈øen between them, and that there was one matter which perhaps the Mar≈øhal might attempt to take advantage of, which was, that he had demanded a ≈øuit of cloaths for the appointment of Mr. Blair M'Clenachan, agent for the unrepre≈øented ≈øhares of ≈øeamen‚Äîthat the truth of the matter was, he had propo≈øed or intended appointing him agent; but as it was a very lucrative office, which would put large ≈øums of money into his pocket, and as he the Judge was empowered by law to appoint whom he plea≈øed, and as the appointment was di≈øcretionary with him, he did not ≈øee why he ≈øhould give Mr. M'Clenachan ≈øuch an appointment without ≈øome compliment in return; that he thought a ≈øuit of cloaths but rea≈øonable, and had ≈øignified that he would appoint him, if he had a ≈øuit of cloaths, that ≈øome time elap≈øed without this being attended to, or any a≈ø≈øurance given of the ≈øaid ≈øuit of cloaths, and therefore he had appointed others.

Mr. Sergeant ≈øworn,‚Äîdoth depo≈øe and ≈øay, that he knows the Judge charged the Mar≈øhal before Council for ≈øelling prizes before condemnation, and without order, that he (Dep.) had formerly frequently applied to have orders for the ≈øale of ve≈ø≈øels before condemnation and procured them‚Äîbut under the pre≈øent law, the
Judge refu≈øed to give any orders but referred him to the Mar≈øhal, implying that he (Judge) would not take any notice thereof if made. That he (Dep.) did not think that ≈øuch application was wicked or unju≈øt.
Acknowledges the paper No. 11 to be his, and under≈øtands the ≈øale of the Albion's cargo was ≈øtopped on that account.

B. M'Clenachan being ≈øworn in ≈øupport of the fir≈øt charge, depo≈øeth and ≈øaith, that he under≈øtood from Mr. M. C. that he would be appointed an Agent for certain unrepre≈øented ≈øhares, but that he never ≈øolicited the appointment and never heard any thing re≈øpecting a pre≈øent of a ≈øuit of cloaths. That he had advanced con≈øiderable ≈øums of money to per≈øons owning unrepre≈øented ≈øhares, and ≈øettled the accounts with M. and F. the agents appointed by the Judge.
In ≈øupport of the 2d.
That on the propo≈øal of Mr. Miller he con≈øented to make a pre≈øent of a ca≈øk of wine to the Judge afore≈øaid.

That the order for delivering the ca≈øk mu≈øt have come from M. C. Judge never applied for it. That he did not intend the ≈øaid wine as a bribe, or to influence the Judge in an undue manner. That the Judge ever conducted him≈øelf in an upright manner to the be≈øt of Dep. knowledge‚Äîalways found Judge in his duty, and thought rather too ≈øevere‚Äî≈øigned a paper reque≈øting the indulgence of the ≈øale of the Charlotte‚Äîno pre≈øent, nor bribe given for the indulgence.
In ≈øupport of the 3d.
That he with others petitioned as he thinks for the ≈øale of the Charlotte before condemnation, being ≈øuited for a privateer.

Andrew Robe≈øon ≈øworn ≈øaith, that he is Regi≈øter of the Court of Admiralty. That about the time that the Mar≈øhal made return that certain ≈øhares of ≈øeamen belonging
to the privateer Holker were unrepre≈øented, the Judge mentioned his de≈øign to appoint ≈øuch agents.

The Judge then informed the Dep. in the cour≈øe of conver≈øation, that the Mar≈øhal ≈øhortly after applied to be agent‚ÄîTo which the Judge objected, as he (M.) was an officer of the Court, &c.‚ÄîMar≈øhal urged it on the ≈øcore of friend≈øhip, &c. but the Judge ≈øtill rejected his the M's application. The matter laid ≈øo ≈øome time, when Ma. told Judge that it would an≈øwer as well to appoint M'C. ≈øuch agent. Judge con≈øented to appoint M'C. agent. That he the ≈øaid Judge, afterwards ≈øeeing M'C. and he M'C. ≈øaying nothing on the ≈øubject, the Judge thought for ≈øeveral rea≈øons, it would be be≈øt to appoint ≈øome one el≈øe ≈øuch agent‚Äîfor if ≈øuch things were not worth a≈øking for, they were not receiving.
On que≈øtion.

Dept. in cour≈øe of conver≈øation heard the Judge ≈øay that Gover. Morris had declared that his (G. M.) father u≈øed to receive pre≈øents, and refu≈øed to proceed again≈øt Act of Parliament without; this was introduced as mere matter of chit-chat. After above conver≈øation ≈øome time, Judge informed Dep. that M. and F. were appointed the agents afore≈øaid, and de≈øired him to prepare bonds accordingly.

Dep. heard no more till the M's hearing before Council, when Mar≈øhal mentioned the ≈øub≈øtance of the fir≈øt charge. Judge told Dep. on conver≈øing with him on the ≈øubject, that M. agreed with him that there would be no impropriety in receiving a ≈øuit of cloaths for the exerci≈øe of a di≈øcretionary, and not a judicial power, &c.‚Äî But that afterwards the Judge told the M. that M'C's deportment and ≈øituation was ≈øuch that we would not appoint him the agent afore≈øaid. And he the Judge directed the M. not to mention the ≈øuit of cloaths, as he now viewed it rather in a different light. The Judge told him that M'C. and Miller had in his ab≈øence had ≈øent him (the Judge) a ca≈øk of wine, and never knew any thing of it until Mrs. Hopkin≈øon had informed him.
2d charge.

M. told Dep. that Judge had received a pre≈øent as ≈øtated in 2d charge‚Äîthat Judge knew nothing of it till delivery, and then imagined it was a mi≈øtake. Glouce≈øter's trial was tried after 14 days notice, the cargo was wine, he ≈øhewed from his minutes that the practice in this in≈øtance is not unu≈øual, &c.
3d charge.

That in ≈øome ca≈øes of armed ve≈ø≈øels, orders i≈ø≈øued for apprai≈øement, &c. that in the ca≈øe of the Charlotte, the Mar≈øhal adverti≈øed for ≈øale and ≈øold previous to condemnation, but on the day the trial was to have been, which was deferred by the neglect of the owners to procure proper te≈øtimony, the Judge attended to forbid the ≈øale, but too late.
She was condemned 27th October, and ≈øold 2d September before.
4th charge.

In the ca≈øe of the Albion, a writ of ap‚Äî i≈ø≈øued previous to the order of ≈øale, under a per≈øua≈øion that the cargo was peri≈øhable in its nature and much wanted. But the ≈øaid order for ≈øale was contradicted on the report of certain in≈øpectors that it was not in danger, &c.
Thinks the Judge to be a per≈øon of great integrity.

Miles Filborne being duly affirmed, ≈øaid, that he was one of the in≈øpectors of the cargo of the Charlotte; and when they made their report, that the cargo was in a peri≈øhing condition, ≈øome of the in≈øpectors ob≈øerved that it was a pity the ≈øhip ≈øhould be detained with forms, as ≈øhe would be a good privateer, &c.‚ÄîThe Judge replied that ≈øhe was ≈øo clearly a prize, that ≈øome of the forms might be di≈øpen≈øed with to expedite her condemnation and ≈øale.
Dep. was one of the in≈øpectors of the Albion's cargo.

William Hey≈øham being ≈øworn, depo≈øeth and ≈øaith, that he was one of three to in≈øpect the cargo of the ≈øhip Charlotte‚Äîthey (the in≈øpectors) waited on the Judge to
report, one of them ob≈øerved to the Judge that the ≈øhip was a good fa≈øt failing ve≈ø≈øel, and that ≈øeveral of the owners had expre≈ø≈øed their de≈øire that ≈øhe might be condemned as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, and that they intended to buy and fit her out as a privateer.

The Judge an≈øwered it was a pity that ≈øuch a ≈øhip ≈øhould be delayed. It would be ≈øerving the public to indulge them the owners, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould be condemned as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible‚Äîbut it could not be done without public adverti≈øement, and this is Saturday and it cannot be done till Tue≈øday, but I will grant every indulgence in my power, where the matter is clear.
Dep. was one of the in≈øpectors of the cargo of the Albion, and they reported it well conditioned and in good order.

William Budden being ≈øworn, ≈øaith, that he was one of three, that in≈øpected the cargo of the Charlotte and reported it in a peri≈øhing condition‚Äîthat ≈øome of the in≈øpectors ob≈øerved that the ≈øhip was a fa≈øt ≈øailing ve≈ø≈øel, and that the Judge ≈øaid the condemnation and ≈øale ≈øhould be expedited as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, but it could not be done without public notice, &c.
Dep. was one of the in≈øpectors of the Albion's cargo, and reported it in good order.

Mr. Charles Miller being ≈øworn, acknowledges the papers No. 4 and 5, to be his hand writing‚ÄîDeponent ‚Äîacknowledges to have ≈øent the ca≈øk of wine mentioned in the ≈øecond charge, as a pre≈øent to the Judge on account of former friend≈øhip, and not for the performance of any ≈øpecial purpo≈øe. Dep. never mentioned to any per≈øon his de≈øign of ≈øending the above pre≈øent, con≈øequently the Judge could not know it, until the delivery.

‚òû On the files of the General A≈ø≈øembly there are two ≈øets of depo≈øitions, given in by the witne≈ø≈øes; the ≈øecond copies have been omitted by the editor as immaterial,
except where they throw additional light on the ≈øubject‚Äîtherefore the following is given‚Äî

Charles Miller being duly ≈øworn, depo≈øeth and ≈øaith, that he acknowledges the papers No. 4 and 5, to be his hand writing, he propo≈øed making a pre≈øent to the Judge of a quarter ca≈øk of wine, with the con≈øent of Mr. M'Clenachan. Mr. Hopkin≈øon knew nothing of the wine until it was ≈øent, it was a pre≈øent from him, as Mr. M'Clenachan had ≈øent a pipe to G. Wa≈øhington, he never told his intention of ≈øending the wine to any per≈øon.
Progre≈øs being made in the bu≈øine≈øs.
It was, on motion,
Ordered, That the further hearing of evidence be po≈øtponed till the afternoon.

div.head: Same Day, P. M.
div.p: The Hou≈øe met; and re≈øumed the hearing of evidence in ≈øupport of certain charges exhibited again≈øt the Judge of the Court of Admiralty, for mal-admini≈øtration in his office, &c.
Re≈øolved, That the 1≈øt and 4th of the ≈øaid charges again≈øt the ≈øaid Judge appear to be ≈øupported by legal evidence. (The 4th to be called the 2d.)
Re≈øolved, That the two following charges exhibited in like manner again≈øt the Judge afore≈øaid, are not ≈øupported by the evidence before the Hou≈øe, viz.

That he, the ≈øaid Judge, received pre≈øents from per≈øons intere≈øted in the condemnation of prizes, previous to their condemnation; particularly a ca≈øk of wine from on board the prize brigantine Glouce≈øter, pre≈øented to him by the captors before any condemnation, ≈øale or di≈øtribution.

And, that he, the ≈øaid Judge, connived at, and encouraged the ≈øale of prizes before condemnation, contrary
to law, and maliciou≈øly charged the Mar≈øhal with the crime of ≈øuch conduct before the honorable Supreme Executive Council; in the in≈øtance of the prize ≈øhip Charlotte.
On motion,

Ordered, That the charges, which appear to be ≈øupported by legal evidence, as above declared, be referred to a committee of three: The gentlemen appointed were Mr. J. Smith, Mr. Galbraith, and Mr. Montgomery.

div.head: FRIDAY, December 8.
div.p: THE committee to whom certain charges again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this ≈øtate, for mal-admini≈øtration in his office, were referred on Wedne≈øday la≈øt, made their report, which was, by order, read.
On motion and by ≈øpecial order, it was read a ≈øecond time; whereupon,
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the con≈øideration of the charges afore≈øaid, and came to the following re≈øolutions, viz.

Re≈øolved, That Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this ≈øtate, be impeached for the crime and mi≈ødemeanor expre≈ø≈øed and contained in the fir≈øt charge exhibited again≈øt him; and declared by a re≈øolution of this Hou≈øe of the 6th in≈øtant, to be ≈øupported by legal evidence.
The yeas and nays being required by Mr. Boyd, and Mr. P. Ander≈øon, are as follow, viz.
Re≈øolved, That the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon be al≈øo impeached for the crime and mi≈ødemeanor expre≈ø≈øed and contained in the ≈øecond charge declared as above to be ≈øupported by legal evidence.
The yeas and nays being required, ≈øtand as follows, viz.

Ordered, That Mr. Campbell, Mr. J. Smith, and Mr. Galbraith, prepare and report to the Hou≈øe, proper articles of impeachment to be exhibited again≈øt the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq conformable to the above re≈øolutions.

div.head: SATURDAY, December 9.
div.p:
THE committee appointed ye≈øterday to prepare articles of impeachment again≈øt the Judge of the Court of
Admiralty, for mal-admini≈øtration in his office, made their report, which was read, and ordered to lie on the table for con≈øideration.

div.head: TUESDAY, December 12.
div.p: THE articles of impeachment again≈øt Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of this ≈øtate, prepared and reported by a committee of the Hou≈øe, were read the ≈øecond time, and, on con≈øideration, agreed to, as follows, viz.

ARTICLES of IMPEACHMENT for certain crimes and mi≈ødemeanors, again≈øt FRANCIS HOPKINSON, E≈øq Judge of the Court of Admiralty of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, by the Repre≈øentatives of the Freemen of the ≈øaid commonwealth, in GENERAL ASSEMBLY met, in their own name, and in the name of all the Freemen of the ≈øaid commonwealth; exhibited to the Supreme Executive Council.

Fir≈øt. div.head: MONDAY, December 18.
div.p: PRESENT as above.
Mr. Hopkin≈øon put in the following an≈øwer to the afore≈øaid articles.

The an≈øwer of Francis Hopkin≈øon, Judge of the Court of Admiralty of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, to the articles of impeachment exhibited again≈øt him, by the Repre≈øentatives of the Freemen of the ≈øaid commonwealth, in General A≈ø≈øembly met, in their own name, and in the name of all the Freemen of the commonwealth afore≈øaid.

TO the fir≈øt article the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon ≈øaith, that Matthew Clark≈øon, E≈øquire, late Mar≈øhal, made a
return to him the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon, as Judge of the Court of Admiralty; of certain unrepre≈øented ≈øhares in prizes taken by the privateer called the Holker, ≈øoon after which the ≈øaid Matthew Clark≈øon came to him the ≈øaid Judge, and de≈øired he might be appointed agent for the ≈øaid unrepre≈øented ≈øhares (the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon then being in intimate friend≈øhip with the ≈øaid Matthew Clark≈øon) but the ≈øaid Judge cautiou≈øly declined giving him the ≈øaid Clark≈øon the agency reque≈øted; ob≈øerving to him that the offices of agent and mar≈øhal appeared to be incompatible, and reque≈øting the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal not to urge a compliance with his de≈øire, as ≈øuch an appointment would probably bring cen≈øure on both.

Neverthele≈øs the ≈øaid Matthew Clark≈øon continued to urge the appointment for two or three days, pleading the poverty of his office, declaring the profits thereof did not pay his Clerk, and alledging that the Judge ought from motives of friend≈øhip to throw any little advantage in his way that might occur from the rights of his office.

But the Judge ≈øtill declined the reque≈øt from a ≈øen≈øe of impropriety and apprehen≈øion of cen≈øure. At length the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal told the Judge that finding him ≈øo very nice and difficult, he had been with Mr. Blair M'Clenachan, and made up matters with him; ≈øo that if the Judge would give the agency to Mr. M'Clenachan, of the ≈øhares in que≈øtion, it would an≈øwer his (the Mar≈øhal's) purpo≈øe and intere≈øt ju≈øt as well.

The Judge, happy to be rid of the embarra≈ø≈øments he was under on the ≈øcore of friend≈øhip, gave the ≈øaid Matthew, then Mar≈øhal, rea≈øon to believe (but no ab≈øolute promi≈øe) that Mr. M'Clenachan ≈øhould be appointed agent.

Thus matters re≈øted for ≈øome days, after which the Judge being at the Mar≈øhal's, and they alone in friendly conference; the Judge informed the Mar≈øhal, that a thought had ju≈øt occurred which he would in confidence mention, reque≈øting his opinion thereupon, and declaring he would be bound by it. And then ob≈øerved
to the Mar≈øhal that he was about to throw into Mr. M'Clenachan's hands, many thou≈øand pounds, by giving him the agency.

That Mr. M'Clenachan had wrought him much trouble in his office, had never ≈øhewn civility of any kind, and even neglected the common compliment of his hat, when they met. That he heard much of Mr. M'Clenachan's politene≈øs and genero≈øity to other per≈øons and ≈øubmitted it, whether it would not be as proper, if Mr. M'Clenachan ≈øhould make him a pre≈øent of a ≈øuit of cloaths, as well as to other per≈øons who had not been as beneficent to him or done him ≈øuch ≈øub≈øtantial favours, and finally ob≈øerved that this was a matter of delicacy and doubt. To which the Mar≈øhal replied, that in common ju≈øtice Mr. M'Clenachan ought to make ≈øome acknowledgment for ≈øo con≈øiderable a favour‚Äîthat there was no impropriety or indelicacy in the Judge's receiving ≈øuch a pre≈øent, ≈øhould it be offered; the appointment to an agency not being a judicial act, but a voluntary favour of the Court; no more conver≈øation of any importance pa≈ø≈øed at that time on the ≈øubject.

Some days after, the Judge a≈øked the Mar≈øhal whether he had ever mentioned any thing of this affair to Mr. M'Clenachan, who replied that he had not had a favorable opportunity, and the≈øe were the only times in which the matter was touched upon; excepting that ≈øome ≈øhort time after the Judge thinking on further con≈øideration that the thing was improper, declared his better ≈øentiments to the Mar≈øhal, and ab≈øolutely forbid him proceeding in it. But told the Mar≈øhal he ≈øhould expect Mr. M'Clenachan would at lea≈øt a≈øk the Judge for the agency, a ceremony he never di≈øpen≈øed with‚Äîas he thought the favour worth a≈øking for, if worth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing; and declared he would never make the favours of his office ≈øo cheap as to force them on per≈øons who would not conde≈øcend to reque≈øt them.

Mr. M'Clenachan however neglecting to a≈øk for the agency in que≈øtion, the Judge frequently urged this ≈øentiment to the Mar≈øhal, which circum≈øtance the ≈øaid
Mar≈øhal hath in his depo≈øition fal≈øely and maliciou≈øly applied to the ≈øuit of cloaths, all ideas of which had long ≈øince been totally di≈øcarded by the Judge. After this, above a fortnight pa≈ø≈øed, in all which time Mr. M'Clenachan never called upon the Judge, or gave the lea≈øt intimation that the agency would be acceptable to him. The matter was al≈øo dropped by the Mar≈øhal, who ≈øeemed rather to avoid any conver≈øation on the ≈øubject. In the interim, other rea≈øons occurred to the Judge for not appointing Mr. M'Clenochan agent, one of which was, that he was a principal owner of the Holker, and another, becau≈øe the Mar≈øhal having had great good fortune in the arrival of a valuable prize (the Needham) taken by one of his privateers, the Judge thought the agency was no longer an object with him: And la≈øtly, becau≈øe the Judge on reflection thought him≈øelf right in refu≈øing to make the Mar≈øhal agent, but found it would be continuing the ≈øub≈øtance, only altering the form, in appointing Mr. M'Clenachan agent, knowing that it was to ≈øerve the purpo≈øe and intere≈øt of the Mar≈øhal.
For all the≈øe rea≈øons, and to relieve him≈øelf at once from ≈øurrounding difficulties, he finally gave the agency to Me≈ø≈ørs. Meade and Fitz≈øimons.

It is not to be wondered at that Mr. M'Clenachan did not apply for the agency. As it appears ≈øince, that he was totally ignorant of the whole affair; Mr. Clark≈øon having never mentioned the matter to him at all, till after the appointment of Me≈ø≈ørs. Meade and Fitz≈øimons, having impo≈øed a fal≈øhood on the Judge to ≈øerve his own avaricious purpo≈øes.

As to the ≈øecond charge, the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon ≈øaith, that the ≈øhip Albion was captured in the North ≈øeas by two ve≈ø≈øels belonging to Robert Morris, E≈øq and others, ≈øent into this port and libelled here. It appeared from her papers exhibited to the Judge that her cargo was altogether ≈øalt, being eight or nine thou≈øand bu≈øhels. A claim was al≈øo filed on behalf of her Maje≈øty the Empre≈øs of Ru≈ø≈øia; as ≈øalt was ≈øcarce at that time,
the Judge hoping to do a public ≈øervice without injury to any individual, waited on Mr. Morris, and ob≈øerved to him, that as a claim was filed, the deci≈øion might be dilatory, that if the cargo waited till condemnation, it would be di≈øtributed in kind, and ≈øo fall into the hands of a few. That he thought ≈øalt water-born, and after ≈øo long a voyage might properly be con≈øidered as a peri≈øhable article, and ≈øold by vendue before condemnation under the Act of A≈ø≈øembly; and that it would be very popular and a public good, if this ≈øalt ≈øhould be ≈øold in ≈ømall lots, ≈øo that the hou≈øe-keepers might have an opportunity of ≈øupplying them≈øelves rea≈øonably.

To this Mr. Morris after a day's interval con≈øented, and a writ of ≈øale in the common form was i≈ø≈øued, and the ≈øalt adverti≈øed to be ≈øold. His Excellency the Pre≈øident ≈øeeing the adverti≈øment, took offence and wrote to the Mar≈øhal on the ≈øubject. The Judge on ≈øeeing this letter waited on the Pre≈øident and declared his motives.

The Pre≈øident ob≈øerved that if the law was inconvenient, methods might be taken to have it amended; but that whil≈øt it was the law, it ought to be held ≈øacred; and that ≈øalt could not be con≈øidered as a peri≈øhable article within the meaning of the Act. The Judge, in deference to the Pre≈øident's opinion, immediately ordered a ≈øurvey; and on the report of the Surveyors, that the cargo was not in a peri≈øhable condition, countermanded the ≈øale, and the cargo remained untouched 'till after condemnation.

And the ≈øaid Francis Hopkin≈øon, by and under prote≈øtation, that the ≈øaid articles, and the matter in the ≈øame contained are not ≈øufficient in law to maintain the afore≈øaid impeachment again≈øt him; and ≈øaving to him≈øelf (and which he prayeth may be ≈øaved to him) both now and at all times hereafter, all and all manner of benefit and advantage of exception to the in≈øufficiency of the ≈øaid articles in point of law: Neverthele≈øs for plea thereto he ≈øaith, that he is in no wi≈øe guilty of all or any the crimes, offences or mi≈ødemeanors, of what nature,
kind or quality ≈øoever, by the ≈øaid articles of impeachment charged upon him, in manner and form, as in and by the ≈øaid articles is ≈øuppo≈øed.

Wherefore he ≈øubmitteth him≈øelf, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ ju≈øtice of his cau≈øe, to this honorable Court, and prayeth to be di≈øcharged of the premi≈øes, and to be hence di≈ømi≈ø≈øed and acquitted of all the matters, crimes, mi≈ødemeanors and offences, in and by the ≈øaid articles of impeachment charged upon him.
FRANCIS HOPKINSON.
Philadelphia, Dec. 18, 1780.

That it hath been the ≈øtated cu≈øtom for the Regi≈øter of the Court of Admiralty to draw out and deliver to the Mar≈øhal, the bills of co≈øts, in every cau≈øe, and for the Mar≈øhal to collect and account with the Judge for the ≈øum total of his the Judge's fees. Que≈ø. Have you ever had any particular directions from the Judge as to the manner of making out the charges?
An≈ø. He directed in general, that in ≈øuch ca≈øes the bill ≈øhould be made out upon the former u≈øage.
Que≈ø. Re≈øpecting the claims of a negro for his freedom?
An≈ø. The claims of negroes for their freedom are never charged.
Que≈ø. You have mentioned, that bills of expences are frequently made out before they really become due, has tho≈øe fees ever been demanded before the ≈øervice was performed?
An≈ø. I don't know what may be meant by demanded; I under≈øtand, that the Mar≈øhal pays the fees to the Judge as the Judge's nece≈ø≈øity may require, or as the Mar≈øhal may be in ca≈øh.

Ques. In ca≈øes where bills are made out before the ≈øervices are done, is it done by the reque≈øt of the parties or not?
An≈ø. It is always done at the reque≈øt of the parties, and for the expedition of their bu≈øine≈øs.

Mr. Ro≈øs frequently looked at the bills, and where a charge for holding a court was omitted, he directed me to make it.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Wil≈øon. Do you recollect any in≈øtance where eight ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels were contained in one libel?
An≈ø. Yes, in the ca≈øe of Kemp, in which Mr. Bank≈øon was Attorney, and either at his reque≈øt or the‚Äî
Que≈ø. You have been intimately acquainted with the Judge. Have you ever ob≈øerved him to be di≈øpo≈øed to exact with ≈øeverity the fees to the utmo≈øt?
An≈ø. I never ob≈øerved any thing of this ≈øort. The que≈øtion re≈øpecting the mode of charging the fees‚Äî
Que≈ø. Do you know of any in≈øtance of a ≈øtipulation being demanded, where the party was too poor to pay?
An≈ø. By ≈øeveral ca≈øes to ≈øhew that in the ca≈øe of per≈øons being too poor to pay, the fees were not demanded, but where claims have been made by ≈øeamen‚Äî
Que≈ø. Did you ever know of any in≈øtance of the Judge's hinting to any per≈øon that he expected a pre≈øent?

An≈ø. I know nothing of the kind, or of any pre≈øents that were made him, except a ≈ømall chicken turtle ≈øent him by ≈øome captain, whether by a claimant in the court or not, I cannot tell, and of the wine which has been talked of; I recollect that a captain who had a cau≈øe depending, ≈øending a chee≈øe to the Judge, which he refu≈øed to accept and ≈øent it back.

div.head: Mr. Fitz≈øimons, ≈øworn.
div.p: In June la≈øt Mr. Hopkin≈øon called at our counting-hou≈øe, and offered the hou≈øe of Meade and Fitz≈øimons the agency of the unrepre≈øented ≈øhares, which they agreed to accept and entered on the bu≈øine≈øs. On applying to the Mar≈øhal he ≈øeemed di≈ø≈øatisfied, ≈øaid the agency had been di≈øpo≈øed of or promi≈øed, and mea≈øurs taken in con≈øequence of that promi≈øe and money paid thereupon. Upon receiving this an≈øwer I informed the Judge, he ≈øaid there had been ≈øome ≈øuch promi≈øe, but that Mr. M'Clenachan never had applied regularly for an appointment, and on further con≈øideration he did not think it proper to appoint one who was ≈øo largely concerned in privateers, that witne≈øs offered to re≈øign the agency, if the Judge, Mar≈øhal &c. could agree among them≈øelves. They afterwards met at the Judge's hou≈øe on the bu≈øine≈øs, when a compromi≈øe was agreed to, which was, that all the monies M'C. could ≈øhew he had paid on the unrepre≈øented ≈øhares ≈øhould be paid to him, and the balances to be paid to Me≈ø≈ørs. M. and Fitz≈øimons.
Judge never intimated to him that he expected any pre≈øent either directly or indirectly.
Nothing pa≈ø≈øed in the conver≈øations from which the witne≈øs knew that any gratuity was expected by the Judge for appointing M'Clenachan.

div.head: Capt. William Hey≈øham, Sworn, being called by the committee.

An≈ø. Yes in my judgment.
Mr. Lewis called up, and a≈øked.
Que≈ø. What do you know of the Judge (Hopkin≈øon) admitting eight ve≈ø≈øels in one libel?

An≈ø. Mr. Hopkin≈øon applied to me to know what was my opinion of admitting eight ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels in one libel, expre≈ø≈øing an earne≈øt de≈øire that it might be done to ≈øave charges, if it was con≈øi≈øtent with law to do it. I knew of but one in≈øtance in point, and in that the Judge (Mr. Ro≈øs) ordered ≈øeparate libels to be filed, but that I knew of no rule of law, in the ca≈øe, and that therefore I thought it might be admitted. div.head: TUESDAY, December 26.
div.p: PRESENT his exellency the Pre≈øident, the honorable the Vice-Pre≈øident, Mr. Lacey, Mr. Potter, Mr. Piper and Mr. Read.

The Council having met agreeable to adjournment. Mr. Smith of the committee of the General A≈ø≈øembly attending, and Francis Hopkin≈øon, E≈øq al≈øo attending, the Pre≈øident read the following DECREE.
IT is not u≈øual to enter into the rea≈øons of the judgment upon occa≈øions of this kind, but the importance of the pre≈øent pro≈øecution makes it nece≈ø≈øary.

In the fir≈øt place it is ob≈øervable, that the commi≈ø≈øion of the Judge is during good behaviour; crimes only are cau≈øes of removal‚Äîthe cau≈øe is of great importance as it re≈øpects the officer, and as it comes from the Repre≈øentatives of the people.

It certainly is of the greate≈øt con≈øequence, that the ≈øtreams of ju≈øtice be kept pure‚ÄîWe act in the double capacity of Judges and Jury‚ÄîIt therefore became our duty, and we have examined minutely into the evidence‚ÄîIt is immaterial from what motives the pro≈øecution has originated, any farther than to determine how far it may affect the credibility of the witne≈ø≈øes‚Äî perhaps few public pro≈øecutions have taken their ri≈øe from pure regard to the public good, nor is it of any con≈øequence with what views the A≈ø≈øembly forwarded the impeachment‚ÄîWhether it is ≈øupported, is the only object of our enquiry‚ÄîThe cau≈øe has been ably argued on both ≈øides.‚Äî
The Pre≈øident then read the fir≈øt article.

The late Mar≈øhal, Mr. Clark≈øon, ≈øwears, that in a conver≈øation he had with Mr. Hopkin≈øon, (te≈øtimony of Mr. Clark≈øon read) the ≈øtre≈øs of the pro≈øecution mu≈øt depend on this te≈øtimony of Mr. Clark≈øon, he him≈øelf
does not ≈øtate the ≈øuit of cloaths as a condition, or ≈øine qua non, without which Mr. M'Clenachan was not to have the agency; ≈øeveral circum≈øtances ≈øeem to confirm what the Judge ≈øays, that he mentioned this matter as a thought that had occurred to him, and by way of taking the opinion of his friend upon it‚ÄîThe Judge and Mr. Clark≈øon were at that time intimate friends‚Äî he took no notice of it, until after the Judge had complained again≈øt him. He was exceedingly di≈øgu≈øted at the agency not being given to Mr. M'Clenachan‚Äîit ≈øeems ≈øtrange if he thought this had been made a condition that he made no mention of it in his complaints. Either the Mar≈øhal approved the pro≈øecution or he did not‚Äîif he did not, why not ≈øay ≈øo. If he did, why not mention it to Mr. M'Clenachan, if he thought it a condition not countermanded‚Äîthe ≈øtory of want of opportunity could not have been the rea≈øon, for he mentioned the agency‚Äîit would have required but a few words more to have mentioned the condition had there been one.

In the next place, tho' Mr. M'Clenachan does not recollect any countermand, yet as the Judge gave the agency to Me≈ø≈ørs. Meade & Fitz≈øimons, not only without receiving any compliment, but as no hint or ≈øugge≈øtion was made that any ≈øuch was expected, this looks like confirmatory of the repre≈øentation made by the Judge. Mr. Clark≈øon in one part of his te≈øtimony is very po≈øitive, in another very cautious, ≈øo far as re≈øpects the mention of the ≈øuit of cloaths, he is entirely clear‚Äî as to any explanatory circum≈øtances he does not remember‚ÄîHe is a≈øked, did the Judge reque≈øt your opinion and advice upon the point? he does not recollect‚ÄîIf he is cautious in determining the complexion of the bu≈øine≈øs, ≈øurely we ought to be in founding our opinion. ‚ÄîIndeed we ≈øhould have had very little difficulty had it not been for the te≈øtimony of Mr. Lewis‚Äîbut the conver≈øation between him and the Judge happened a good while ago‚Äîa few words make a great difference‚Äî a gentleman cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed to recollect with an entire exactne≈øs‚Äîwe cannot but con≈øider Mr. Lewis as
a ≈øecondary witne≈øs, and therefore cannot overrule the pre≈øumption ari≈øing in favour of the Judge upon Mr. Clark≈øon's te≈øtimony from the circum≈øtances that have been mentioned‚Äîbut here another que≈øtion ari≈øes, quo animo? with what mind was this done‚Äîfor a great deal depends upon the intent‚Äîevery killing is not murder ‚Äîon a di≈øpa≈ø≈øionate con≈øideration of the character of the Judge, his general conduct in office, and all the circum≈øtances we do not think there is any proof of corruption‚Äîwe could have left this charge without any further animadver≈øion had it not been for ≈øome doctrines advanced by the coun≈øel for the Judge, which we think proper to make ≈øome ob≈øervations upon.‚ÄîIn an in≈øtant State it is of the highe≈øt importance, as we ≈øaid before, that the ≈øtreams of ju≈øtice ≈øhould be kept pure, and that the people ≈øhould have a confidence in the integrity of the Judges.‚ÄîNot only the taking a bribe, but even ≈øoliciting it, tho' not falling perhaps ≈øtrictly within the definition of bribery would draw down the vengeance of the State‚ÄîWhether for a Judicial officer or one that did not concern the admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice, whether by a Judge ≈øitting on the ≈øeat of Ju≈øtice or this Council in their capacity as ≈øuch; the office of a Vendue-Ma≈øter is not a judicial office, but we ≈øhould e≈øteem it criminal for any member of this Council to accept a compen≈øation for his vote to an appointment in that office.‚ÄîThe man who can be≈øt ≈øerve the public is the proper object of choice, it is enough that the office is an office of tru≈øt, whether judicial or not makes no difference‚Äîand we think the ob≈øervation of the Attorney-General that the appointment of an agent is done by the Judge, as ≈øuch, is well founded, and if we had been ≈øatisfied of the fact, that the Judge had either received or ≈øolicited a compen≈øation in this con≈øideration we ≈øhould have been at no lo≈øs to have declared him guilty‚Äîand we take this opportunity to mention that we conceive it indelicate for a Judge to accept pre≈øents from per≈øons who frequently have bu≈øine≈øs
before him, tho' no cau≈øe be then depending, ≈øuch as owners of privateers.‚ÄîIn ≈øhort the pre≈øent ≈øhould appear to be made to the MAN, and not to the OFFICER.
The Pre≈øident then read the ≈øecond article.

The Judge acknowledges that he did make a mi≈øtake in the i≈ø≈øuing the writ, and upon being informed of the error rectified it‚Äîto make a Judge an≈øwerable for the veracity of every a≈ø≈øertion contained in the forms of proce≈øs would be very unrea≈øonable‚ÄîI will not ≈øay how far a Judge may be an≈øwerable in a criminal pro≈øecution for giving a judgment contrary to a plain law; but then it mu≈øt appear that he acted wilfully wrong, and not from hone≈øt, tho' ill judged de≈øigns‚Äîbut here was a point of ≈øome doubt.‚ÄîThe Judge ≈øuppo≈øed, and there was ≈øome colour for the idea that the law was merely directory; that he was to have recour≈øe to the intervention of a ≈øurvey only in ca≈øe of uncertainty, and to inform his con≈øcience‚Äîbut that where he was at no lo≈øs for the very nature of the article to determine it peri≈øhable, of cour≈øe, that the ≈øtep was unnece≈ø≈øary.‚ÄîSalt is thus con≈øidered ≈øometimes.‚ÄîIf for in≈øtance, in≈øurance is made on it at ≈øea, it is treated as a peri≈øhable article.‚Äî If a mere error of judgment was to be turned into a ≈øubject for criminal pro≈øecution, we mu≈øt, as was ob≈øerved by one of the learned coun≈øel for the Judge, get infallible Judges. We are therefore at no lo≈øs to pronounce an acquittal upon this article, more e≈øpecially as the mi≈øtake was rectified as ≈øoon as di≈øcovered.
The Pre≈øident then read the third article.
This charge has been con≈øidered by many to be more likely to endanger the Judge, and to occa≈øion a ≈øentence to his di≈øadvantage, than the others.

The Judge an≈øwers that he took fees according to the former tables, and the practice e≈øtabli≈øhed at his coming into office. Now, altho' the degree of puni≈øhment ought not to make any difference, nor enter into con≈øideration where the matter is plainly proved, yet more caution becomes nece≈ø≈øary in proportion to the con≈øequences
of conviction‚Äîin this ca≈øe the penalty by the Con≈øtitution is very great.
26th ≈øection of the Con≈øtitution of the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania, e≈øtabli≈øhed in 1776.
Court of Se≈ø≈øions, Common-pleas and Orphans' Courts ≈øhall be held quarterly in each city and county; and the Legi≈ølature ≈øhall have power to e≈øtabli≈øh all ≈øuch other courts as they may judge for the good of the inhabitants of the State. All courts ≈øhall be open, and ju≈øtice ≈øhall be impartially admini≈øtered without corruption, or unnece≈ø≈øary delay: All their officers ≈øhall be paid an adequate but moderate compen≈øation for their ≈øervices: And if any officer ≈øhall take greater or other fees than the laws allow him, either directly or indirectly, it ≈øhall ever after di≈øqualify him from holding any office in this State.

There are in almo≈øt all offices compen≈øatory as well as ≈øpecific fees.‚ÄîIn fee laws, laws made for the regulating the fees of officers, it is very difficult to enumerate all the ≈øervices. In ≈øuch ca≈øes compen≈øatory fees mu≈øt be allowed, or the nece≈ø≈øary bu≈øine≈øs will not be done. There is a great difference between exacting more than the ≈øpecific fees, and a≈øking fees for ≈øervices where nothing is provided.‚ÄîBut it is ≈øaid that the law on which this charge is founded, intended to have excluded all other fees except the wheat. But every part of this law was not attended to. In a preceding paragraph it is ≈øaid, that the fees of the ≈øaid officers ≈øhall be e≈øtimated and paid according to the price of good merchantable wheat in the manner following, that is to ≈øay, the ≈øaid fees as they were regulated by law or practice under the late government of Penn≈øylvania before the fir≈øt day of July one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ≈øeventy-≈øix, ≈øhall from and after the publication of this Act be ≈øatisfied in good merchantable wheat; accounting and allowing that a bu≈øhel of ≈øuch wheat, weighing at lea≈øt ≈øixty pounds, ≈øold formerly in times of war and difficulty for ten Shillings. The fifth paragraph mentions that this former one ≈øhall extend to the Judge, Regi≈øter and Mar≈øhal of the Court of Admiralty.

It appears therefore in this very law, the principle of making a difference between ≈øpecific and compen≈øatory fees was adopted‚Äîformerly by an Act of Parliament, the
Judges of the court of Admiralty in the then province of Penn≈øylvania, were allowed ¬£. 15 ≈øterling for every ve≈ø≈øel above 100 tons, and ¬£ 10 for every ve≈ø≈øel below that burthen‚Äîas the ≈øame number of tons is mentioned in this Act of A≈ø≈øembly, as applied to the twenty-five bu≈øhels of wheat and the forty, it ≈øeems probable that this was intended in lieu of tho≈øe ≈øums. On this con≈øtruction the law is con≈øi≈øtent and complete, and the law and practice agree, and it mu≈øt appear that the ¬£ 1300 taken by the Judge exceeds what he was entitled to by this mode of computation‚Äîhere were three cau≈øes; the fir≈øt, libel to decide prize or no prize‚Äîthat is the object of the law‚Äîthen the claim by Mr. Morris‚Äîthen the negroes; the≈øe are three as di≈øtinct cau≈øes as if they related to different ve≈ø≈øels. At this rate the fees would have amounted to ¬£ 1320‚Äîbut ≈øuppo≈øe the matter had not ≈øtood entirely on this ground, and that it had appeared the ¬£ 1300 was a ≈øum beyond what the Judge was entitled to, ≈øtill the charge is not, that he received too much, but that he exacted too much. We do not ≈øay, that the Judge ought not to take care of his officers ‚ÄîBut an inadvertence of this kind would not be a ground for rendering a man infamous for life. On looking into the authorities we found they all run in this ≈øtile‚Äî that the Judges exacted‚Äîthat bu≈øine≈øs was kept back and delays affected until the money was paid‚Äî≈øuppo≈øe the court wrong, they ought not to be immediately pro≈øecuted in a criminal way, but complaint ≈øhould be made, and if they will not rectify the mi≈øtake, then it will be proper to pur≈øue in a cour≈øe of ju≈øtice‚Äîat the ≈øame time we take this opportunity to ≈øay, that the fees of the court of Admiralty have increa≈øed lately extremely, not in the time of the pre≈øent Judge; indeed, he took things as he found them; as to the agency I do not conceive it to be the ≈øpirit and meaning of the act of A≈ø≈øembly, that one ≈øhould be appointed to every ve≈ø≈øel where there are unrepre≈øented ≈øhares‚Äîthe holding of courts for mini≈øterial purpo≈øes is wrong al≈øo‚Äîthis practice has taken ri≈øe within four or five years‚Äîit's
di≈øtre≈ø≈øing to trade‚Äîall the mini≈øterial bu≈øine≈øs ≈øhould be done at the holding of ≈øome court, or at chambers‚Äî the other mode is a ≈øtrained con≈øtruction of the meaning of holding a court‚Äîit is a matter that I am de≈øired to mention, that the Judge direct the Regi≈øter to prepare a book in which he is to enter all the items of the bills of co≈øts‚Äîthat people may always know whether they pay unrea≈øonably‚Äîthe Judge it ≈øeems tru≈øted to the Regi≈øter, and the bill mu≈øt have been made out in the lump, as it agrees exactly with no rule. When this is done, if on complaint made, errors are not rectified, there will be a proper ground for criminal pro≈øecution. UPON THE WHOLE, WE ARE UNANIMOUSLY OF OPINION THAT THE JUDGE OUGHT TO BE ACQUITTED UPON ALL THE THREE CHARGES.
AN ACCOUNT OF THE IMPEACHMENT, TRIAL, AND ACQUITTAL OF JOHN NICHOLSON, ESQUIRE, COMPTROLLER-GENERAL OF THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY FRANCIS BAILEY, AT YORICK'S HEAD, No. 116, HIGH-STREET. M,DCC,XCIV.

div.head: AN ACCOUNT OF THE IMPEACHMENT, TRIAL, AND ACQUITTAL &c.

On Tue≈øday the 4th day of December, in the year of our Lord, 1792, and ≈øixteenth of the Independence of the United States, the Repre≈øentatives of the Freemen of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, met at the State-hou≈øe in Philadelphia, and proceeded to bu≈øine≈øs.
div.p: ON the 7th they appointed John Swanwick, Thomas Forre≈øt, John Chapman, John Hannum, Samuel Boyd, John Stewart, James Power, Nicholas Lutz, Jacob Eyerly, jun. George Woods, jun. John White, Abraham Hendricks, David Bradford, Albert Gallatin, James John≈øton, Cadwallader Evans, Simon Spalding, Stacy Potts, Thomas Morton and William We≈øt, E≈øqrs. a committee to devi≈øe ways and means for the ≈øupplies of the current year.
On the next day John Canan of Huntingdon county was added to the ≈øame committee.
On the 4th of January following, a letter was received from the State-Trea≈øurer, from which the following is an extract.

body.p:
"FULLY convinced in my own mind, indeed I may ≈øay from my po≈øitive knowledge, that it never was
the intention of the Legi≈ølature to embrace within the redemption the ≈øo called New-Loan certificates, which in fact never were a ≈øtate debt.

"I was much ≈øurpri≈øed (when after ob≈øerving among the li≈øt of purcha≈øers the name of John Nichol≈øon for 65,000 dols. all paid for in redeemable debt without any money) to ≈øee in the hands of Mr. Morris's Clerk, warrants amounting in the whole to 63,093 35/100 dols. exclu≈øive of an order on me for 4621 60/100 dols. due Mr. Nichol≈øon for Dollar-money redeemed, which he pre≈øented to me as payment for ≈øtock in lieu of money.

"The warrants were properly ≈øigned and counter≈øigned, I could not refu≈øe payment; I a≈øked him if he knew how they originated, he ≈øaid he did not, but that Mr. Morris had borrowed them that morning from Mr. Nichol≈øon. Having previou≈øly heard that one or more hawkers employed by, and even the Comptroller-General him≈øelf were running about town purcha≈øing up New-Loans, and that they were ≈øo eager in the pur≈øuit that they had rai≈øed the market price on them≈øelves from 20 É to 21 É6, I got alarmed.

"I ≈øent a confidential Clerk to the office of the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans, he returned and told me, that he ≈øaw Mr. Nichol≈øon's name in the ≈øub≈øcription book, but no ≈øum annexed to it. The next morning I went down to Mr. Smith and a≈øked him if Mr. Nichol≈øon or any body el≈øe had ≈øub≈øcribed New-Loans, he an≈øwered they had, put his hand in a drawer be≈øide him, and pulled out a bundle of New-Loans and ≈øaid, the Comptroller-General ≈øub≈øcribed the≈øe and certified them to be genuine and a≈ø≈øumable ≈øtate debt and when he did, he left the ≈øub≈øcription blank, and ≈øaid, he had more to bring.

"I waited on his Excellency the Governor, the Secretary of the commonwealth, and the Regi≈øter-General, and an immediate ≈øtop was put to this, in my conception, unwarrantable career of ≈øpeculation, a few more warrants of le≈øs moment than the Comptroller's having been previou≈øly paid.

"The honorable Legi≈ølature will pardon me for being thus lengthy, when I declare, that viewing the ≈øubject as I do, it is not only a direct violation of law, but a glaring impo≈øition on the public.

"I have made ≈øeveral calculations; the mo≈øt moderate and exact of which is a nett profit to the ≈øpeculator of near 25 per cent. If the original entries of tho≈øe tran≈øactions are had recour≈øe to in the offices of accounts, they will ≈øhew that my calculations are not exaggerated.
"Be plea≈øed Sir to pre≈øent to the honorable Hou≈øe enclo≈øure B. being a memorial ≈øoliciting to be re-appointed Trea≈øurer for the en≈øuing year.
