div.p: On the motion of Mr. Gallatin, ≈øeconded by Mr. Evans, the above letter was referred to the committee on ways and means to report thereon.
On the 8th the following letters from Mr. Nichol≈øon, were pre≈øented to the Speakers of both Hou≈øes, read, and ordered to lie for con≈øideration.

body.p: "I UNDERSTAND a communication from Chri≈øtian Febiger, E≈øq Trea≈øurer, was ye≈øterday read in the Legi≈ølature, containing reflections again≈øt me; knowing my own conduct, I feel my≈øelf perfectly ≈øecure from injury by any a≈ø≈øault he may make, and I defy and de≈øpi≈øe the attempts, he or any other enemy I have, may make again≈øt me.

"But without regarding the character of the man, it is proper that I ≈øhould take ≈øome notice thereof, I do not wi≈øh that the motives of malice which actuate him, may operate to relax from the ≈øtricte≈øt ≈øcrutiny into my conduct. I have this morning applied for and ju≈øt now obtained
from the a≈ø≈øi≈øtant clerk of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, a copy of the repre≈øentation alluded to, and was referred to the Printer, where I ≈øaw the ≈øtatement therein referred to.

"On examination I find nothing therein but what hath already been ≈øtated in the joint report of the Regi≈øter-General and my≈øelf on the revenues to the Governor, and which hath been heretofore laid before you, except the po≈øitive opinion (for they merit not the name of rea≈øons) of Mr. Febiger, and ≈øome deductions therefrom which are worthy of him≈øelf.

"The facts being ≈øtated and before the Legi≈ølature, I ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe they needed not the aid of Mr. Febiger's opinion on the ≈øubject: If any members of the pre≈øent Hou≈øe regret the parting with the ≈øtock in the manner which was done, or the mode of the redemption of the debt, whether that, on which an intere≈øt had been payable half yearly, the unfunded depreciation debt, or the New-Loan debt (the two latter of which were only redeemable through the intervention of the Loan of the United States). They will find the cau≈øes thereof in the Redemption Act of la≈øt year; and while they lament the adoption of ≈øuch a ≈øy≈øtem, when a more advantageous one was within their reach, they have al≈øo to be thankful to Congre≈øs that it was no wor≈øe, for had the Legi≈ølature of the United States thought proper to have adopted the ≈øy≈øtem of loaning State debts in the extent and manner in which it was fir≈øt brought before Congre≈øs, this law would al≈øo have obligated the ≈øtate to have immediately paid for all the old Bills of Credit emitted by the ≈øtate to carry on the war, and which might have been ≈øub≈øcribed to the Loan of the Union.

"I fore≈øaw, the effects that bill if pa≈ø≈øed, would have when it was before the Legi≈ølature, and did not fail, to members of both Hou≈øes, to deprecate the con≈øequences of enacting it, both as it regarded the parting with ≈øtock and the redemption of the debt, and al≈øo mentioned its operation with re≈øpect to the ≈øeveral cla≈ø≈øes of debt afore≈øaid.

"When it became a law, I availed my≈øelf of the advantage it pre≈øented as well as others, the proceedings are regular, the invitation for ≈øtock was public, all might apply, and the propo≈øals by Mr. Febiger, either by him≈øelf or his "confidential Clerk" were as welcome as any other. With re≈øpect to the debt redeemed and for whom, it al≈øo ≈øtands on record, and hath been already laid before you, and in my purcha≈øes or application for redemption, I never u≈øed the name of another, not even a "confidential Clerk," had I thought it wrong I ≈øhould not have done it, and it generally argues a conviction of impropriety to u≈øe the cover of another name, but this will be remembered that my purcha≈øes were not with the public money.

"As to the rates at which I purcha≈øed, they were ≈øuch as afforded a profit, or I would not have made them, although as he ob≈øerves, and I ≈øuppo≈øe found, a competition of prices, ≈øoon brought up their value in the market, but it is none of his bu≈øine≈øs what the≈øe profits were.

"There are I ≈øuppo≈øe mi≈øtakes in the copy given me, where it reads, 365,000; 863,093 55/100 and 84,621 60/100 ari≈øing from his mode of prefixing his figures, the fir≈øt 8 in the three ca≈øes I pre≈øume were not originally ≈øo de≈øigned, taking this to be the ca≈øe, or otherwi≈øe I can't ≈øee what he hath to do with the bu≈øine≈øs; whether payment of my warrant was made to Mr. Morris, my≈øelf, or any other per≈øon, to whom I cho≈øe to give an order, nor do I ≈øee why he ≈øhould trouble the Legi≈ølature with the ≈øtory of my giving Mr. Morris an order for the principal and intere≈øt of the Dollar-money al≈øo redeemable.

"The Dollar-money however was not mine, it belonged to a per≈øon who I believe thought him≈øelf degraded in finding Mr. Febiger appointed to ≈øucceed him in an office he re≈øigned and had once filled.

"From the ≈øtile of his letter one would think he had the merit, if there were any merit in it, of effecting every thing as well in the department of the Governor,
as in that of the Regi≈øter-General and Secretary of the commonwealth, and that he had put a ≈øtop to it; the fact is the limited period put a ≈øtop to further ≈øub≈øcriptions, but tho≈øe few ≈øub≈øcribed, a≈ø≈øigned and not paid, will yet be done, the parties are legally entitled thereto, but as a doubt aro≈øe with the Governor, I paid Judge Addi≈øon the ca≈øh for the amount of his ≈øecond ≈øub≈øcription for which he was waiting that he might not he delayed as he was from a remote part of the State; the others were of this city and they have not ≈øince been brought forward till every objection be removed, but then the parties claim payment as their legal right. There remains but one thing more in Mr. Febiger's letter to notice, and that is the information from Mr. Smith's office by his confidential Clerk and him≈øelf. They are both mi≈øtaken or wor≈øe, I never delayed an account at that office for ≈øub≈øcription till more ≈øhould be added. The fir≈øt I took with the certificates, I made two copies of, to expedite my bu≈øine≈øs, I left one of them with the Loan-officer, the other I got him to certify immediately, and it was transferred before I left the office, the next was a few days after and contained what I had purcha≈øed in the interim, I ≈øent them down by a me≈ø≈øenger, and by him al≈øo they were brought back without remaining for any additional certificates to be added.
"On enquiry of Mr. Smith I find (as I expected) that Mr. Febiger got no ≈øuch information from him.

body.p:
"AS the accounts of Chri≈øtian Febiger, E≈øq as Trea≈øurer hath been laid before you with his late repre≈øentation and they al≈øo come under my con≈øideration, it may be proper to remark thereon, that the payments
of intere≈øt of the New-Loan debt in bills of credit as appears in ≈øaid accounts is in violation of the Act of the Legi≈ølature of the 7th April, 1791, which excepted tho≈øe bills from re-i≈ø≈øue or payment, and I was a≈øtoni≈øhed on the exchange of the New-Loan certificates lately for Jo≈øeph Pennel, E≈øq to be informed by him that he had ju≈øt been paid in tho≈øe bills and was unable to get any other, and wanted to know what he could do to get the money, I ob≈øerve it is only to ≈øome per≈øons this intere≈øt hath been ≈øo paid therein.

"In his letter and in his accounts, he expre≈ø≈øes a de≈øire that the Legi≈ølature would direct what is to be done with the old continental money and equivalents in his hands, they have already directed them to lie in the Trea≈øury, which in my opinion is the be≈øt thing that could yet be done with them. But hath he ob≈øerved the≈øe directions? no; if you look at his accounts No. 13, you will find that he hath been di≈øpo≈øing thereof of his own authority, and in a former account he hath di≈øpo≈øed of far the greater part of the whole continental money on like authority, and he had even the confidence to declare to me that he knew, at the time he did it that it was not authorized by the Legi≈ølature. The A≈ø≈øembly will plea≈øe to ob≈øerve that at the ≈øame time an offer was made the Legi≈ølature of ten per cent. advance upon what they would get if they cho≈øe to loan it to the United States. As I will never pa≈øs the≈øe ≈øums to his credit in violation of law and as in my e≈øtimation, they will be of more value than he ever will be able to pay, I think it nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo to inform the Legi≈ølature that he hath neglected to give and record the ≈øurety required of him in the manner directed by law. The Hou≈øe need not be informed that his former ≈øureties will not be bound for him under another appointment. There is one thing more which hath in ≈øome mea≈øure delayed the ≈øettlement of his accounts, notwith≈øtanding the Clerk of the late Trea≈øurer (who was at fir≈øt employed by him, and ≈øo cruelly treated afterwards) mu≈øt have informed him as well of the bu≈øine≈øs generally, as that
receipts had always been taken for the intere≈øt paid or allowed on the redemption of the dollar-money, yet he neglected to do it, or if he did, to exhibit them as vouchers for the money ≈øo paid, this was the more nece≈ø≈øary as by an interpretation of law acted on, a great difference was made in the allowance between that emi≈ø≈øion coming in by taxes and by other means; it is true he hath at la≈øt adopted that mea≈øure but is was towards the clo≈øe of the time.

closer.signed: I have the honor to be with great re≈øpect, Sir, your mo≈øt obt. ≈øervant, JOHN NICHOLSON."

div.p: The following letters were written on this ≈øubject ≈øoon after‚Äî

body.p:
"I HAVE read with attention the letter of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury of the U. S. dated 21 December, 1791, and the two letters of the Comptroller-General dated 24th December, 1791, and 29th of February, 1792, relative to the con≈øtruction of the 18th ≈øection of the Act of Congre≈øs making provi≈øion for the debt of the U. S. It appears to me that the word "tho≈øe" in the enacting part of the clau≈øe can only apply to the certificates i≈ø≈øued by the State, but as that never could be the meaning of the Act of Congre≈øs, I agree that the con≈øtruction given by the Secretary is the only rational one. Be that as it may, it is very certain that neither the New-Loan certificates of Penn≈øylvania, remaining in circulation, nor the Continental certificates in exchange for which the≈øe New-Loans had been i≈ø≈øued, have been ≈øurrendered to the U. S.‚ÄîIt is not le≈øs certain that the payment of intere≈øt, whether to the ≈øtate or to individuals has not been ≈øu≈øpended, the pre≈øent
≈øu≈øpen≈øion to the ≈øtate is but temporary, and ari≈øes merely from the exten≈øion of the former law of Congre≈øs by their Act of la≈øt May, and will of cour≈øe cea≈øe on the fir≈øt of March next, (if the former objections are not revived) and of cour≈øe it mu≈øt have appeared to the ≈øatisfaction of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury that all the New-Loan certificates have been re-exchanged or redeemed. To have con≈øidered them as ≈øuch is I ≈øuppo≈øe, what the Comptroller means by the "equitable deci≈øion" of the Secretary. It is however of importance to us to know what were the real grounds of that deci≈øion, as it is po≈ø≈øible that the ≈øub≈øcription made lately in New-Loan certificates to the loan of the U. S. may affect it materially. For if the Secretary con≈øidered the whole of the New-Loan certificates as actually re-exchanged or redeemed, it mu≈øt have been, becau≈øe the ≈øtate law which entitled the holders to ≈øuch an exchange might been ≈øuppo≈øed to have been altogether carried into effect, ≈øince not a ≈øingle of tho≈øe certificates had been offered for ≈øub≈øcription to the loan of the U. S. But as ≈øome have been offered ≈øince the exten≈øion of the loan took place, that circum≈øtance may induce him to alter his opinion, and indeed I cannot well under≈øtand how he may ≈øuppo≈øe him≈øelf ju≈øtifiable in looking upon the whole amount as being actually re-exchanged, whil≈øt he has got it in proof, that ≈øome of them are not ≈øo. Upon the fir≈øt impre≈ø≈øion I ≈øhould be led to think that the Secretary having once declared (by his allowing the intere≈øt not to be ≈øu≈øpended) that the whole amount was re-exchanged (and that upon the information of the ≈øtate officer) will now look upon them in the ≈øame light and return them as not a≈ø≈øumable, an opinion which I think, may al≈øo be ≈øupported on different ground both from the nature of the certificates them≈øelves and from the ≈øtate law of 1789, which declared the ≈øtate not to be liable for the payment of the principal.

"However as the whole of this rea≈øoning is mo≈øtly conjectural, as the deci≈øion of the Secretary may, under the pre≈øent circum≈øtances, lead him to ≈øu≈øpend the payment
of intere≈øt to the ≈øub≈øcribers to the loan (≈øince it was extended at lea≈øt) unle≈øs ≈øome legi≈ølative mea≈øures can prevent that inconvenience, permit me to ≈øugge≈øt to you the propriety of procuring as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible the nece≈ø≈øary information on that ≈øubject, as I have no doubt the Hou≈øe or the committee of ways and means will ≈øoon apply to you in an official manner for the ≈øame. The que≈øtions which appear to me the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øolved are the following‚Äî

"1≈øt. What were the grounds of the deci≈øion of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury relative to the intended ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of intere≈øt in Feb. 1791, and what con≈øtruction did he give to the 18th ≈øection of the funding Act of Congre≈øs?

"2d. Does he look now on the New-Loan certificates offered for ≈øub≈øcription to the loan of the U. S. as a≈ø≈øumable, if ≈øo, upon what ground? if not, upon what grounds al≈øo? and will he return them ≈øoon to the ≈øub≈øcribers?

"3d. Will his deci≈øion relative to the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of intere≈øt be the ≈øame now as la≈øt winter, and if it is not, what mea≈øures on the ≈øide of the Legi≈ølature of Penn≈øylvania, will remove the difficulties that may in his opinion now prevent the payment of intere≈øt?

"I have cho≈øen to communicate to you my ideas on that ≈øubject as an individual, rather than to wait for the formalities of official application taking place, in order to prevent delays; which I hope will be a ≈øufficient apology for this letter.
body.trailer: A. J. Dallas, E≈øq

body.p:
"IT is regretted that the pre≈ø≈øing bu≈øine≈øs of this department has not till this time permitted a reply to the que≈øtions ≈øtated in Mr. Gallatin's letter of the 14th of
January, re≈øpecting the New-Loan certificates of the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania.

"It has been the uniform con≈øtruction of the Act making provi≈øion for the debt of the United States, that to render any certificates receivable on the loan it was not only nece≈ø≈øary that they ≈øhould have been i≈ø≈øued for ≈øervices or ≈øupplies towards the pro≈øecution of the late war, but al≈øo that they ≈øhould at the time of being ≈øub≈øcribed be recognized by the exi≈øting laws of the States as evidences of debts by them re≈øpectively owing.

"It was not, till lately under≈øtood, that any doubts were entertained whether the New-Loan certificates were in fact debts due by the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania in every ≈øen≈øe nece≈ø≈øary to bring them within the meaning of the Act of Congre≈øs; it is certain, that no ≈øuch doubts were ≈øugge≈øted to the Trea≈øury.

"The commi≈ø≈øioner of loans was accordingly advi≈øed in June 1791 that the certificates which had been received of the State in lieu of certificates of the U. S. were receivable on loan, though at the ≈øame time he was in≈øtructed with a view to future convenience to u≈øe his endeavours with the holders to exchange them with the State.

"In con≈øequence of an explanation which was rendered nece≈ø≈øary by the provi≈øions contained in the 18th ≈øection of the Act making provi≈øion for the debt of the U. S. it appeared that none of the New-Loan certificates of Penn≈øylvania had been ≈øub≈øcribed to the loan of the U. S. That only the ≈øum of about forty thou≈øand pounds of ≈øaid certificates remained to be exchanged, and that adequate and final arrangements had been made for exchanging the remainder by the State.

"This being the ≈øtate of the ca≈øe it became nece≈ø≈øary to determine whether the payment of intere≈øt on the a≈ø≈øumed debt of Penn≈øylvania was to remain ≈øu≈øpended until a ≈øum in certificates of the United States, equal to the amount of New-Loan Certificates remaining un-exchanged, was ≈øurrendered to the Trea≈øury.

"As the provi≈øion in the law was expre≈øsly de≈øigned
to prevent intere≈øt from being twice paid on what originally con≈øtituted one debt; an event which could not in this ca≈øe happen; as it appeared incon≈øi≈øtent with equity, that the ≈øtate ≈øhould be required to ≈øurrender the certificates which were the ≈øole con≈øideration for which they had become indebted to their citizens when no equivalent had been ≈øtipulated therefor by the United States; as ≈øuch a ≈øurrender would defeat the arrangements made by the ≈øtate for effecting a re-exchange of the out≈øtanding certificates, and a ju≈øt ≈øettlement with their creditors, as a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the payment of intere≈øt on the a≈ø≈øumed debt of Penn≈øylvania would prove highly injurious to the rights of individuals; and la≈øtly, as it appeared to me that the terms and intent of the law could be ≈øatisfied without a≈ø≈øuming a con≈øtruction liable to the ≈øtrong objections before ≈øtated, I could not he≈øitate to determine, that a ≈øurrender on the part of the ≈øtate was not nece≈ø≈øary.

"I have been the more explicit in my reply to the fir≈øt que≈øtion propo≈øed by Mr. Gallalin, as it appears to be the mo≈øt important, and for the purpo≈øe of evincing that as the ca≈øe was then pre≈øented, no doubt was or could be entertained, that the New-Loan certificates might have been ≈øub≈øcribed to the loan of the United States. If however the New-Loan certificates are not by the laws of Penn≈øylvania, con≈øidered as debts, but merely as receipts for certificates of the United States, which may be demanded at plea≈øure‚Äîthen according to the general rule of con≈øtruction, the New-Loan certificates of the ≈øtate will not be con≈øidered as receivable on loan to the United States, and will be re≈øtored to the ≈øub≈øcribers.

"As the engagements of the United States appear to be ≈øomewhat implicated in a right deci≈øion of this que≈øtion, I ≈øhall take mea≈øures to have the ca≈øe ≈øtated to the Attorney-General of the United States for his opinion. At the ≈øame time I ≈øugge≈øt the expediency of ≈øome mea≈øures being taken on the part of the government of the
≈øtate, for expre≈ø≈øing their ≈øen≈øe re≈øpecting the certificates in que≈øtion.

closer.signed: With great con≈øideration and e≈øteem, I am, &c. ALEXANDER HAMILTON."

body.p: "IN order to obtain the be≈øt information, in an≈øwer to your letter of the 14th ultimo, I con≈øulted the Secretary of the Trea≈øury; and I now inclo≈øe you a copy of this communication on the ≈øubject to which you refer.

"If you think I can be of any further ≈øervice to your enquiries, I beg you to ≈øugge≈øt the points, and to rely on a prompt and chearful attendance. body.p: "AGREEABLY to the de≈øire of the Committee of Ways and Means, I ≈øubmit the following ≈øtate of facts, relative to the redeeming certain ab≈øtracts of New-Loan Certificates, as ≈øtated in my report to the Honorable Legi≈ølature on the 14th January la≈øt, and contained in Book A, Article No. 3.

"It having been previou≈øly arranged with the Secretary of the Trea≈øury, that the ab≈øtracts with receipts a≈ø≈øigned to the Commonwealth, ≈øhould be ≈øufficient to authori≈øe the proper officers of the United States to i≈ø≈øue the certificates to be granted thereon, direct to the commonwealth.

An examination with re≈øpect to the ca≈øting and intere≈øt took place, and ≈øubmitted to the Comptroller for his examination and approbation, when, if approved by him, a certificate to the Governor from his office, was ≈øent to this office, of the amount of the redeemable debt and intere≈øt, which was counter≈øigned by the Regi≈øter, and ≈øent to the Secretary, on which a warrant i≈ø≈øued on the Trea≈øury.

"Of the ab≈øtracts in que≈øtion, No. 264-5-6-8, and one in favour of David Rittenhou≈øe, E≈øq were a≈ø≈øigned, and ≈øent from the Comptroller-General to this office, examined and entered as before ≈øtated, and returned to the Comptroller-General on the 7th July, and warrants i≈ø≈øued the 9th, and were entered in this office on the 10th.
Ab≈øtract, No. 262, was ≈øent in the ≈øame manner from the Comptroller's office, entered in this the 9th July, and a warrant i≈ø≈øued on the 12th, and was entered the 14th in this office.

"Ab≈øtract, No. 272, was pre≈øented by Mr. Addi≈øon on the 17th July, which was the fir≈øt time I knew of any New-Loans being ≈øub≈øcribed to the Loan of the United States, and not before. A conference took place between Comptroller and Regi≈øter, in which it was ≈øtated by the Comptroller, that they were within the Act of the United States, and were certainly redeemable. In this I concurred, provided the conditions ≈øtipulated by the Act of the United States, could be complied with: This he ob≈øerved was a matter of the United States, and that he had or would con≈øult the Secretary of the Trea≈øury on the bu≈øine≈øs.

"About this time, I had a conference with the Secretary, Mr. Dallas, who informed me that he had heard
much of this bu≈øine≈øs, and that it was wrong, in which the Attorney-General agreed with him‚ÄîThat he would put the que≈øtion in writing to him, and tran≈ømit official directions for my government.

"In con≈øequence of the communications with Mr. Dallas and the Trea≈øurer, there was a ≈øtop put to the bu≈øine≈øs until the Attorney-General's opinion ≈øhould be obtained in writing, which the Secretary applied for on the 23d July, and received an an≈øwer the 28th, and tran≈ømitted the ≈øame to this office on the 31≈øt July.

"No payments were made for any ab≈øtracts containing New-Loan Certificates, after the communications with the Secretary, Trea≈øurer and Comptroller, ≈øave the one in favor of Mr. Addi≈øon, No. 272, for 217 dollars and 69 cents.

div.p: The bu≈øine≈øs progre≈ø≈øed in this manner until the 3d of April, when the committee on ways and means made the following report, viz.

The committee on Ways and Means to whom were referred ≈øundry letters and documents relative to the ≈øub≈øcription to the Loan propo≈øed by the United States, and the ≈øub≈øequent redemption of ≈øundry certificates, formerly i≈ø≈øued under the authority of Penn≈øylvania, and commonly called New-Loan, report on that ≈øubject‚Äî

That by a law pa≈ø≈øed on the 10th day of April 1792, among≈øt other provi≈øion made for the redemption and final di≈øcharge of ≈øundry debts due by the commonwealth; in the ≈øixth ≈øection, it is enacted, That if Congre≈øs ≈øhall on or before the fir≈øt day of July next, renew and again open the ≈øub≈øcription to the loan heretofore propo≈øed to the ≈øtate creditors, or ≈øhall in any other manner or upon any other terms, provide for the a≈ø≈øumption of the non-≈øub≈øcribed debts owing to ≈øuch ≈øtate creditors, the holder or holders of any certificate or certificates, ≈øub≈øcribable to the ≈øub≈øcription ≈øo renewed, or entitled to the benefit of ≈øuch other provi≈øion, ≈øhall be entitled to have and receive the nominal value of the ≈øaid certificate or certificates from the State-Trea≈øurer, upon this condition and not otherwi≈øe: that they ≈øhall and do ≈øub≈øcribe to the loan ≈øo renewed, or acquie≈øce in the terms of ≈øuch other provi≈øion, and thereupon, on or before the fir≈øt day of July next, transfer to the State-Trea≈øurer, for the u≈øe of the commonwealth, each and every
the certificate and certificates which they ≈øhall receive from the United States, in con≈øequence of ≈øuch ≈øub≈øcription, or all and ≈øingular the intere≈øts and benefits to be derived from ≈øuch other provi≈øion, together with the proper evidences thereof.

That by the arrangements taken in con≈øequence of the law of Congre≈øs, extending the terms of their former loan, no certificates could i≈ø≈øue in favor of the ≈øub≈øcribers, prior to the 1≈øt day of May 1793; whereupon, it having been agreed that the receipts given by the commi≈ø≈øioner of loan, to the ≈øub≈øcribing ≈øtate creditors, ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øigned to the commonwealth, and that the certificates from the Loan-office, ≈øhould i≈ø≈øue directly to the commonwealth; the bu≈øine≈øs was conducted under the following regulations: When the holder of any ≈øtate-certificate or certificates, wi≈øhed to ≈øub≈øcribe the ≈øame to the loan propo≈øed by Congre≈øs, and to avail him≈øelf of the benefit of the above-mentioned law of the commonwealth, pa≈ø≈øed in April 1792, he pre≈øented ≈øuch certificate or certificates, with an ab≈øtract of the ≈øame, ≈øpecifying the number, date, by whom and to whom i≈ø≈øued, and the amount of the principal and intere≈øt, to the Comptroller- General, who after examination certified on the face of the ab≈øtract, that the certificates were genuine and a≈ø≈øumable. The ab≈øtract being then pre≈øented to the commi≈ø≈øioner of loan, and the certificates them≈øelves depo≈øited with him, the commi≈ø≈øioner gave to the party a receitps for the ≈øame on the ab≈øtract. The ab≈øtract and receipt were then a≈ø≈øigned to the commonwealth, and pre≈øented to the Regi≈øter-General and Comptroller-General for examination, and if approved, a certificate ≈øigned by the two officers, was ≈øent to the Governor, ≈øtating the amount due to the party, and a warrant for the ≈øame, thereupon i≈ø≈øued according to law.

That among≈øt other ab≈øtracts thus declared to be a≈ø≈øumable by the Comptroller, which pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øeveral offices, and the nominal amount of which (including both principal and intere≈øt,) was con≈øequently paid to the re≈øpective holders out of the State-Trea≈øury, there
were ≈øundry certificates of that de≈øcription commonly called New-Loan, and which were i≈ø≈øued by virtue of an Act, entitled An Act for the further relief of the public creditors, who are citizens of this ≈øtate, by receiving on loan certain debts of the United States of America, and for funding the ≈øame, and for paying the annual intere≈øt of ≈øuch loans, and the intere≈øt of certain debts of this ≈øtate, every ≈øix months, pa≈ø≈øed on the fir≈øt day of March 1786; part of which Act was repealed by the Act, entitled An Act to repeal ≈øo much of any Act or Acts of A≈ø≈øembly of this commonwealth, as directs the payment of the New-Loan debt, or the intere≈øt thereof, beyond the 1≈øt day of April next, and for other purpo≈øes therein mentioned, pa≈ø≈øed on the 27th day of March 1789, wherein it is enacted that the continental certificates received by the ≈øtate by virtue of the former Act, ≈øhall be returned to the holders of New-Loan certificates, upon their delivering the ≈øame, and that "≈øo much of every Act or Acts of General A≈ø≈øembly as directs or ≈øecures the payment of the principal ≈øum or ≈øums, in the ≈øaid certificates or any of them mentioned, or of the intere≈øt thereof, beyond the term of four years, ≈øhall be, and the ≈øame is hereby repealed and made null and void."

That the total amount of the New-Loan certificates thus redeemed by the ≈øtate, at their nominal value, including the intere≈øt, amounts to 63,075 dollars and 37 cents; 60,220 dollars and 41 cents of which, were ≈øub≈øcribed in the name, and of cour≈øe appear to be the property of John Nichol≈øon.
The committee are of opinion that the Comptroller-General, in the above-mentioned tran≈øactions, has been guilty of a high mi≈ødemeanor:‚Äî
Fir≈øt. By certifying the a≈ø≈øumable quantity of the New-Loan certificates; the greater part of the ≈øame being his own property.
Second, By pa≈ø≈øing and certifying the ≈øame to the Executive in the u≈øual forms of office; thereby cau≈øing them to be redeemed.
The opinion of the committee on the fir≈øt point, is founded upon the following con≈øiderations‚Äî

1≈øt. They conceive, that ≈øince the Act of March 1789, above mentioned, the New-Loan certificates cea≈øed to be a ≈øtate debt; were not, therefore, within the a≈ø≈øumption of, and could not be ≈øub≈øcribed to the loan propo≈øed by Congre≈øs.

2. Whatever the deci≈øion of the officers of the Trea≈øury of the United States might be on the preceding po≈øition, as it was not, by law, the official duty of the Comptroller-General to decide on it, he ought not to have done ≈øo, when a deci≈øion given under the colour of office operated in his own favor, at the expence of the ≈øtate.

3d. In certifying the New-Loan certificates to be a≈ø≈øumable, he neither con≈øulted the Regi≈øter-General, nor communicated the tran≈øaction to the Governor; and as neither the ab≈øtracts on the face of which the a≈ø≈øumable quantity was certified, nor the official certificates on which warrants were i≈ø≈øued, did di≈øcriminate the kind of debt that was redeemed; the checks provided by law were thereby de≈øtroyed, and the other officers of the ≈øtate deluded into error.

4th. The Comptroller-General knew, by a former deci≈øion of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury of the United States, that at all events the New-Loan certificates could not be recognized as a≈ø≈øumable, unle≈øs an equal amount of continental certificates was delivered to the Secretary afore≈øaid; which no law authori≈øed the Comptroller to do: and he was appri≈øed that the payment of the intere≈øt to the ≈øub≈øcribing ≈øtate creditors and to the ≈øtate, on account of the a≈ø≈øumption, would have been ≈øu≈øpended, when the time limited for receiving ≈øub≈øcriptions to the former loan of Congre≈øs expired, had it not, upon inve≈øtigation, appeared that no New-Loan certificates had been ≈øub≈øcribed.

The opinion of the committee on the ≈øecond point, ari≈øes from con≈øidering that, independent of the qu ‚Ä¢ ≈øtion, Whether the New-Loan certificates were within
the a≈ø≈øumption of the United States, they were not redeemable by the Act of April 1792? and this appears from the following con≈øiderations‚Äî
1≈øt. No funds were provided by the Act for the redemption of tho≈øe certificates.

2d. The ≈øixth ≈øection of the Act can only be regarded as a provi≈øo and exception to the preceding ≈øections by which the redemption of certain de≈øcriptions of debts, which do not include the New-Loan certificates, were exclu≈øively and ≈øolely contemplated.

3d. Even the ≈øixth ≈øection, ≈øuppo≈øing it to ≈øtand alone, cannot admit of the con≈øtruction given by the Comptroller-General, as it de≈øignates only ≈øtate-creditors, and by the exi≈øting laws of the commonwealth, the holders of New-Loan certificates are declared not to be ≈øuch.
Having ≈øtated this ge ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ral view of the ≈øubject, the committee deem it their duty to pre≈øent the following re≈øolutions to the con≈øideration of the Hou≈øe.
Re≈øolved, That John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of this commonwealth, be impeached for a high mi≈ødemeanor in his office.

Re≈øolved, That the Attorney-General be directed to in≈øtitute a ≈øuit again≈øt the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon, to recover, for the u≈øe of the commonwealth, the amount of the New-Loan certificates, which have been redeemed and paid at the Trea≈øury of this ≈øtate.

The committee in the cour≈øe of their enquiries upon this occa≈øion, have found rea≈øon to lament, that in the execution of the various, important and confidential duties, (embracing the emi≈ø≈øion of certificates and the care and management of other public property to an immen≈øe amount) which have from time to time been a≈ø≈øigned to the Comptroller-General, an adequate check has in few ca≈øes been provided, and, in fewer ≈øtill, enforced. They conceive, therefore, that the honor and intere≈øt of the ≈øtate, require an early and effectual inve≈øtigation of the Comptroller's official tran≈øactions; and they would be wanting in their duty to the public and to them≈øelves, were they not to offer an earne≈øt recommendation
that the following re≈øolution ≈øhould be adopted.

Re≈øolved, That a committee be appointed to examine, during the rece≈øs of the Hou≈øe, all the accounts and official tran≈øactions of the Comptroller-General of this commonwealth, and to report thereon at the next ≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Legi≈ølature.

Acts, pa≈ø≈øed on the thirtieth of March and fir≈øt of April 1790: and by an Act of the 10th of April 1792, provi≈øion is made for the redemption of certain ≈øtate debts, and particularly, in the ≈øixth ≈øection, for paying the nominal amount of tho≈øe certificates, which are ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan propo≈øed to the ≈øtate creditors, by the Act of Congre≈øs, which was pa≈ø≈øed on the 4th of April 1790, and extended in it's operation by an Act of Congre≈øs pa≈ø≈øed on the eighth day of May 1792.
"Having con≈øidered the≈øe laws, the following are ≈øubmitted to your deci≈øion.

"1≈øt. Whether, after the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of A≈ø≈øembly of the twenty-≈øeventh of March 1789, and the other Acts on the ≈øubject, the New-Loan certificates could be recognized, by the officers of the federal or ≈øtate government, for any other purpo≈øe than re-exchanging them for continental certificates?

Whether the New-Loan certificates, after the pa≈ø≈øing of the above Act, by which all Acts ≈øecuring the payment of either principal or intere≈øt thereof, are declared void, can be included within the de≈øcription of the ≈øtate debts, directed to be redeemed and paid by the Act of the 10th of April 1792?

Whether the New-Loan certificates, being i≈ø≈øued after the war, and, as the preamble of the Act of the fir≈øt of March 1786, ≈øtates, for the relief of the patriotic citizens of Penn≈øylvania are excluded from the loan propo≈øed by Congre≈øs, by the words or ≈øpirit of the provi≈øo annexed to the 13th ≈øection of the Act of Congre≈øs of the fourth of Augu≈øt 1790?

body.p: "ENGAGEMENTS at court have prevented me from returning an earlier an≈øwer to your favour of the 23d in≈øtant.

"I am of opinion that after the pa≈ø≈øing the Act of A≈ø≈øembly of the 27th March, 1789, and the other Acts on the ≈øubject, the New-Loan certificates cea≈øed to be a ≈øtate debt within the view of the Legi≈ølature, and could not con≈øi≈øtently with tho≈øe laws, be recognized by the officers of the Federal or State government, for any other purpo≈øe than re-exchanging them for continental certificates.

"The State debt what was originally and properly ≈øo called, and which the Legi≈ølature could only have had in contemplation when they made provi≈øion for ≈øuch deficiency, as they con≈øidered to be left unprovided for by the continental rule of a≈ø≈øumption was about one million, or ≈øay 1,200,000 dollars.

"By the Act of April la≈øt, the ≈øtate agrees to redeem the≈øe a≈ø≈øumptions from the holders of the debt, by paying 10 É in the pound for the 3 per cents, and ¬£. 39 per cent. for the deferred part, being the e≈øtimated value of the annuity of 6 per cent. per annum for the time limited.
"This recapitulation of facts appears to me to ≈øugge≈øt the ≈øolution of your ≈øecond que≈øtion.

"If the New-Loan certificates are brought in a≈ø≈øumable by the United States, the ≈øum may exceed the whole that Congre≈øs have agreed to a≈ø≈øume, and our A≈ø≈øembly will have encouraged mea≈øures for the exclu≈øion of the whole of our State debt from being a≈ø≈øumed.
"Two motives may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have actuated our Legi≈ølature.
"Fir≈øt‚ÄîTo free the ≈øtate from debt that in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity they might anticipate their re≈øources by credit.

"On the New-Loan certificates they were paying no intere≈øt, the continental certificates furni≈øhed the means of redemption at any moment, without expen≈øe, the rea≈øon of the law determines it's extent, neither of tho≈øe motives apply to the New-Loan certificates, it is impo≈ø≈øible that the ≈øtate could have intended, that they ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øumed by the United States, or that they were in contemplation in the provi≈øion made by the Act of April la≈øt.

In either ca≈øe the balance mu≈øt be repaid to the ≈øtate by the officers who have been guilty of the neglect; but it will require a very long examination, and a compari≈øon of the endor≈øements on each certificate, with the corre≈øponding payments at the Trea≈øury, before it will be po≈ø≈øible to di≈øcover exactly where the mi≈øtake or the fault lies. 5.

5. "As the la≈øt paragraph refers to the State-Trea≈øurers and not to me, I pa≈øs over without ob≈øervation, ≈øave that the method they mention, hath long before their appointment been adopted and proceeded in by me, and that it requires, as they ≈øay, a very long examination, &c. to in≈øert in the books oppo≈øite the certificates re≈øpectively, every ≈øucce≈ø≈øive payment of intere≈øt made

div.head: Report continued.
div.p: "In the mean while, in order to a≈øcertain the balance which, exclu≈øively of that deficiency, might be due to the ≈øtate, the committee charged the Comptroller, as will appear by the account E, with the amount of intere≈øt which appeared to have been paid upon the face of the certificate re-exchanged or redeemed by the Land-Office. But as the Regi≈øter has not yet furni≈øhed the committee with the total amount which, from the examination of the certificates them≈øelves, will appear to have been paid upon the certificate re-exchanged; the committee have been obliged to re≈øt, for the pre≈øent, ≈øatisfied with a rough calculation made by them≈øelves from the books of New-Loan certificates received on exchange. They have al≈øo charged the Comptroller with the indents he had drawn upon the continental certificates yet in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and with four years intere≈øt upon the two balances, amounting together to 12,456 2/90 dollars, which appear to be due by him in continental certificates, from the accounts, C, and D.

"It will appear by the credit ≈øide of the ≈øame account E, that 27,473 28/100 dollars, in indents and 3 per cent. ≈øtock, which ≈øhould have been paid long before, were delivered or transferred to the Trea≈øurer only in June la≈øt. The committee thought them≈øelves obliged to write to the Governor on that ≈øubject, in order to ha≈øten the delivery. By the ≈øame account it appears that the the Comptroller is accountable for a balance of 47,544 33/90 dollars, a great part of which, ≈øhould, in the opinion of your committee have been paid before this time. It is however, proper to ob≈øerve, 1≈øtly, That about 20,000 dollars, part of the ≈øaid balance, ari≈øe from indents due by parties (upon equalizing the intere≈øt on the exchanges of New-Loan and continental certificates) which they had not paid, by the information of the Comptroller, in June la≈øt, but for which he is accountable as by the re≈øolutions of Council above-mentioned, he was not to
deliver any continental certificates until he had received the full amount of intere≈øt due.‚Äî2ndly, That the Comptroller has mentioned that he would transfer to the ≈øtate whatever balance might appear to be due by him, as ≈øoon as the ≈øame was a≈øcertained. 6

div.p: 6. "It is not nece≈ø≈øary for me to make any remark on the balance of indents, repre≈øented by them in the 10th line from the bottom of the 126th page, to be al≈øo due from me, as they have ≈øtated them≈øelves in the 15th line preceding, that it grew out of a "rough calculation" they had made, and as they have al≈øo herein done me the ju≈øtice, in the 3d, 4th, and 5th lines of this page, to mention what I had ≈øaid that if any balance might appear due from me, I would transfer it to the ≈øtate as ≈øoon as the ≈øame was a≈øcertained.

"As the committee there al≈øo ob≈øerve in the ≈øix la≈øt lines of the 126th page, and two fir≈øt lines of the pre≈øent one, I know that I am not to expect from the ≈øtate, a credit for indents due by individuals. "In the beginning of the ≈øentence, and at the 17th to the 14th line from the bottom of the la≈øt page, the committee again mention the late delivery of about 27,000 dollars in indents, to the Trea≈øurer; the fact is, the quantity not funded, was ≈ømall in it≈øelf, and con≈øi≈øted of a great number of ≈ømall and broken indents which it required time to count, and which time was then, I thought better employed at our accounts with the United States. It was therefore delayed as well as much other bu≈øine≈øs until that throng was over, after which they were attended to; they would have been delivered then, had no ≈øteps been taken by that committee, who I conceived had nothing to do with it. It is further ob≈øervable, that a con≈øiderable part of the ≈øaid 27,473 dollars
28 cents, was already funded and ≈øtood to the credit of the ≈øtate, ≈øo that the intere≈øt came as regularly into the Trea≈øury, as if the ≈øtock had been in the Trea≈øurer's hands."

div.head: Report continued. "SECOND HEAD. "Depreciation Debt.
div.p:
"BY an Act pa≈ø≈øed on 18th day of December, 1780, Council were directed to appoint three Auditors, with powers to ≈øettle the accounts of the officers and ≈øoldiers of the Penn≈øylvania line, in the Act de≈øcribed for the depreciation of their pay, and to i≈ø≈øue certificates for the ≈øame. By an Act pa≈ø≈øed on the 10th of April, 1781, Council were empowered to appoint additional Auditors for the purpo≈øe of carrying into operation the la≈øt mentioned Act; they were al≈øo directed to draw upon the State-Trea≈øurer for ≈øuch ≈øums of ≈øtate-money as they thought convenient, and to place the ≈øame in the hands of commi≈ø≈øioners to be appointed for that purpo≈øe, who ≈øhould, before the fir≈øt day of May following, repair to the ≈øeveral rendezvous of the regiments, and pay to ≈øuch of the officers and ≈øoldiers who ≈øhould apply for the ≈øame, one third part of the ≈øums ≈øpecified in the Depreciation certificates, i≈ø≈øued to them by the Auditors; and after receiving the old certificates, ≈øhould tran≈ømit them to the Trea≈øurer, and i≈ø≈øue new ones for the balance. By the ≈øame Act it was provided that ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhould not apply to the commi≈ø≈øioners, might at any time afterwards apply to the Trea≈øurer, who was directed likewi≈øe to pay one third of the original certificates in ≈øtate-money, and to i≈ø≈øue new ones for the balance. In conformity to tho≈øe two laws, James Steven≈øon and John Nichol≈øon were appointed auditors and commi≈ø≈øioners, together with ≈øeveral other per≈øons, but the pre≈øence of one of them was declared to be nece≈ø≈øary in tran≈øacting the bu≈øine≈øs of commi≈ø≈øioners, and they were directed to collect all the papers and vouchers relative to tho≈øe tran≈øactions. Receipts were al≈øo directed by Council,
to be taken for the payments in ≈øhilling-money, and all the commi≈ø≈øioners have accordingly ≈øettled their accounts with the former Auditors of accounts.

"By an Act of the 13th of April, 1782, the Comptroller-General (who≈øe office had been in≈øtituted by another Act of the ≈øame date) was directed to ≈øettle the accounts of the depreciation of the pay of ≈øeveral officers and others in the Act de≈øcribed, and Council were authori≈øed to draw on the Trea≈øurer, for ≈øuch ≈øums of ≈øtate-money as might, from time to time appear, by the report of the Comptroller-General to be nece≈ø≈øary, and to place the ≈øame in the hands of the ≈øaid Comptroller, who ≈øhould pay to ≈øuch per≈øons as might apply for the ≈øame, one third part of the ≈øums found due on ≈øettlement in bills afore≈øaid, and for the remaining two thirds, they ≈øhould receive certificates in like manner as the other troops of the ≈øtate. Although, by the Act in≈øtituting the office of Comptroller-General, the office of Auditors to ≈øettle the accounts of depreciation, had been virtually aboli≈øhed, yet neither by the ≈øame nor by the la≈øt mentioned Act, was any provi≈øion made for ≈øettling any original depreciation accounts, except of tho≈øe in the Act ≈øpecially defined, nor for i≈ø≈øuing of cour≈øe any original certificates except for them, and, indeed, from the general tenor and expre≈ø≈øions of the la≈øt Act, the power to pay one third in money, and to i≈ø≈øue certificates for the two thirds remaining, ≈øeems confined to the ≈øame de≈øcription of per≈øons The expre≈ø≈øion ≈øuch per≈øons, in the 9th ≈øection of the law, general as it may, on fir≈øt view, appear, can only apply to the per≈øons in the Act mentioned, as there is not in the ≈øection a ≈øingle word about depreciation accounts, nor any other expre≈ø≈øion to define who the per≈øons are. 7..

div.head: Mr. Nichol≈øon's An≈øwer.
div.p:
‚Äî "Here the committee are at ≈øome pains to define the import of a ≈øection of the law of 13th April, 1782, which I was thereby required to execute; the words directed me to pay in ≈øtate-money of 1781, to "≈øuch per≈øons" as ≈øhould apply therefor, one third of the depreciation allowed at ≈øettlement‚Äîthis I did; but
had the words been "to ≈øuch of the per≈øons afore≈øaid" as ≈øhould apply, I ≈øhould then have conformed my conduct to what they thought it ought to have been under the law as it ≈øtands. To me it appears plain; I never had a doubt of its meaning, nor ≈øhould I have ≈øuppo≈øed a doubt would have exi≈øted with any, had it not been for this of the committee.

"I do not indeed find that they ≈øugge≈øt any articles of impeachment again≈øt me for this violation of their con≈øtruction of the law; had the advantages which were gained by the ≈øtate, in the ≈øaving of intere≈øt, on the third part thus paid by me, lay on the other ≈øide, ≈øo as to have formed a debit of account, and charge again≈øt me, no doubt it would have had a different turn with them."

div.head: Report continued.
div.p: ‚ÄîBy the Act of the 20th of September, 1782, all the powers formerly exerci≈øed by the above-mentioned Auditors, were ve≈øted in the Comptroller, whereby he became authori≈øed to ≈øettle all depreciation accounts, and to i≈ø≈øue original certificates for the ≈øame‚Äîa power which he ≈øeems however to have exerci≈øed from the time of his appointment. 8.

"Had this committee been de≈øirous of a candid inve≈øtigation, and enquired, I could have ≈øhown them that the very rever≈øe of this was true; that in no one in≈øtance was this power exerci≈øed until it was legally given, and that in fact it appears from the minutes and files of the A≈ø≈øembly, the next law alluded to was founded on my repre≈øentation, that I had not power to adju≈øt and certify tho≈øe claims, the ≈øettlement of which it provided for."

div.head: Report continued.
div.p:
‚ÄîHe al≈øo exerci≈øed all the powers ve≈øted formerly in the above-mentioned commi≈ø≈øioners, who were authori≈øed to pay a third in money, and to i≈ø≈øue certificates for the two thirds remaining, although they were not farther

div.p: 9 "Here al≈øo they mi≈ørepre≈øent the matter, no ≈øuch thing happened. I exerci≈øed none of the powers of tho≈øe commi≈ø≈øioners after I cea≈øed to be one of them my≈øelf. div.head: Report continued.
div.p: "By an Act of the 25th of March 1786, it was enacted that, in order to prevent frauds, no depreciation certificates ≈øhould be delivered except to the parties them≈øelves, their attorneys in fact or executors, or to their admini≈øtrators legally entitled to the ≈øame, or a ≈øhare thereof, by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion ab inte≈øtato; and that all depreciation certificates unclaimed on the 1≈øt of April 1787, ≈øhould e≈øcheat to the commonwealth; the Comptroller-General was further directed, within two months after the ≈øaid day, to tran≈ømit a li≈øt of all ≈øuch unclaimed certificates remaining in his hands, and of all that might have been claimed, if any, together with the certificates, to Council, that the ≈øame might be endor≈øed and rendered u≈øele≈øs.

"By the Act of the 18th of December 1780, confi≈øcated e≈øtates were directed to be ≈øold at public vendue for depreciation certificates, which were to be delivered to the State-Trea≈øurer, and by him cancelled, in ≈øuch manner as the A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhould direct. All the certificates thus received by the late Trea≈øurer, Mr. Rittenhou≈øe, were delivered to the Compttoller-General.

"By an Act of the 12th of March, 1783, a certain
tract of land, lying north-we≈øt of the Ohio and Allegheny rivers, and in the Act de≈øcribed, was directed to be ≈øold at public vendue, for depreciation certificates, to be paid to the Receiver-General of the Land-Office.

"By the Acts of the 1≈øt of April, 1784, and 8th of April, 1786, depreciation certificates were made receivable in payment for lands, and city lots, and payable for both to the Receiver-General, who was directed to deliver the ≈øame to the Comptroller-General.
"Provi≈øion was made for the final redemption of tho≈øe certificates, and tho≈øe commonly called Funded Debt, by the Acts of the 9th of April, 1791, 10th of April, 1792, and 9th of February, 1793.

"Previous to the appointment of the Comptroller-General, the Auditors and Commi≈ø≈øioners ve≈øted with the power of i≈ø≈øuing depreciation certificates, went, according to the orders of Council, to ≈øeveral po≈øts, and there ≈øettled the accounts; i≈ø≈øued the certificates, and made the payments in ≈øhilling money. The Comptroller is in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the books they kept of their tran≈øactions; of the counter parts of the certificates i≈ø≈øued by them, and other vouchers. The certificates received by them upon renewals, were al≈øo delivered to him. The books of tho≈øe tran≈øactions are not all of them equally correct and perfect. From them, however, and the counter parts, the Comptroller has formed books of depreciation certificates, i≈ø≈øued before his appointment; and has continued them in the ≈øame form for tho≈øe i≈ø≈øued by him. Tho≈øe books contain the numbers of the certificates; the names and rank of the grantees, and the amount of each certificate, di≈øtingui≈øhing the original from the renewed, but do not di≈øtingui≈øh in the column of original, tho≈øe which were granted in full, from tho≈øe which were i≈ø≈øued only for two-thirds (the other third being paid on ≈øettlement) nor in the column of renewed, tho≈øe which were granted for the accommodation of the parties in exchange for, and to an equal amount of other certificates, from tho≈øe which were i≈ø≈øued for two-thirds only of the original certificate;
the other third having been paid in ≈øhilling-money. Tho≈øe books, therefore, are not, alone, ≈øufficient to ≈øettle either the general account of depreciation debt, or the account of the Comptroller with the depreciation certificates by him received. For in order to know the total amount of the depreciation debt paid by the ≈øtate, it is nece≈ø≈øary to add to the amount of the original certificates i≈ø≈øued, the amount of ≈øhilling-money paid upon ≈øettlement, exclu≈øively of tho≈øe certificates; and the Comptroller, exclu≈øively of all the certificates he may ≈øtand charged with for renewals, mu≈øt al≈øo he charged with the whole amount of the ≈øhilling-money paid in part of original certificates, as the amount of tho≈øe original certificates delivered by the parties, upon receiving one-third thereof in ≈øaid money, and the remainder in new certificates, exceeds the amount of tho≈øe renewed certificates exactly by the amount of ≈øhilling-money, thus paid the parties in part.

"The Comptroller, at the reque≈øt of the committee, furni≈øhed them with copies of the accounts of the ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øioners appointed to pay that ≈øhilling-money, as ≈øettled by the former Auditors of accounts, and as tho≈øe accounts did not in all ca≈øes di≈øtingui≈øh between the money paid upon ≈øettlement, and the money paid in part of certificates, he, by ≈øundry letters and memorandums, informed the committee of the ≈øums re≈øpectively paid. The accounts of the Comptroller him≈øelf in ≈øhilling money, have been ≈øettled by the A≈ø≈øembly as far as the 11th day of November, 1782; his accounts from that day to the 19th of November, 1783, were exhibited to the committee, and he furni≈øhed to them an ab≈øtract of his accounts from the 19th of November, 1783, to the year 1787. Tho≈øe la≈øt accounts were ≈øent, ≈øince the appointment of the committee, to the Regi≈øter-General, to be examined and ≈øettled by him according to law. Some of tho≈øe accounts may have been entered in the general books, of which mention will be made hereafter, under the fourth head, but all of them were not, and ≈øuch as were, were not ≈øo dige≈øted as to
di≈øtingui≈øh between the money paid on ≈øettlement, from the money paid in part; and of cour≈øe would (had it not been for the explanations of the Comptroller) have been in≈øufficient for ≈øettling either the accounts of depreciation debt, or of the Comptroller.

"The account G is the general account of the ≈øtate with the depreciation debt. The debit ≈øide is left blank, as no accurate calculation has been procured of the ≈øame, and it is now u≈øele≈øs. The credit ≈øide con≈øi≈øts of the ≈øhilling money paid upon ≈øettlement of the total amount of original certificates i≈ø≈øued, (di≈øtingui≈øhing in each ca≈øe the amount paid, or i≈ø≈øued by the Comptroller, or by the re≈øpective Commi≈ø≈øioners or Auditors) and of the e≈øcheats as returned to the Secretary of the Commonwealth, per li≈øt annexed. The Comptroller had always returned tho≈øe e≈øcheats as amounting to ¬£. 57,540‚Äîan amount e≈øtimated, but not grounded upon any exact calculations. The Act of the 25th March 1786, is grounded upon an idea that all the certificates were made out, as it orders the Comptroller to return to Council, all the unclaimed ones by the 1≈øt of June 1787. It appears, however, by the letter of the Comptroller to the Governor, dated the 22d day of June 1792, that he made out the certificates only upon the application of the parties, and of cour≈øe that the claims, and not the certificates unapplied for, e≈øcheated to the commonwealth by virtue of the Act above-mentioned. The amount of e≈øcheats as returned at the ≈øame time by the Comptroller, is only ¬£. 42,293:4:4 ¬Ω. 10.

11. "It will not appear ≈øtrange, that in an e≈øtimation, where, as the committee ob≈øerved, no exact calculations thereof were made, there ≈øhould be a difference as great as the above, from the true amount: but it is to be al≈øo con≈øidered, that the fir≈øt amount was le≈ø≈øened by certificates granted after April, 1787, as appears by the books and receipts for accounts ≈øettled after the ≈øame date;
but which had been rendered before it; and owing to the want of te≈øtimony, and additional proof, were po≈øtponed till afterwards; ≈øo that here, al≈øo, if the committees intention of the law was right, "that it clearly prevented any certificates i≈ø≈øuing after the 1≈øt April, 1787" ‚Äîthat law was violated by the Regi≈øter-General and my≈øelf, for ≈øeveral of tho≈øe accounts were not ≈øettled till after he came into office in 1789; but the law admits no ≈øuch con≈øtruction as may appear therefrom.

"Having made out the depreciation certificates only as they were applied for, I had no return of any to make as I informed the Council at the time, except ≈øome I had ≈øtopped, on the pre≈øumption that though they were delivered by the Auditors, they had never come to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the parties in who≈øe favour they were granted. The≈øe certificates with a li≈øt thereof I took up to the Council chamber, but there was a controver≈øy and ≈øuit then depending re≈øpecting them, and therefore they could not be cancelled. div.head: Report continued.
div.p:
"Three enquiries ari≈øe on the ≈øubject of the i≈ø≈øuing depreciation certificates‚Äî1≈øt. Have no other certificates been i≈ø≈øued than tho≈øe entered upon the books of i≈ø≈øue? 2d. Have no certificates been i≈ø≈øued in the name of per≈øons who, by the terms of the laws, were not entitled to the ≈øame, 3d. Have the certificates always been delivered to the per≈øons in who≈øe name they had i≈ø≈øued, or to their legal repre≈øentatives? The an≈øwer to the fir≈øt query may be obtained, from a compari≈øon of the books, with the certificates delivered to the Regi≈øter, after the ≈øame ≈øhall have been numerically arranged, and with the li≈øt of tho≈øe ≈øub≈øcribed to the loan of the United States. Should any certificates appear, upon ≈øuch examination,
to have been i≈ø≈øued by the Comptroller, and not have been entered, he mu≈øt account for the ≈øame. The ≈øecond enquiry will require a minute compari≈øon of every certificate, with the number, rolls and other vouchers upon which the certificates i≈ø≈øued. As to the third, it will be very difficult fully to a≈øcertain it, becau≈øe prior to the law of the 25th March, 1786, no receipts were taken for certificates either i≈ø≈øued by the Auditors or the Comptroller. There is however a kind of indirect proof, by which a great part of tho≈øe certificates are di≈øcovered to have been i≈ø≈øued to the parties them≈øelves. Many of the certificates were a≈ø≈øigned, and receipts were taken on the back of tho≈øe which were di≈øcharged in part, in ≈øhilling money for the ≈øame. The committee were furni≈øhed by the Regi≈øter-General with the depreciation certificates delivered to him by the Comptroller; they examined them, ≈øet a≈øide all tho≈øe which appeared to them, upon the face of the ≈øame, to bear evidence of their having been delivered to the parties; and formed a li≈øt of the others, a copy of which they are to tran≈ømit to the Comptroller, as he thinks he may collect ≈øome other indirect proofs re≈øpecting many certificates upon which no receipt nor a≈ø≈øignment appear Mo≈øt of the receipts and a≈ø≈øignments are irregular for want of witne≈ø≈øes..

I al≈øo find, that the Act of Congre≈øs of the third of October, 1780, provides, that the regiments of artillery, as they now ≈øtand, be con≈øidered as belonging to the ≈øtates re≈øpectively, to which they are, or may be a≈ø≈øigned; which ≈øtates ≈øhall complete them to the full complement, ≈øupply them with nece≈ø≈øaries, and in every re≈øpect treat them as if rai≈øed therein.

"I am, therefore, of opinion, that Capt. Simonds is entitled to the benefit of the Act of the fir≈øt of March, 1780; and that his account for arrearages of clothing ≈øhould be allowed, as ≈øtated, amounting to one hundred and forty-five pounds and five pence.

div.head: "FOURTH HEAD.
"Settlement of accounts generally.

"The ≈øuppo≈øition of the Comptroller-General being at the ≈øame time an officer of the United States and of the State, was too ab≈øurd and uncon≈øtitutional to be admitted, and the committee re≈øted ≈øatisfied with laying the fact before the Governor, mentioning at the ≈øame time that as the papers had been delivered according to re≈øolutions of Congre≈øs, to ≈øuch officer as the Executive of the State might direct, and without any intervention of the Legi≈ølature, it might be perhaps ≈øugge≈øted that the officer then cho≈øen was accountable only to the Executive and not to the Legi≈ølature; they concluded by ≈øaying that they had no doubt of the Governor taking effectual mea≈øures to compel the officer to render a full account of that tran≈øaction‚ÄîBut although the Governor gave him peremptory orders to ≈øubmit tho≈øe books, vouchers and certificates to the committee, and tran≈ømitted to him a copy of the opinion of the Attorney-General dated June 20th, 1793, (in which he gives his official opinion, that tho≈øe books, certificates and vouchers were ≈øubject to the direction and controul of the Governor, and that he had a competent power to order the Comptroller to deliver them to whoever he plea≈øed, and of cour≈øe to direct that they ≈øhould be ≈øubmitted to the in≈øpection of the committee) the Comptroller has per≈øi≈øted in his refu≈øal‚ÄîAs it mu≈øt be evident that the officers of the United States have no controul or power whatever over our own officers, and that the≈øe of cour≈øe mu≈øt account only to our own Executive who then will render an account of the ≈øame to the proper officers of the United States whenever required; no proper motive can be ≈øugge≈øted that can ju≈øtify the refu≈øal of the Comptroller; and if every thing has been fairly tran≈øacted by him in that bu≈øine≈øs, ob≈øtinacy mu≈øt with him, on that occa≈øion, have prevailed over a ≈øen≈øe of his own intere≈øt and reputation. 25.

That I am not de≈øirous on my own account of attending a ≈øuit, and ≈øupporting the expences of it. 2d. I do not wi≈øh that the ≈øtate ≈øhould be at unnece≈ø≈øary expence in maintaining one, e≈øpecially as the cau≈øe hath been decided already, in the ≈øame court where this cau≈øe was propo≈øed by the committee of the late Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives to be brought‚ÄîFor as to juri≈ødiction, the Supreme Court have, as already mentioned, allowed it to have been in me, by a≈ø≈øuming it them≈øelves, in the ca≈øes of appeal which have been cited; and as to principles adopted at ≈øettlement, they have, at lea≈øt, ≈øanctioned mine, in favour of the ≈øtate, by them≈øelves, allowing more. One ob≈øervation it is natural to make here: The≈øe accounts were acted on, and approved both by the Governor and Regi≈øter-General. If the thing was wrong, the blame ≈øhould be participated to them, re≈øpectively: yet we hear of no re≈øolutions, for a ≈øuit again≈øt either the Governor or the Regi≈øter-General. On this I leave candor it≈øelf to make reflection.

div.head: Report continued.
div.p: "Re≈øolved, That a committee be appointed to prepare and bring in a bill to provide for the effectual and final ≈øettlement of the accounts of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller and E≈øcheator General. 27.

div.head: Mr. Nichol≈øon's An≈øwer.
div.p:
27. "The re≈øolution to provide by a law for the ≈øettlement of my accounts, ≈øo far as re≈øpects E≈øcheator-General, is nugatory; as ≈øuch I am not an officer of account; no public money can pa≈øs thro' my hands, either for real or per≈øonal e≈øtates, e≈øcheated or otherwi≈øe. I have, therefore, no account as E≈øcheator-General, to ≈øettle: As it intends my accounts as Comptroller-General, its de≈øign is either to create another office, or it is there al≈øo nugatory. By law, the Regi≈øter-General, as directed by the Executive, hath the power to ≈øettle
all the accounts of the Comptroller-General; and progre≈øs hath been, by him, made therein‚ÄîHowever if it is de≈øigned to create an additional office, I have no objections to whoever may examine and ≈øettle my accounts; and no other to that plan, than, as it may encrea≈øe the public expence, which, as a citizen, I mu≈øt contribute to pay.

div.head: Report continued.
div.p: "Re≈øolved, That a committee be appointed to prepare and bring in a bill to provide for the ≈øettlement of the arrearages of taxes due by the ≈øeveral counties and to enforce the collection of the ≈øame. 28.

div.head: Mr. Nichol≈øon's An≈øwer.
div.p: 28. "This third re≈øolution, not applying, in any wi≈øe, to my ca≈øe, I make no ob≈øervation upon it.
"It only remains, therefore, for me to a≈ø≈øure your≈øelf, and the members of your honorable Hou≈øe, that I am, &c.

div.head: SEPTEMBER 3.
div.p: THE additional articles of impeachment were read the ≈øecond time‚ÄîMajor M'Connell appeared at the bar of the Hou≈øe, and being duly ≈øworn, an≈øwered the following interrogatories.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Gallatin. Have you been po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of any New-Loan certificates in the year 1788?
An≈øwer. I had a quantity of New-Loan certificates about that time, but at pre≈øent cannot a≈øcertain their amount or numbers.
By the ≈øame. Did you ≈øell a certificate of that de≈øcription amounting to ¬£. 3275:19:4 to Blair M'Clenachan, if yea, plea≈øe to tell at what time?

An≈ø. It appears from my book, that I delivered ≈øuch a certificate to Mr. M'Clenachan, the 23d day April, 1788, which had been i≈ø≈øued in my own name. I delivered him many New-Loan certificates about that time.
Que≈ø. by Do. Do you know what he did with that certificate who≈øe amount was ¬£. 3275:19; 4, did he ≈øell it, or did he exchange it?

An≈ø. Impo≈ø≈øible for me to tell what Mr. M'Clenachan had done with it, the certificate was his own after he got it from me. I believe an exchange took place between him and the Comptroller-General, but in this I am not po≈øitive.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Evans. Have you a li≈øt of the names of the per≈øons to whom the certificates which you then had, were originally granted?
An≈ø. I have a book at home, in which I have entered their amounts, &c. but at this time I cannot be particular.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Gallatin. Had you any other New-Loan certificate of the ≈øame amount i≈ø≈øued in your name, about that time, before that time, or ≈øince that period?
An≈ø. Not likely that I ≈øhould have another of the ≈øame amount in my own name, it is impo≈ø≈øible for me to a≈øcertain.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Evans. Can you tell the number of that certificate, for ¬£. 3275:19:4?
An≈ø. I cannot a≈øcertain it, not having the No. of that one in my book.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Gallatin. Can you a≈øcertain the time when this certificate was i≈ø≈øued, and whether it was an original one, or i≈ø≈øued for a number of certificates, commonly called con≈øolidating?
An≈ø. I am inclined to think it had been i≈ø≈øued in exchange for others by the means la≈øt mentioned: but I am not certain as to that, nor to the time when i≈ø≈øued.
Mr. Gallatin ob≈øerved he had no more que≈øtions to a≈øk, and that the witne≈øs might retire.

Que≈ø. by Mr. Evans. Can you furni≈øh us with a li≈øt of the names of the per≈øons to whom i≈ø≈øued, numbers, dates and amounts of the certificates which you delivered to Blair M'Clenachan about the time alluded to?
An≈ø. I have a book, from which I will extract ≈øuch dates, numbers, and amount as far as I have entered them, and will tran≈ømit a li≈øt to the Hou≈øe as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible.
After which the witne≈øs retired.
Whereupon it was re≈øolved that the further con≈øideration of the ≈øaid additional articles of impeachment be po≈øtponed till the next day.
And the Speaker i≈ø≈øued his ≈øummons to accelerate the attendance of Blair M,Clenachan to give te≈øtimony on the≈øe articles again≈øt Mr. Nichol≈øon.

It was on motion, Ordered that Me≈ø≈ørs. Morgan, Evans and Gallatin, the three managers, ≈øhould procure atte≈øted documents from Mr. Thomas Smith, Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans, to an≈øwer the purpo≈øes of evidence on the≈øe articles again≈øt the Comptroller.

The committee got no documents from him, at that time, he was in the country for fear of the yellow fever
which then raged in the city, and carried off about 18 per≈øons per day.
Three gentlemen, were appointed a committee by the Senate on the 2d to confer with a committee from the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives on the expediency of an adjournment of the Legi≈ølature.
The Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives appointed five members to join the committee of the Senate.

div.head: SEPTEMBER 4.
div.p: THE committee appointed to confer with a committee of the Senate on the expediency of an adjournment of the Legi≈ølature, made report; which was read, as follows, viz.

That in the conference held by your committee with the committee of the Senate, they declared that they did not conceive that the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives would be ready to take a que≈øtion upon the expediency of an adjournment until they knew what time was fixed by the Senate for the trial of the charges brought by the Hou≈øe again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General‚ÄîYour committee thought it their duty al≈øo to mention, that although the Hou≈øe could not controul the deci≈øion of the Senate on that point, yet, they knew, they were ready at any time to ≈øupport the charges and de≈øirous that the trial ≈øhould come on immediately, to which they added ≈øeveral rea≈øons to urge the propriety of a deci≈øion on that bu≈øine≈øs taking place at this ≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Legi≈ølature.
Your committee ≈øubmit the following re≈øolution‚Äî

Re≈øolved, That the Senate be requ≈øted to fix the time at which they mean to try the charges brought by the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller General, and to give notice thereof to the Hou≈øe.
Ordered to lie on the table.

Mr. Edie, a committee from the Senate, being introduced, pre≈øented to the chair an Extract from the
Journal of that Hou≈øe; and having withdrawn, the ≈øame was read, as follows, viz.

body.p: "On motion of Mr. Morris, ≈øeconded by Mr. Thomas,
"Re≈øolved, That the Legi≈ølature will ri≈øe to-morrow. And
"Ordered, That Mr. Edie be a committee to pre≈øent the foregoing Re≈øolution to the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives for concurrence.

closer.signed: Extract from the Journal, TIMOTHY MATLACK, Clerk of the Senate."

div.p: The committee of accounts reported, a re≈øolution, that a warrant be drawn in favour of Benjamin R. Morgan for 492 dollars and 75 cents, being a balance due the committee of inve≈øtigation for their ≈øervices and expences.
Agreeably to the order of the day the additional articles were read the third time and adopted, and it was ordered that they ≈øhould be engro≈ø≈øed and ≈øigned by the Speaker.

Mr. Blair M'Clenachan having been ≈øummoned previous to the third in≈øtant, when Mr. M'Connell gave his evidence, and not appearing, a motion had been made to compel his attendance by an attachment, whereupon ≈øome argument had en≈øued, and it was conceded, that he did not ab≈øent him≈øelf thro' contumacy, but through a belief and expectation that the General A≈ø≈øembly had adjourned on account of the di≈øorder, con≈øequently no further notice had been taken of his non-attendance.
He appeared this day, and had been ≈øworn.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Evans. Did you purcha≈øe or receive any New-Loan certificates from Matthew M'Connell?
An≈øwer. I did, to a great amount.

Que≈ø. by ditto. To what amount were any of the≈øe certificates, or do you recollect any New-Loan certificate
received from him to be for the ≈øum of 3 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 19s. 4d.?
An≈ø. I remember to have had ≈øeveral.
Que≈ø. Has there been any ≈øuch in your name, or in the name of Mr. M'Connell?
An≈ø. My name! Mr. M'Connell's name!
Here the witne≈øs appeared ≈øomewhat embarra≈ø≈øed, not knowing the drift of the que≈øtion.

Mr. Gallatin ro≈øe, and ≈øaid he would put the witne≈øs right, ≈øaying, "I will mention a circum≈øtance, Do you remember that a large New-Loan certificate had been i≈ø≈øued about the time alluded to, for the ≈øum of ¬£. 5000 or thereabouts; that the ≈øaid certificate had been cancelled the next day, and two certificates i≈ø≈øued in lieu thereof, the aggregate amount of which was ¬£. 5000, as afore≈øaid; that one of the≈øe certificates had been for ¬£. 3275:19:4, and the other for the balance, do you remember any of the≈øe circum≈øtances?"
An≈ø. I perfectly recollect that circum≈øtance, and that I purcha≈øed the larger certificate, which was for 3275l. 19s. 4d, I believe.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Evans. Did you at any time ≈øell that certificate, or any other of the ≈øame kind?
An≈ø. Not to my knowledge, I do not remember.
Que≈øtion by Mr. Gallatin. Do you remember to have ≈øold that large certificate at any time, or to have exchanged it; if you have, plea≈øe to tell to whom, and what did you receive for the ≈øame?

div.p: "The Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, Pro≈øecutors on behalf of them≈øelves, and the People of Penn≈øylvania, again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of the ≈øaid commonwealth, reply to the an≈øwer of the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon, and averIt is worthy of remark that notwith≈øtanding this averment, the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives who made it, never went into any examination of the evidence, on which the charges were founded; and that Mr. Nichol≈øon in an≈øwer to his letter of 25th Feb. 1794, (≈øee page 200) was informed by the managers that the oral te≈øtimony given in the former Hou≈øe had not even been reduced to writing or pre≈øerved., that their charge of high mi≈ødemeanors again≈øt him the ≈øaid John is true, and that the ≈øaid John is guilty of all and every the matters contained in the articles of impeachment, by them exhibited again≈øt him, in the manner and form as they are therein charged, and this the ≈øaid Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives are ready to prove again≈øt him, at ≈øuch convenient time and place as the Senate ≈øhall appoint for that purpo≈øe."
