Mr. Morgan read the 5th article, ob≈øerving that he would ≈øub≈øtantiate the charge contained in this by re≈øpectable witne≈ø≈øes, they did not appear, and he moved for an adjournment, which was granted, with directions from the Speaker to be punctual.‚ÄîThe members of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives returned to their chamber, and repeated the ceremony, as in page 214 and 215.

The letter of Mr. Nichol≈øon, read ye≈øterday in the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives (≈øee page 200) was read the ≈øecond time; and referred to Me≈ø≈ørs. B. Morgan, M'Lene, Evans, and Bowman. It does not appear that they reported on it.

div.head: Third day of the trial. FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28.
div.p: THE Senate met; and the members of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives in committee of the whole repaired to the Senate-chamber.

At 10 minutes after eleven o'clock Mr. Morgan ro≈øe, having premi≈øed that his arguments the preceding days re≈øpected the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, third and fourth articles of impeachment again≈øt the Comptroller-General, that he would then proceed in order to the fifth.

That he would ≈øhew by the different ≈øtatements of that officer to the Legi≈ølature in his official capacity, that he did not look upon New-Loan certificates as a State debt after the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of March, 1789, as Mr. Nichol≈øon made no mention of them in any of his communications.
That the Governor was of the ≈øame opinion.
The committees on Ways and Means of the ≈øame;
And the Legi≈ølature likewi≈øe.

That after the printed documents would be brought forward, he ≈øhould then adduce oral te≈øtimony. He read part of the State of the Finances of the commonmonwealth as reported by Mr. Nichol≈øon on the 7th November, 1787, in which Mr. Nichol≈øon mentioned the New-Loans as an exi≈øting debt again≈øt the ≈øtate.

That in all his communications previous to March, 1789, the Comptroller mentioned the New-Loans as an exi≈øting debt; and a total change of ≈øentiment took place in him, in the Legi≈ølature, and Governor, after that period; becau≈øe they conceived the law of March, 1789, had done away the claim which exi≈øted by the law of 1786, and the New-Loans were omitted in all their ≈øub≈øequent ≈øtatements as no longer an object of Legi≈ølative con≈øideration.

He ob≈øerved that the Governor in his ≈øpeech to the Legi≈ølature on the 10th December, 1791, did not mention New-Loans as a debt or claim on the ≈øtate, and that he did not forget them, as he made mention of the payment of the arrears of intere≈øt due on them, for which provi≈øion is made in the repealing act of March, 1789.

He read part of the Governor's ≈øpeech to both Hou≈øes on the 28th December, 1790, being the fir≈øt ≈øe≈ø≈øion after the pa≈ø≈øing of the act of March, 1789, in which the Governor enumerated the aggregate of all the engagements of the commonwealth, and mentioned only the balance of intere≈øt due on the New-Loan debt; if they had been debts, he would not have executed his duty in omi ‚Ä¢ ting to ≈øtate them, that funds might be provided by the Legi≈ølature for their redemption.
The ≈øame idea was pur≈øued by the Governor in all his communications re≈øpecting the New-Loans.

The Comptroller-General him≈øelf, the committee on Ways and Means, and the other officers were of the ≈øame opinion. Mr. Morgan read part of the report of the committee on Ways and Means, Feb. 8th 1791, page 166 of the minutes, wherein the other debts of the commonwealth are mentioned and provided for, but not the New-Loans: Notwith≈øtanding this is called a ≈øtatement of all the debts of Penn≈øylvania, and added that every body put the ≈øame con≈øtruction on that debt.

He read part of the ≈øtatement of the Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General of the 30th November, 1791, to the Governor, and ob≈øerved that the Governor and the Secretary were betrayed into the part they had acted, and for proof of which he would call witne≈ø≈øes.

div.head: Alexander James Dallas, E≈øq ≈øworn.
div.p:
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Had there been any e≈øtimate made by the Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General of the ≈øtock to be ≈øold and debt to be redeemed, which e≈øtimate cannot be found at this time, and did or did not the
Comptroller ever hint that New-Loans were redeemable?

An≈ø. Immediately after the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of the 10th of April, 1792, agreeably to direction from the Governor, I applied, by letter, to the Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General, in the following words:

body.p: "BY the Act, entitled "An Act to provide for paying and redeeming certain public debts and for defraying the expences of Government." The Legi≈ølature contemplates the payment of certain debts on the fir≈øt day of July, next, by the ≈øale of 3 per cent. ≈øtock, at a certain rate, with a power however to ≈øu≈øpend the ≈øale until the ≈øtipulated price can be obtained, you will be plea≈øed therefore to take that Act into immediate con≈øideration, and report what arrangements will be nece≈ø≈øary, in your opinion, for carrying the redemption of the debt into effect. By order of the Governor,
body.trailer: To the COMPTROLLER-GENERAL and REGISTER-GENERAL of Penn≈øylvania.

div.p: Soon after this the Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General joined in a report to the Governor on the ≈øubject, which the Governor peru≈øed, approved, and ≈øigned with the initials of his name; in con≈øequence of which indor≈øement I returned it as an official document to the Comptroller or Regi≈øter's office as their authority to act, I do not know to which of them, not by my≈øelf, but by one of my a≈ø≈øi≈øtant clerks, whom I ordered to take it and deliver it with his own hands.

When the ≈øubject was before the Legi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ature, an enquiry was made for this document, and, I think, ≈øir, that application was made both to the Comptroller and Regi≈øter to furni≈øh it, after ≈øearch in their re≈øpective offices, they an≈øwered, it was not be found among their records. I then ≈øtrictly examined the papers in
my office, whether by ≈øome mi≈øtake or other, it had not been ≈øent to the Comptroller or Regi≈øter-General, after this ≈øearch my mind was clear, that it had been tran≈ømitted to the officers above mentioned.
I wrote again by the direction of the Governor to the Comptroller-General and Regi≈øter-General, (≈øee page 226.)
On the 26th of the ≈øame month they united in a joint report to the Governor, (≈øee page 227.)

Mr. Dallas ob≈øerved that he was not provided for being an evidence in this cau≈øe, that letters might be in his office, of which he might be totally ignorant, and if he ≈øhould be unacquainted with ≈øuch, or mi≈øtaken in dates or numbers he hoped to he excu≈øed, as he did not prepare him≈øelf to be a witne≈øs in this bu≈øine≈øs. The la≈øt e≈øtimate corre≈øponded with the fir≈øt, I ≈øpeak more from the conviction of my mind, than from the recollection of the document. The Comptroller and Regi≈øter's fir≈øt e≈øtimate, was dated before the 16th of April, 1792, which directed the mode of carrying the Act of the 10th of April, 1792, into execution, ≈øuppo≈øed to be lo≈øt.

Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Did any communication, except in writing, pa≈øs between the Governor and the Comptroller-General re≈øpecting the ≈øtock to be ≈øold and kind of debt to be redeemed, ≈øub≈øequent to the Act of the 10th of April, or whil≈øt that bu≈øine≈øs was pending before the Legi≈ølature?

An≈ø. Not to my knowledge; the Governor ≈øhewed me a plan of finance recommended by Mr. Nichol≈øon, who reque≈øted him (the Governor) to ≈øubmit it to the Legi≈ølature, I ≈øhewed it to ≈øome of the members, Mr. Gallatin for in≈øtance was one of them, who, if I under≈øtood him right, informed me he had ≈øeen and read it before, and refu≈øed to read it again.

Que≈ø. by the ≈øame. Do you remember any conver≈øation between your≈øelf and Mr. Nichol≈øon, re≈øpecting the redemption of New-Loans, or whether any intimation was made to you re≈øpecting the operation of that Act to embrace New-Loans?

An≈ø. On my fir≈øt hearing of the redemption of New-Loans, I was much ≈øurpri≈øed, I called on the Regi≈øter-General, ≈øame day I wrote to Mr. Inger≈øoll, (page 98-9), who appeared to be at a lo≈øs him≈øelf; I al≈øo called on the Comptroller-General, and a≈øked him upon what grounds he was proceeding in the redemption of New-Loans; as it was my opinion they were annihilated by the Act of March 27th, 1789, except for the purpo≈øe of equalizing the intere≈øt for four years, and the re-exchange.

Mr. Addi≈øon was in the office at the ≈øame time, he introduced him≈øelf to me, I learned that his bu≈øine≈øs there was, for the purpo≈øe of re-exchanging or redeeming New-Loans‚ÄîMr. Nichol≈øon told me that he was ≈øure he was right, and acting under the regular con≈øtruction of the Act, but gave me no particular rea≈øons for his proceedings.
I mentioned it to the Governor who directed me to get the Attorney-General's opinion on the ≈øubject, which was accordingly obtained, (≈øee pages 100-1-2.)
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Do you know any thing further on this bu≈øine≈øs, or relatively to what pa≈ø≈øed between the Comptroller and Mr. Addi≈øon?

An≈ø. I under≈øtood that Mr. Addi≈øon had two New-Loan certificates either for re-exchange, or redemption, he came to my office, I ≈øhewed him the annihilating Act, and gave him my opinion on the ≈øame. Mr. Dallas retired to be called up again, if wanted.

div.head: John Donnald≈øon, ≈øworn.
div.p: Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Have you been called upon to render an e≈øtimate of the debt to be redeemed and ≈øtock to be ≈øold about the 13th April, 1792?

An≈ø. About that time the Comptroller-General and my≈øelf received a letter from the Governor, directing us to render an e≈øtimate or ≈øtatement of the debt to be redeemed, and of the ≈øtock nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øold according to the directions of the Act of the 10th of April ≈øame year, for the purpo≈øe of redeeming that debt.

The documents on which this ≈øtatement or e≈øtimate was made, were lying in the Comptroller's office, the e≈øtimate was drawn up there, I concurred in it, a calculation of the 3 per cent. ≈øtock contemplated to be ≈øold, was annexed, or added to it; which was tran≈ømitted to the Governor, who approved of it, and it was returned, I believe, but do not know at this time, what became of it.

In December, 1792, being called upon by the committee of ways and means, for it, I turned to my letter book with confidence expecting to find it there, but could not, whether hurry of bu≈øine≈øs, or what prevented me from copying it, I cannot tell. I went to the Comptroller's office, it could not be found there, we ≈øat down and made out another from the rough papers which accorded with the fir≈øt, to which I gave my ≈øignature.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Did that e≈øtimate contain a ≈øtatement of all the ≈øtock to be ≈øold and the debt to be redeemed?
An≈ø. It occured ≈øo to us at that time.
Que≈ø. Do you recollect the amount of the 3 per cent. ≈øtock entered in the ≈øecond e≈øtimate?
An≈ø. I know it to be the ≈øame preci≈øely in the fir≈øt as in the ≈øecond. (He read it.)

Que≈ø. Did or did not the Comptroller intimate at any time to you his ideas, that New-Loan certificates were ≈øub≈øcribable, if ≈øo at what time, and when was the date of the fir≈øt warrant i≈ø≈øued for the payment of ≈øuch redemption?
Before the witne≈øs had time to an≈øwer this que≈øtion, Mr. Rawle propo≈øed that it would be better to ≈øtate the matter generally.‚ÄîTherefore the que≈øtion was altered to this.
Que≈ø. How was the redemption of State debts conducted.

An≈ø. As well as I can recollect when the debt was to be redeemed the party generally made out two copies of an ab≈øtract of the debt he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the≈øe ab≈øtracts were ≈øometimes printed and contained eight columns‚Äî
in the fir≈øt column the date was in≈øerted, in the ≈øecond the number, in the third, the name of the per≈øon by whom i≈øued; in the fourth, to whom i≈ø≈øued; in the fifth, the commencement of intere≈øt; in the ≈øixth, the amount of each certificate; in the ≈øeventh, intere≈øt computed to the 31≈øt December 1791, or otherwi≈øe agreeably to the quality of the certificates; and the eighth or la≈øt, contained the total amount of principal and intere≈øt in pounds, ≈øhillings and pence.
That ab≈øtract was brought to the Comptroller-General to certify the genuine and a≈ø≈øumable quality of the debt.
Que≈ø. Were the certifications of genuine and a≈ø≈øumable on both or only on one?
An≈ø. Sometimes on both, more from accident than de≈øign, as it was unnece≈ø≈øary.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Wilcocks. You ≈øay, the≈øe ab≈øtracts were printed, where were they to be had?
An≈ø. At the Stationers.
Que≈ø. Were there none to be had at the Comptroller's office?
An≈ø. I do not know.

After this certificate was obtained from the Comptroller, they carried that ab≈øtract and certificate to the Loan-officer of the United States, and there ≈øub≈øcribed it to the loan opened in a book for that purpo≈øe; after making this ≈øub≈øcription, the Loan-Officer gave them a duplicate of the ab≈øtract, and a receipt, which were brought to my office, and examined there, the intere≈øt calculated up to the time allowed by law, and an account was ≈øtated by me, State of Penn≈øylvania to ‚Äî Dr., owing to the hurry of bu≈øine≈øs it was divided between my Clerks and my≈øelf, they made the calculations of intere≈øt and additions, and I made the entries; or they made the entries, and I made the calculations and additions;‚Äîthat calculation with the ab≈øtract was ≈øent to the office of the Gomptroller-General, a corre≈øponding entry being made in my books.
Que≈ø. Was you always able to make this?

An≈ø. Being oftentimes much hurried, a per≈øon helped me in the calculations and ca≈øtings; intere≈øts were calculated ≈øometimes by my≈øelf, and ≈øometimes by another, but the entries were for the mo≈øt part made by me. I think it underwent an examination at the Comptroller's office, and in that ca≈øe the ab≈øtracts were returned to me becau≈øe I had not completed the returns of the particulars and different kinds of debt, but the gro≈øs amount: the Comptroller ≈øigned it, the ≈øame was brought to me, which I counter≈øigned, and it was then ≈øent to the Governor, who granted a warrant on the Trea≈øury for the amount.

I recollect to have no conver≈øation with the Comptroller re≈øpecting New-Loans, until after the date between the 14th and 17th July, 1792, when the ab≈øtracts No. 264, 265 and 266, and warrants had pa≈ø≈øed my office.

On this conver≈øation a conference took place concerning this matter, wherein I agreed with him in ≈øentiment, that the New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable, redeemable, and embraced under the act of the 10th April, 1792.
Que≈ø. Was it Mr. Nichol≈øon gave you the information?

An≈ø. I received information out of doors, that New-Loans were contained in the ab≈øtracts, and was ≈øo well convinced, altho' I went to Mr. Smith's to ≈øee whether New-Loan certificates were included, that I afterwards pa≈ø≈øed ≈øeveral ab≈øtracts knowing them to contain New-Loans, for which warrants i≈ø≈øued and were ≈øtopped in my hands, except one from Mr. Addi≈øon which I delivered him by mi≈øtake.

In my conver≈øation with the Comptroller we referred to the ≈øeveral acts of the United States and laws of this commonwealth, the only difficulty which occurred was the delivery of the Continental certificates for which the New-Loans had i≈ø≈øued‚ÄîHe an≈øwered it was a bune≈øs of the United States, and that he either had, or would ≈øettle that bu≈øine≈øs with the Secretary of the Trea≈øury
of the United States. He al≈øo avered that a per≈øon (as a creditor) holding the certificate, had it in his power to do it, knowing that the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of intere≈øt was the only difficulty, and that that would only take place until certificates of the United States were rendered.
This was the ≈øub≈øtance, I do not recollect the preci≈øe or ≈øpecific terms.
Que≈ø. You mention that you ≈øtopped ≈øome warrants ‚Äîrelate that circum≈øtance.
An≈ø. I ≈øtopped them in con≈øequence of a conver≈øation with Mr. Dallas.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Tilghman. Where did the conver≈øation with Mr. Nichol≈øon take place?
An≈ø. I believe in my office. I think I had a conver≈øation with him at his office door in con≈øequence of receiving ≈øub≈øcribable debt for three per cent. ≈øtock.
Que≈ø. How was ab≈øtract No. 262 ≈øub≈øcribed?

An≈ø. I recollect, that on receiving a debt, ≈øome were ≈øub≈øcribable, I made out an ab≈øtract in my own name, which I afterwards made over to the commonwealth. I went down to Mr. Smith's, where I ≈øub≈øcribed in blank for their amount, the hurry was ≈øo great in his office that he could not count them, this was on the 30th of June, as ≈øoon as Mr. Smith had lei≈øure, ≈øome days after, he counted them, and found that they corre≈øopnded with the ab≈øtract, he gave his receipt, dated 30th of June, corre≈øponding with the time I had ≈øub≈øcribed, which al≈øo appears in his report. I think, but will not be po≈øitive, that Mr. Nichol≈øon's name was there in blank on the books of ≈øub≈øcription.
Que≈ø. Have you the warrants here, which were ≈øtopt in your hands?
An≈ø. Yes‚Äîhere are four warrants and one certificate.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Will it require time to examine, or can you ≈øtate the amount of all the proper ≈øtate debt?
Que≈ø. It will require time to examine. (Retires.)

div.head: Thomas Biddle called up, and affirmed.
div.p: Que≈ø. Do you know any thing of a certificate brought to the office of the Comptroller-General for exchange, and bought by him. If you do, plea≈øe to inform the Senate?

An≈ø. In June 1792 I bought for my father from Solomon Raphael a New-Loan certificate ≈øigned by Nichol≈øon and Rittenhou≈øe, being one of tho≈øe commonly called New-Loan, in the name of John Thomp≈øon. Three year's intere≈øt had been paid by the ≈øtate on the certificate, and it was one of tho≈øe endor≈øed between Sept. 1777 and March 1778‚Äîand bore intere≈øt on the nominal ≈øum. The next day I ≈øent Je≈ø≈øe Morris, a young man who lived with my father, to the State-Trea≈øury, to receive the intere≈øt due thereon, he ≈øoon returned and informed me ≈øome difficuly occured re≈øpecting it, that Mr. Febiger had ≈øtopped the certificate, and had ≈øent Mr. Reilly his chief clerk to the Comptroller with it.
I therefore went to the Comptroller's office, met Mr. Reilly on the ≈øtairs, and he returned with me to Mr. Nichol≈øon's room.

I was informed more fully of the circum≈øtances by the Comptroller-General. I then recollected to have ≈øeen this de≈øcribed in an adverti≈øement on a file of ≈øtolen and lo≈øt certificates u≈øually hung up in Mr. Nichol≈øon's office; and likewi≈øe in the ne≈øwpapers. I enquired of Mr. Nichol≈øon whether any lo≈øs re≈øpecting this certificate would accrue to Mr. Biddle.

Mr. Nichol≈øon informed me that in a former ca≈øe of the like nature, the per≈øon who held them, had amicably ≈øettled the matter, and letters were ≈øent to Thomp≈øon re≈øpecting the certificates; likewi≈øe that he believed it would be no injury to Mr. Biddle, as it could be exchanged.

Upon this I turned to Mr. Nichol≈øon's de≈øk, took a blank exchange and filled it up, de≈øcribing this certificate of Thomp≈øon's, which I purcha≈øed of Raphael, the bu≈øine≈øs re≈øted here, and I went home, and left both the certificate and exchange with Mr. Nichol≈øon.
Que≈ø. Did or did not the Comptroller mention to you that the continental certificates for the≈øe were not in the office?
An≈ø. Yes he did, adding that they were loaned on bond to Thomp≈øon.
Que≈ø. Can you de≈øcribe it?

An≈ø. No, it is now a long time ago, I can't de≈øcribe the certificate, the bill of parcels, which I got from Raphael, and the papers were lo≈øt during the di≈øorder, and thereby the whole of the facts are deranged.
Que≈ø. Do you recollect the date of either September 1777, or March 1778, to be endor≈øed.
An≈ø. Yes‚Äîand I wrote to Mr. Nichol≈øon by the direction of my father the 5th day of July, 1792, who had been wholly intere≈øted in this bu≈øine≈øs. (Retired.)

div.head: Clement Biddle, affirmed.
div.p: I had been in the habit of purcha≈øing New-Loan certificates and entru≈øted that bu≈øine≈øs principally to my ≈øon, about the latter end of June, 1792, I ≈øaw by the bills of parcels, that my ≈øon had purcha≈øed a New-Loan certificate from S. Raphael, who frequently brought in certificates, which I purcha≈øed from him at their current value; ≈øame time I ob≈øerved that one year's intere≈øt was due, not apprehending any difficulty, I ≈øent it to the Trea≈øury to draw the intere≈øt.

Either that day, or the next, I do not recollect which, my ≈øon mentioned the circum≈øtances, and the difficulty in the payment of intere≈øt, and exchange,‚Äîafter which, on conver≈øing with ≈øome friends, and con≈øidering the law, and knowing that it was payable to bearer; I was convinced that I could not ≈øuffer, the ≈øtate had indemnified the holder, it mu≈øt be exchanged, the law was pa≈ø≈øed, the ≈øtate mu≈øt make it good.

A few days after, not immediately, I came to Mr. Nichol≈øon, and had, I believe, two opportunities, and ≈øpoke to him before the ≈øtate-hou≈øe; and I urged the exchange as there could be no exception to my right, he ≈øeemed to admit my right, but mentioned that he
had or mu≈øt fir≈øt write on the occa≈øion, to Mr. Thomp≈øon, from whom it had been ≈øtolen. I mentioned the inconvenience ari≈øing from delay, and to the be≈øt of my knowledge, was turning off with an intention of going home. After I mentioned that, he an≈øwered, and propo≈øed to give me the parts in ≈øtock, and to take it him≈øelf, which I con≈øidered as an accommodation, and by recurring to my letter book of the 5th or 6th July, I find that I wrote a letter or directed my ≈øon to do it, that I was obliged by his offer, and reque≈øted him to to take the certificate and to transfer the parts which the ≈øame would yield; by recurring I find the certificate was for 800 dollars nominal amount ≈øubject to depreciation between September 1777, and March 1778, and three year's intere≈øt paid. I ≈øent up that note: in a few days, and in the cour≈øe of bu≈øine≈øs I received the ≈øtock agreeable to the amount, I do not recollect the parts in ≈øtock. I had no idea then that New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable, nor for ≈øome time after.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Wilcocks. You ≈øay that Mr. Nichol≈øon offered the parts in ≈øtock?

An≈ø. If I had exchanged them I ≈øhould have received original Loan-Office certificates on paying the intere≈øt or an equivalent in Indents, I ≈øhould then have loaned them, and received the ≈øtock in 6, 3, and Deferred, which Mr. Nichol≈øon transferred to me, and this I con≈øidered an accommodation in point of time, in going to the office, and u≈øual routine of this bu≈øine≈øs. When I urged my right, and de≈øired an exchange, he offered to take it upon him≈øelf, and to transfer the parts, I had no idea for what purpo≈øe, or for what object?
Que≈ø. Do you know the date of your letter to him?
An≈ø. Yes; the 5th or 6th of July.
Que≈ø. Do you know the difference between the value of the parts you received and 20 É in the pound, was it 25 per cent?
An≈ø. I can't tell, can't a≈øcertain, I don't think it near that, I do not know, but will make up an account, ≈øign it, and ≈øend it.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Did you take up that certificate out of the office, or cu≈øtody of the Comptroller?
An≈ø. I did not.
Que≈ø. Was it the ≈øame day, or the day after your ≈øon mentioned the difficulty, that you went up to the Comptroller-General's office?
An≈ø. It might be a week thereafter, or longer, I cannot a≈øcertain. (Retired.)

div.head: Je≈ø≈øe Morris, affirmed.
div.p: I took a certificate from Mr. Biddle's to Col. div.head: Mr. John Oldden, affirmed.
div.p: Being then de≈øired to proceed, he ≈øaid, as it is a good while ≈øince the≈øe tran≈øactions had happened, and as my memory may fail, I had rather an≈øwer que≈øtions.

An≈ø. Yes; on or about the 4th of July, 1792, I had a number, ≈øuppo≈øe about ≈øeven or eight hundred odd pounds in New-Loan certificates, I, according to the u≈øual practice made up an ab≈øtract, and took them to the Comptroller-General's office to be exchanged, pre≈øented the ab≈øtract and certificates in due form, and left them with the Comptroller as it was u≈øual on ≈øuch occa≈øions.

An≈ø. After pre≈øenting them, I expected the original Continental certificates in lieu of them, I a≈øked when I might get the Continental certificates, the an≈øwer, as well as I can recollect, was, that I ≈øhould have them the next day about the ≈øame hour, it was then about 12 o'clock. I went up the next day‚Äî(Mr. Oldden was
de≈øired by Mr. Lewis to tell what pa≈ø≈øed in the mean time.) I ≈øaw the Comptroller the next day, I fancy, it mu≈øt have been in the mean time, an idea ≈øtruck me, that he could pay them into the Land-Office, and intended to a≈øk him ≈øomething more, don't know whether I went up twice or thrice, ≈øtill not ready; and when I did the la≈øt time, I told him, if he would give me thirty dollars beyond what their value was, as I ≈øuppo≈øed they would be of more u≈øe to him, he ≈øhould have them. Que≈ø. When you offered the certificates to the Comptroller for 30 dollars, did the Comptroller tell you it was too late?

An≈ø. I do not recollect, not certain, that any ≈øuch thing was mentioned, it is a long time ago, the arrearages of intere≈øt and thirty dollars con≈øtituted the ≈øum for which he gave me a check, and that was on the 7th of July, 1792, this I know from an entry in my memorandum book, the only written account, which I have of this tran≈øaction.

The ab≈øtract No. 262, was looked for, found, and ≈øhewed to Mr. Oldden, and he was de≈øired to inform the Senate whether his certificates were in it; he directly

div.head: Fourth day of the trial. SATURDAY, MARCH 1.

Mr. Morgan apoligized for the unavoidable nece≈ø≈øity they were under of po≈øtponing the trial, as it was out of their power to proceed to the 6th and 7th articles of impeachment as the te≈øtimony of two per≈øons are clo≈øely connected, one of them was ≈øeriou≈øly indi≈øpo≈øed, to procure who≈øe te≈øtimony they had taken preparatory

div.head: Fifth day of the trial. TUESDAY, MARCH 4.
div.p: SENATE met pur≈øuant to adjournment.
Mr. Morgan,
Mr. Speaker and Gentlemen of the Senate,

Having gone through the five fir≈øt articles of impeachment again≈øt the Comptroller-General of this commonwealth, it now remains for me to go on to the 6th and 7th articles, to under≈øtand the≈øe two, a con≈øiderable ≈øcale of important facts and corroborating te≈øtimony mu≈øt fir≈øt be attended to‚ÄîIf I have ≈øhewn that the Comptroller's opinion was, long before the pa≈ø≈øage of the Act of March 1789, that the New-Loans cea≈øed to be a State debt, it will render his conduct more criminal, a retro≈øpective view of a pa≈øt tran≈øaction will add ≈øome information to what has been already advanced: in one of his reports on the ≈øtate of the finances, dated October 1, and December 11, 1790; he had ≈øtated what debts were valid again≈øt the commonwealth and what were not.

Here Mr. Morgan read the report page 385, in the appendix to the minutes of 1790, containing what debts were to be di≈øcharged, and what were valid, agreeably to the report of the proper officers; that the pre≈øent con≈øtitution allowed of no draughts from the Trea≈øury except by previous appropriations made by law. But in page 389 in the 7th article of the finances are ≈øeveral ≈øubdivi≈øions, wherein the amount of the principal and intere≈øt of the New-Loans are defined, and excluded from redemption in the Land-office, whereby they cea≈øe to be and are no longer a debt of the ≈øtate. This is explained in expre≈øs terms, page 395 that New-Loans were then excluded. Here then we re≈øt our te≈øtimony
of the five fir≈øt articles, the≈øe are objects of our accu≈øation for plain and obvious rea≈øons.

We now come to objects of greater moment, to impeachments of a deeper dye, as the articles are of greater magnitude the puni≈øhment is to be ≈øeverer, ina≈ømuch as the Comptroller as a faithful guardian to pre≈øerve the property of the public, did not lay his hands on the trea≈øures of the commonwealth, for the purpo≈øe of ≈øaving the ≈øame, but made his official duty ≈øub≈øervient to ≈øpeculation. If the te≈øtimony already exhibited and arguments adduced, has made equal impre≈ø≈øion on the Senate as on the managers and on the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, who are his accu≈øers, the articles of impeachment will have the effect which the law and con≈øtitution require. (Here Mr. Evans a≈ø≈øi≈øted Mr. Morgan in arranging the papers and preparing the parts to be read.)

Among the various per≈øons who came to the Comptroller's office to loan their certificates, we find the name of Hans Hamilton, in different progre≈ø≈øions, and if I am RIGHTLY INSTRUCTED it will be proved that Loan-office certificates of the United States and New-Loan certificates were depo≈øited with Mr. Nichol≈øon, and both ultimately ≈øub≈øcribed to the Loan of the United States.

It remains with the Comptroller-General to account for that procedure, if the Act had required the ≈øame Continental certificates to be returned, the ca≈øe would be plain, and owing to the circum≈øtances of both, the New-Loans and the other certificates having been ≈øub≈øcribed by the ≈øame per≈øon a pre≈øumption is rai≈øed; and he ≈øhould ≈øhew why they had not taken different cour≈øes. The moment that they cea≈øed to be private property, they immediately became the property of the commonwealth, for the New-Loans and the Continental certificates could not be public and private property at one and the ≈øame point of time, yet both have been ≈øub≈øcribed.

In the li≈øt of New-Loans certificates originally i≈ø≈øued, book A, page 129‚Äîa certificate of ¬£. 11:16, No. 4051,
i≈ø≈øued to Hans Hamilton, ≈øame page, No. 4052 for ¬£. 268, No. 4053, ¬£.242:7:6 making in the whole ¬£. 522:3:6.

In the next Book A, ≈øtating what Continental certificates were received for the New-Loans i≈ø≈øued, from which it will appear a ≈ømall error of 2 É3 only excepted, that they agree exactly. Continental certificates with their numbers, &c. are as follows:‚Äî
No. 8316 Dolls. 31 42 ¬†

The≈øe la≈øt have been ≈øub≈øcribed by the Comptroller-General in the name of Hans Hamilton.

To prove that the Continental certificates thus depo≈øited exactly corre≈øponded with the New-Loans, I have in my hand a certificate from the Regi≈øter of the Trea≈øury ≈øigned by Jo≈øeph Nour≈øe, March 4th, 1794, by which it appears that the Comptroller-General had ≈øub≈øcribed by the Act of Augu≈øt 4, 1790, the certificates i≈ø≈øued as afore≈øaid.

It thus appears, that the fir≈øt therein, corre≈øponds exactly with the ≈øecond in the other, in numbers, names, dates, commencement of intere≈øt, and total amount; the corre≈øpondence between them is be≈øt a≈øcertained by going over the ab≈øtract, and examining the ≈øame, and, by comparing it with the Comptroller's books. I will now proceed to ≈øhew the New-Loans were al≈øo ≈øub≈øcribed‚Äî

Hans Hamilton

The≈øe three la≈øt contain the whole of the Continental certificates in the above ≈øtatement; ≈øo that it appears
Hans Hamilton came forward and had New-Loans i≈ø≈øued for his Continental ones, two evidences of the ≈øame debt‚Äîthis inconvenience would not have happened if the intention of the Legi≈ølature had been pur≈øued. After the law of 1789 the New-Loans were only a receipt or claim to get back the Continental certificates; by this means a duplication of debt had been brought again≈øt the United States, contrary to what the Union and Penn≈øylvania had contemplated. This is the only te≈øtimony now in our power, it remains with the Comptroller-General to ≈øhew and explain; it is manife≈øt that we had two debts in≈øtead of one, the certificates of the United States and tho≈øe of Penn≈øylvania, it is in his power to ≈øatisfy the Senate if his books were kept in the manner in which they ought to have been‚Äîif this tran≈øaction is not cleared up, the pre≈øumption is that ≈øomething is unfair and unworthy of this officer.

To ≈øhew however by as direct te≈øtimony as the circum≈øtance of this ca≈øe will admit that the Comptroller-General has made u≈øe of certificates brought to, and depo≈øited with him for re-exchange which he afterwards ≈øub≈øcribed to the Loan of the United States.

The circum≈øtances which both points are briefly to prove, are the≈øe; that Matthew M'Connell furni≈øhed or ≈øold a certificate for ¬£. 3275:19:4, to Blair M'Clenachan, which is among tho≈øe ≈øub≈øcribed by Mr. Nichol≈øon in his grand ab≈øtract. The pre≈øumptive te≈øtimony will be ≈øtrong, that the Comptroller received this certificate in his official capacity, and that he afterwards took it to his own u≈øe: The fir≈øt witne≈øs whom we ≈øhall call on this ≈øubject is Matthew M'Connell.

His depo≈øition amounted to this; that he ≈øaw Blair M'Clenachan on Saturday the fir≈øt of March in≈øtant, appeared to be much afflicted with the gout, that he was rolled about in an armed chair, from one part of his room to the other, that in every other re≈øpect he appeared to be in good health; the deponent left Germantown early on Sunday morning before Mr. M'Clenachan was up.

M'Clenachan, the witne≈øs, was ≈øummoned by Mr. Martin, the Serjeant-at-Arms of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, and wi≈øhed to have him ≈øworn, he was called, ≈øome delay occurred whil≈øt the Senate waited for him, after ≈øome time he came forward, and was ≈øworn. Mr. Morgan ob≈øerved, how they had taken all means in their power to procure the viva voce te≈øtimony of the

Whereupon the Speaker a≈øked him was it by the unanimous con≈øent of the defendant's coun≈øel‚Äîand being an≈øwered in the affirmative, he then ≈øtated how the commi≈ø≈øion i≈ø≈øued to the two magi≈øtrates, &c. and began the reading as herein after ≈øet down, Mr. Rawle read the interrogatories, Mr. Morgan the an≈øwers.

div.head: To the honorable the SENATE of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania,
div.p: WE the ≈øub≈øcribers, appointed to take the an≈øwers of Blair M'Clenachan, E≈øq on oath to ≈øeveral interrogatories committed to us in writing, to be propo≈øed to him, relative to an impeachment made before your honorable Hou≈øe by the honorable the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the commonwealth afore≈øaid, again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, E≈øq Comptroller-General of the ≈øaid commonwealth, do re≈øpectfully certify that on this fir≈øt day of March, Anno Domini one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ninety-four we repaired to the dwelling hou≈øe of the ≈øaid Blair M'Clenachan at Germantown, in the county of Philadelphia, and communicated to him the ≈øeveral interrogatories afore≈øaid, which are hereunto annexed; and that the ≈øold Blair M'Clenachan then and there, after having carefully and attentively read, examined and con≈øidered the ≈øaid ≈øeveral interrogatories, did on his ≈øolemn oath on the Holy Evangeli≈øts of Almighty God, to him by us duly admini≈øtered, declare unto us his an≈øwers to the ≈øaid ≈øeveral interrogatories in the words following‚Äîthat is to ≈øay:‚Äî
Inter. 1. on behalf of the ≈øtate. Were you at any time proprietor of a New-Loan certificate i≈ø≈øued by the State of Penn≈øylvania to the amount of ¬£. 3275:19:4?

An≈ø. 1. It is probable that I had a certificate of that amount, but I cannot be certain thereof as I had ≈øeveral large ones, and did not make out any account or li≈øt of my certificates when I delivered them to Mr. Nichol≈øon; but it may probably be found on examining the books of Mr. Rittenhou≈øe, the late State-Trea≈øurer, what certificates I received intere≈øt on.
Inter. 2. Did you ≈øell or lend ≈øuch certificate or depo≈øit ≈øuch certificate, at any, and what time, with, or to Matthew M'Cornell?

An≈ø. 2. I never, to the be≈øt of my knowledge, either ≈øold or lent to, or depo≈øited with Matthew M'Connell a certificate of the amount of ¬£. 3275:19:4, but I did lend him a number of ≈ømall certificates, (amounting in the whole to upwards of ¬£. 3000) a con≈øiderable time before I delivered my certificates to Mr. Nichol≈øon,‚Äî my ≈øon will furni≈øh you with the exact ≈øum from a memorandum made by me in a book at pre≈øent in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

body.p: "I HAVE ≈øent you the memorandum of tho≈øe certificates which my father lent to Mr. Matthew M'Connell, it is in his own hand-writing, and the leaf which I enclo≈øe containing the whole ≈øum.

div.p: Certificates lent Matthew M'Connell, Broker, Second-≈øtreet.
The above certificates delivered to Mr. M'Connell the 30th of March 1789, to be returned when demanded."

Inter. 3. Did you afterwards, and at, or about what
time receive ≈øuch certificates back from Matthew M'Connell?
An≈ø. 3. As I did not lend Mr. M'Connell a certificate of ¬£.3275:19:4 I could not receive one from him in return‚Äîthe amount of the ≈ømall certificates which I lent him, he did return to me.
Inter. 4. Did you take ≈øuch certificate to the office of the Comptroller-General for exchange pur≈øuant to Act of A≈ø≈øembly of March 27, 1789?

An≈ø. 4. I took all the New-Loan certificates that I po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed (which were to a very con≈øiderable amount) to the Comptroller-General and delivered them to him to be exchanged, without having made any li≈øt or account of them.

Inter. 5. Was ≈øuch certificate exchanged by the ≈øaid Comptroller-General, and did you receive in lieu thereof Continental certificates of equal value to the ≈øame as tho≈øe you originally loaned to the State?

When or how impeachments began in England, or for what purpo≈øe, and whether this mode, like engines, are made u≈øe of for power or faction, is immaterial. An≈ø. I have under≈øtood that tho≈øe were the points to which I ≈øhould give evidence, and I have ju≈øt ≈øent for the minutes of 1791 to whet my recollection as my memory is imperfect at this time. [Gets the books.] The only difficulty I have is, the date of the conver≈øation, I do not recollect that very well, whether before the bill was reported, or while the report of the committee on ways and means was before the Hou≈øe‚Äîthe import of the conver≈øation was that Mr. Nichol≈øon had an objection, he gave me his plan, and reque≈øted me to give my opinion, the plan before the Hou≈øe was to redeem the debts, his plan did not propo≈øe a redemption but commutation with an irredeemable quality. I thought the redeeming plan better and therefore did not approve and I returned him his plan. Another circum≈øtance, After I returned the plan to Mr. Nichol≈øon, the Secratary of the commonwealth ≈øhewed me that plan or a copy of it, and reque≈øted me to look at it, and that Mr. Nichol≈øon reque≈øted the Governor to recommend it to the Legi≈ølature, the bill agreeably to the report of the committee of Ways and Means was
then under the con≈øideration of the Legi≈ølature, I told Mr. Dallas that I had ≈øeen it before, and di≈øapproved of it, and told him the Governor had better examine the plan, and not ≈øend it except he approved of it.

After the bill pa≈ø≈øed; and the Hou≈øe adjourned. I was in the Comptroller's office; the conver≈øation turned on the po≈ø≈øibility of carrying the Act into execution, ≈øe≈øeveral difficulties aro≈øe, and objections were ≈øtarted, on account of the price of ≈øtock in the market being lower than the price limited in the Act, and propo≈øitions were made to get over the difficulty. Al≈øo whether a part of the 3 per cent. ≈øtock ≈øhould be ≈øold or the whole at once; I was afraid the whole plan would be defeated. The≈øe objections were rai≈øed by the officers. The defendant ≈øugge≈øted that by the law unfunded depreciation certificates were redeemable, altho' the Legi≈ølature perhaps might not intend it: That it appeared to him unfunded depreciation was redeemable, altho' the report excluded them. Upon that Mr. Nichol≈øon ≈øhewed me the 6th ≈øection, I a≈ø≈øented to what he ≈øaid, and ≈øaid that I thought the unfunded certificates were included in that ≈øection. I added that I had drawn the bill my≈øelf, and had made the 6th ≈øection a provi≈øo to the ≈øecond; expre≈øsly providing for the redemption of certain certificates therein defined, which would put the thing beyond di≈øpute, becau≈øe the ≈øecond ≈øection defined the thing to be redeemed, that the provi≈øo was made a di≈øtinct ≈øection out of the Hou≈øe; as ≈øome kind of provi≈øo, always con≈øidered in the Hou≈øe, but a≈ø≈øented at the ≈øame time that the con≈øtruction would extend to unfunded depreciation. I had no time to form an opinion, it was of the moment, on the fir≈øt impre≈ø≈øion. I al≈øo added that it was very immaterial to the ≈øtate to redeem this way, or by the Land-Office, the price being at that time nearly the ≈øame as ca≈øh.The defendant refers to the price-current of the brokers to prove that the price of New-Loans in the market was then as high as unfunded Depreciation certificates. Mr. Donnald≈øon was pre≈øent the whole or mo≈øt of the time. I don't remember
member to hear any other opinion from Mr. Donnald≈øon except at that time. At the next meeting of the Legi≈ølature on my return to the city, I was a≈øtoni≈øhed to hear that New-Loans were redeemed‚ÄîI had a ≈ømall New-Loan certificate from Mr. Dougla≈øs, which I kept pretty late, don't know whether before or after the law pa≈ø≈øed, I gave it to the Comptroller to exchange it, he ≈øaid he was hurried, he would get it exchanged and ≈øub≈øcribed and give me the parts; he gave me a receipt for the New-Loan. I do not know the time, it was about May, it was not completed at the end of April, I left town with that receipt in my pocket, which I gave to Mr. Dougla≈øs, I know I had no idea of their being of any other u≈øe than for the purpo≈øe of exchange, if I had thought they were redeemable, I would enquire and do the be≈øt for him who employed me.
Que≈ø. Did you not give an opinion that whatever were ≈øub≈øcribable, were redeemable?
An≈ø. Yes; that was the ground of my opinion that the unfunded depreciation were redeemable.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Lewis. Of what date was that conver≈øation?

An≈ø. A day or two after the adverti≈øement was publi≈øhed, I ≈øtaid in town ten days after the Hou≈øe had adjourned, the adverti≈øement was put into the public papers before I left town, the ≈øale of ≈øtock was the 16th April‚Äîthe ≈øum to be ≈øold was 986,000 dollars. I think the adverti≈øement was the ground of our conver≈øation.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Did you concur in opinion with the Comptroller-General that if Congre≈øs ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume the ≈øtate debts that bills of credit would be redeemable?

An≈ø. That was not mentioned, if it was I did not a≈ø≈øent. The rea≈øon why I recollect it, was that during the following Legi≈ølature a letter was written by the Comptroller in which ≈øuch an idea was introduced. This made me look into the law, to ≈øee whether there were any grounds for it, ≈øaw there a di≈øtinction made between certificates and bills of credit, the ≈øixth ≈øection
includes only certificates. The Comptroller's letter is in the fall of 92 or ≈øpring of 1793.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Do you recollect how the Regi≈øter-General expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf at that meeting?
An≈ø. I don't remember his giving any opinion, I think he acquie≈øced as far as the unfunded depreciation certificates.
Que≈ø. by ditto. In the cour≈øe of this conver≈øation was there any other object than the unfunded depreciation certificates?
An≈ø. None that I recollect.
The Regi≈øter-General expre≈ø≈øed his opinion very fully next year before the committee of ways and means, but before that time I do not remember.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. Did he mention his opinion at the time New-Loans were redeemed?

An≈ø. Yes. (Report of committee on ways and means, page 337) a part of the report was grounded on the te≈øtimony of the Regi≈øter-General re≈øpecting them‚Äî (Here he read "deluded into error, di≈øcriminate," &c.) the whole of that was grounded on the declaration of the Regi≈øter-General, he declared he was not con≈øulted and the ab≈øtracts on the face did not di≈øcriminate, there was a change took place between this and the time when the articles of impeachment were before the Hou≈øe, he ≈øaid the ab≈øtracts ≈øufficiently di≈øcriminated, and that the New-Loans could be ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhed. Another article was then made to conform to this idea. (Hers Mr. Gallatin pointed out what, he called, an error in the minutes, page 361 and 374.) He al≈øo ≈øaid he always conceived if they were a≈ø≈øumable, they were redeemable with this ≈øingle difficulty, whether there was power lodged with the Comptroller to give up the Continental certificates‚ñ™ The Comptroller had always certified the ≈øub≈øcribability without his knowledge. He was al≈øo a≈øked how he did not di≈øcover them by other marks‚Äîhis an≈øwer was, that his part was the calculation of intere≈øt, and did not attend to any other. La≈øt ≈øummer when the committee of inve≈øtigation examined the certificate of John
Thomp≈øon, for ¬£. 231:7:7, found that intere≈øt was calculated on ¬£.300‚Äîthat certificate was reduced by the ≈øcale of depreciation, I a≈øked Donnald≈øon, here was one you could not mi≈øtake, you ≈øaid you calculated the intere≈øt from this calculation, and date of intere≈øt, you mu≈øt be ≈øati≈øfied that this was a New-Loan?‚ÄîHe ≈øeemed much confu≈øed and ≈øaid a clerk had done it, and appeared as if he knew nothing of it. He al≈øo ≈øaid he pa≈ø≈øed one ≈ømall one after he knew it.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Lewis. Were the articles found without the witne≈ø≈øes being ≈øworn?

An≈ø. Mr. M'Clenachan, Mr. M'Connell, and Mr. Oldden were ≈øworn‚ÄîDonnald≈øon was a public officer, and was not ≈øworn, no other witne≈øs whatever was attached to this third article but Mr. Donnald≈øon.

div.head: Mr. Jo≈øeph Boggs, ≈øworn.
div.p: Que≈ø. Did you ≈øub≈øcribe any New-Loans to the ≈øtate loan of the United States?

An≈ø. Yes; about the latter end of June or beginning of July 1792, I was a≈øked for New-Loan certificates, I a≈øked what they would give me, they ≈øaid 6 or 7 pence more than for final ≈øettlements, I had none then, but from this circum≈øtance I was induced to try to find out what they wanted to do with them. After reading the Act of Congre≈øs of 4th of Augu≈øt 1790, a≈ø≈øuming ≈øtate debts, and the Act of this ≈øtate which was pa≈ø≈øed in April 1792, it was my opinion they were a≈ø≈øumable, and in con≈øequence I purcha≈øed and ≈øub≈øcribed part on my own account and part on account of another per≈øon, none on Mr. Nichol≈øon's account, I can't tell who came to me, I made an ab≈øtract, carried it to Mr. Nichol≈øon, he certified them genuine and a≈ø≈øumable, they were not redeemed as the bu≈øine≈øs was ≈øtopped.
Que≈ø. by Mr. Inger≈øoll. What's the rea≈øon of 6 or 7 pence higher than the other certificates? Were they equal before?

An≈ø. No difference. I did not know that Mr. Nichol≈øon was purcha≈øing at that time‚Äîwas informed by
the Regi≈øter-General that a ≈øtop was put to them in the Secretary's office.
Mr. Tilghman proceeded‚Äî

It appears al≈øo that Judge Addi≈øon was making a ≈øecond ≈øub≈øcription, it is pre≈øumable that he knew the law. It is mentioned that Mr. Nichol≈øon did not certify in his own ca≈øe. This is a ≈øtrong circum≈øtance: If he was con≈øcious that the certification would be improper, he would have omitted it: before the ≈øecond loan it was not cu≈øtomary. A counterfeit certificate of Lawman, of Lanca≈øter, gave ri≈øe to this certification.
Mr. Richard Smith (≈øon to the late Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans) brought the ≈øub≈øcription book to the ≈øtate loan of the U. S. and being ≈øworn, declared as follows.

George Lawman of Lanca≈øter ≈øub≈øcribed in the name of Gungachu, a certificate No. 234 which proved to be counterfeit. I believe the cau≈øe of certifying was to prevent inconvenience to the parties, when they came without ≈øuch certification they were generally ≈øent to Mr. Nichol≈øon's office, I did not know when the practice commenced‚Äîit made no odds to us whether it was done or not, as the receipt which my father gave was ≈øubject to examination, when the fir≈øt and ≈øecond loans clo≈øed we took the certificates to the Comptroller's office and examined for our≈øelves. (Retired.)
Mr. Tilghman.

It hath been objected that the Governor called for a ≈øtatement which does not at this time appear, altho' its contents are pretty ≈øatisfactorily acknowledged, a bare attention to the time when this tran≈øaction took place will ≈øhew the a≈ø≈øertion is unfounded‚ÄîIt is true the ≈øtate committed her≈øelf ≈øo far as to redeem what would be a≈ø≈øumed, but as the Act of Congre≈øs was not then pa≈ø≈øed, it was unknown what Congre≈øs would a≈ø≈øume. The Comptroller never thought New-Loans came under the ≈øecond ≈øection, the ≈øale of ≈øtock related only to the ≈øecond ≈øection, he could not divine more than others, it by no means follows from this that New-Loans were not redeemable‚Äî≈øtrange that in the fourth article they endeavour
to prove the premi≈øes from the conclu≈øion. It was lawful for him to purcha≈øe as well as others, the moment a doubt was ≈øugge≈øted he ≈øtopped and paid Judge Addi≈øon July 23, 1792, for his ≈øub≈øcription pound for pound. If this is doubted, recour≈øe may be had to the bank, where they'll find that Mr. Nichol≈øon paid the full amount.
He read the following letter‚Äî

body.p: "THE Governor directs me to reque≈øt that you will avoid giving any ≈øanction to an idea that the New-Loan certificates of the State are ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan propo≈øed by Congre≈øs, or certifying that they are ≈øo to the Continental Loan-officer, until he has received the opinion of the Attorney-General upon that ≈øubject.
body.trailer: To the Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General.

div.p: Mr. Tilghman.‚Äî

Before I proceed to the next head, I will remark that the ≈øtate ought to pay the full amount, that the New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable and redeemable, and con≈øequently the ≈øtate ought to pay pound for pound, and really the complaint again≈øt the Comptroller is of an extraordinary nature‚Äî"Mr. Nichol≈øon acquired wealth that the ≈øtate ought to have got!"‚ÄîI fancy if any que≈øtions ought to be rai≈øed, it ought not to be between the commonwealth, but between the per≈øons from whom Mr. Nichol≈øon bought, he however bought fairly. I now come to the Acts of A≈ø≈øembly, and I will ≈øhew that the con≈øtruction drawn by the managers, is injurious and derogatory, and I hope to ≈øhew Mr. Nichol≈øon's con≈øtruction to be con≈øonant to good faith, honor and equity. If the law is to receive their con≈øtruction, it will oppo≈øe the Federal Con≈øtitution, which is the ≈øupreme law of the land; and therefore it is utterly void.
My po≈øitions are, that New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable to the fir≈øt loan, al≈øo to the ≈øecond, and likewi≈øe redeemable under the ≈øixth ≈øection of the Act of the 10th April 1792.

(Here Mr. Tilghman read the 3d, 7th and 11th ≈øections of the Act of March 1, 1786, to prove that New-Loans were as much a debt as any other.) No matter whether the commonwealth became immediately indebted or thro' the agency of others. Temporary provi≈øion is not apparent from the Act. If the commonwealth entertained temporary views they were not mutual. Mutuality and reciprocity are the e≈ø≈øence of contracts. Whatever is rea≈øonable with private per≈øons in the ca≈øe of contracts is ≈øo with the State.

But it hath been contended that the Act of March 27 1789, puts the≈øe certificates into an ambiguous ≈øtate; let us examine the Act it≈øelf‚Äî"Whereas the duties on exports and impo≈øts are given to Congre≈øs‚Äîtemporary relief ‚Äîit became inconvenient to pay half-yearly, &c."‚Äîthis Act does not compel an exchange, it leaves it optional; perhaps the commonwealth could not pay, what then ought to be done?‚Äîwe will give you an option. You are our creditor; we have contracted to pay you principal and intere≈øt; we will pay you four year's intere≈øt becau≈øe we are able to do ≈øo, and we will give you back your original certificate at your option, or we will pay you when we can.

The 3d ≈øection did not contemplate that all would exchange, and it implies too much inju≈øtice and impropriety to pre≈øume they meant to ab≈øolve them≈øelves from the payment of the remainder; "MANY," is a relative term, it does not imply a majority, it means ≈øome may, others would not.

Under the con≈øtruction of the Managers the New-Loan holder is a creditor of nobody; but po≈ø≈øibly or probably may become the creditor of the Continent. Notwith≈øtanding the time of payment is altered, yet the State holds the value in her hands and continues no debtor. How can ≈øuch a con≈øtruction be put on this
Act without flying in the face of the Federal Con≈øtitution‚Äî(Section 10 of the fir≈øt article is cited,) Congre≈øs in the ninth ≈øection of the ≈øame article is denied the power of making ex po≈øt facto laws.

This is the la≈øt of all ≈øuppo≈øable ca≈øes, by this Con≈øtitution no State can pa≈øs a law impairing the obligation of contracts made between A and B, con≈øequently a State cannot do it, when ≈øhe is a contracting party.

I now refer to the Act of 7th April 1791, that the commonwealth contemplated them as a debt. (He quoted Act of 7th April, 1791, page 51 and 54.) Where the State ≈øeemed to contemplate the preventing of New-Loans from ≈øub≈øcription. No. 235 is the fir≈øt ab≈øtract which was certified‚ÄîNo. 234 was counterfeit as afore≈øaid. No certification of genuine and a≈ø≈øumable from Mr. Nichol≈øon before the counterfeit was di≈øcovered.

It was not the duty of the Comptroller-General to certify‚Äîno checks of office have been broken‚ÄîMr. Nichol≈øon was under no obligation to con≈øult the Governor‚Äîno law required a di≈øcrimination, it would be wrong to do it, no intention in the Comptroller to deceive, if a difference of opinion with the Regi≈øter-General exi≈øted then it would be right, he took no pains to colour, no labour to ≈øhed confu≈øion, the New-Loans in his ab≈øtracts might have been known from all others, if the Regi≈øter or any other per≈øon would examine them, this afforded an infallible criterion, if he had been at any pains to conceal‚Äîit would be contemptible ≈øwindling, „Äà‚óä„Äâ mean point of view indeed, "till he got the money. The ≈øub≈øcription was in his own name, fairly and openly "to promote and procure his own emolument"‚Äîcome what will of the≈øe allegations no ≈øuch thoughts were in the Comptroller's mind, he ≈øets all ≈øuch at de≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
The 4th a article of impeachment.

There is a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nd, 12th appropriation, by the Act of 7th April, 1791, and applies to our ca≈øe by the 6th ≈øection of the Act of 10th April 1792. Out of this fund were redeemed the unfunded depreciation warrant
No. 1551 for Brigade-In≈øpector, and ≈øeveral others which he referred to. If there was no fund it was no guilt imputable to the Comptroller, as it was not his look out, but the Governor's who drew the orders. (Here Mr. Wilcocks hinted to Mr. Tilghman, "no matter what fund, ≈øo you get the money." Other warrants were produced here‚Äîwarrant No. 243 in favor of Mr. Rittenhou≈øe, May 16th, 1792, no law expre≈øsly appropriating this fund.

Mr. Dallas was called up and ≈øaid, he never knew unfunded depreciation debt to have been paid under the Act of 10th April, 1792. The unfunded depreciation debt was not in the e≈øtimate (Mr. Trimble was introduced with his book) and Mr. Dallas read from his records the forms of the certificates and warrants‚Äîthe original ≈øtatement did not extend to unfunded deprecition debt: The Comptroller and Regi≈øter-General were called on for a ≈øtatement of the debt to be redeemed and accordingly the Governor directed the ≈øale.

Mr. Tilghman‚ÄîHaving ob≈øerved that the 1≈øt, 2d and 3d articles of impeachment are not ≈øupported, and the 4th being a con≈øequential deduction from the preceding ones, if the former has no foundation, the latter cannot be ≈øupported, I will to-morrow endeavour to di≈øcharge my duty re≈øpecting the ≈øucceeding articles.

In the minutes of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives the following is recorded:‚Äî

"In conformity to the re≈øolutions of the 25th February la≈øt the Hou≈øe re≈øolved it≈øelf into a committee of the whole in order to attend the trial of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of this commonwealth, now depending before the Senate, on the articles of impeachment exhibited again≈øt him by the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives.

div.head: Eighth day of the trial. FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1794.
div.p: SENATE met pur≈øuant to adjournment.
Mr. Tilghman.‚Äî

Under the 12th appropriation the law admits the fund for claims and improvements. In≈øtances can be produced: But it is immaterial whether there are in≈øtances or not, if the law is with us. (The Trea≈øurer was ≈øent for at this time, who an≈øwered he could not come, and if the defendant wanted the vouchers he mu≈øt ≈øend a hor≈øe and cart for them.)

Under the fifth and ≈øixth articles the Comptroller is charged with purcha≈øing certificates of per≈øons coming to his office for the purpo≈øe of exchanging them ‚ÄîI acknowledge the fact and contend it is lawful; he purcha≈øed of Oldden, I contend that the property of the certificates were not ve≈øted in the State or Penn≈øylvania, the bu≈øine≈øs was inchoate: a good deal remained to be done, the property belonged to the party, the amount of intere≈øt was to be calculated, indents to be paid, &c. before the exchange was completed. In≈øtances will be be ≈øhewn to prove the practice of withdrawing after they had been thus rendered.
John Pear≈øon, for whom a ≈øubpoena had been i≈ø≈øued, was called but did not appear.

div.head: Griffith Evans, ≈øworn.
div.p: I had been in the practice of frequently bringing New-Loans to the Comptroller-General's office to be exchanged. I was once at the Comptroller's office, I met a per≈øon from Che≈øter county who had previou≈øly left a New-Loan certificate with Mr. Nichol≈øon to be exchanged, he appeared to be going away, I ≈øuppo≈øe to get indents; I offered to do it for him, Mr. Nichol≈øon delivered me the certificate which I afterwards exchanged, probably at ≈øome ≈øub≈øequent period when I was exchanging more for my≈øelf, the date I ≈øuppo≈øe in the winter of 1792.
Que≈ø. Was it before the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of the 10th April 1792? and inform of any circum≈øtances re≈øpecting it.

An≈ø. I will relate a circum≈øtance; previous to the pa≈ø≈øing of that Act, I came to the Comptroller-General's office, I met Mr. Gallatin going down, almo≈øt as ≈øoon as I came up to Mr. Nichol≈øon's table, I ≈øaid is it po≈ø≈øible that they will pa≈øs that law? if pa≈ø≈øed as reported it will include New-Loans. Mr. Nichol≈øon ≈øaid, I have been endeavouring to convince Mr. Gallatin that it will do ≈øo.

We conver≈øed on the ≈øubject and both agreed that it would not be for the intere≈øt of the State, and that it would be better if the Act did not pa≈øs. We thought it better for the State not to ≈øell the ≈øtock. Mr. Nichol≈øon ≈øaid, he thought he had convinced Mr. Gallatin. I do not remember any thing about unfunded debt‚Äîit appeared to me ≈øo extraordinary that I thought it would not pa≈øs. We did not go into particular ≈øtatements, no other inconvenience mentioned except the ≈øelling of the public ≈øtock. After the law pa≈ø≈øed I revolved in my mind whether I ≈øhould go into a ≈øpeculation, but from ≈øome con≈øideration I did not.
Mr. Tilghman:

On the 16th of March 1792, the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives
(by the minutes) re≈øolved it≈øelf into a committee of the whole to take the Act of the 10th April 1792 into con≈øideration. I will ≈øhew from the books of Mr. Nichol≈øon that he ≈øpoke to Mr. Gallatin as the la≈øt witne≈øs had depo≈øed‚Äî(after ≈øome debate the diary, book A, of the Comptroller was rejected as improper te≈øtimony, being the private memorandum of the defendant, as they alledged.)
Mr. Donnald≈øon was called and declared,
I was never before the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives; only before the committee of Ways and Means: never on oath. I was reque≈øted to reduce what I had to writing, and ≈øend it to them, which I did.

Mr. Tilghman.‚ÄîIt has been ≈øuppo≈øed that Hans Hamilton received Continental Loan-office certificates from the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania the≈øe have been ≈øub≈øcribed by John Nichol≈øon on Hans Hamilton's account to the dome≈øtic debt of the United States‚ÄîAnd the corre≈øponding New-Loans al≈øo by the Comptroller-General on his own account to the State loan. div.p: THE order which as Coun≈øel for the defendant I ≈øhall ob≈øerve in replying to the articles of impeachment, will conform to that pur≈øued in the arrangement of the articles them≈øelves. I ≈øhall accordingly begin with the fir≈øt which appears of the greate≈øt importance, and ≈øerves as an introduction to the others.

This article, after declaring that the New-Loans cea≈øed to be a State-debt on the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of March 1789, charges the defendant with certifying them to be ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan of Congre≈øs as debts of Penn≈øylvania, contrary to his official tru≈øt, and as he well knew to the manife≈øt injury of the commonwealth.

The ≈øub≈øtantial part of the article con≈øi≈øts in the po≈øition that the New-Loans were not State debt after March 1789, nor of cour≈øe ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan, and grounds on this ba≈øis the ≈øub≈øequent charge of guilt in the defendant in declaring them to be ≈øub≈øcribable.
To a≈øcertain the weight of this po≈øition it will be nece≈ø≈øary to a≈øcend to the origin of the≈øe certificates, and to trace them from that time to the period mentioned in the article.
The≈øe certificates are derived from the Act of the 1≈øt March 1786. Vol. 2. p. 417.
This Act after mentioning the occa≈øion of pa≈ø≈øing it, directs the mode of i≈ø≈øuing the certificates and places them upon the ≈øame footing with the mo≈øt favored certificates of the ≈øtate.

The fir≈øt ≈øection declares "it is ju≈øt and proper that the patriotic citizens of this State, who in the late arduous conflict, yielded their property and their per≈øonal ≈øervices to the public u≈øe, and thereby eminently contributed to the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the peace, liberty, and ≈øafety, of the United States of America, ≈øhould be relieved, as far as circum≈øtances will admit, from bearing an undue proportion of the public burthen, which ought to re≈øt equally on all the citizens." The ≈øecond proceeds to direct blank certificates to be procured, and pre≈øcribes the form, viz. The commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania has received on loan from _____ the _____ of _____ to be paid to the ≈øaid _____ or bearer on or before the fir≈øt day of March in the year of our Lord one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ninety-≈øix, with intere≈øt from the _____ day of _____ at the rate of ≈øix per centum per annum to be paid half-yearly at the State-Trea≈øury according to the directions of an Act of the General A≈ø≈øembly, pa≈ø≈øed on the _____ day of _____ . The third directs the loan to be opened, to continue ≈øo two years, and regulates the dates of the certificates to be i≈ø≈øued. The fourth di≈øtingui≈øhes the kinds of Continental certificates to be received. The ≈øixth and ≈øeventh mention that certain Continental Loan-office certificates i≈ø≈øued between 1 Sept. 1777 and 1 March 1778 are ≈øubject to liquidation by the ≈øcale of depreciation on their final redemption, altho' the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors are entitled to receive the annual intere≈øt at full value on the nominal ≈øum until ≈øuch redemption takes place, and direct a reference to the≈øe certificates to be made on the New-Loans i≈ø≈øued therefor; that on the payment of the principal they may be ≈øubject to the ≈øame liquidation.

The other ≈øections provide for the payment of the intere≈øt on the New-Loans half-yearly‚Äîmake them redeemable at the Land-office‚Äîprovide for the Continental certificates received and for conducting the loan.
A Supplement to this Act was pa≈ø≈øed 28th March 1787, p. 508, extending the loan to tho≈øe citizens who had made loans in the Continental Loan-offices of Delaware and New-Jer≈øey.

From the whole complexion of this Act it appears that the Legi≈ølature con≈øidered the certificates i≈ø≈øued in pur≈øuance of it, or in other words the New-Loans, as effectually State debt, as tho≈øe of any other de≈øcription. For they on the face of the certificate promi≈øe to pay the principal on or before the year 1796, and the intere≈øt half-yearly until that time. The Land-office is open for their reception as for other certificates; and tho≈øe which were peculiarly ≈øituated as already mentioned, are directed to be reduced to ≈øpecie value on the payment of the principal.

The merit of the holders of the≈øe certificates was equally great, with the holders of any other. The debts were contracted in a common cau≈øe‚Äîthe citizens of Penn≈øylvania were the creditors, and the State her≈øelf enjoyed in common with the other States, the benefits of their exertions.

That the provi≈øion made in this Act was de≈øigned to be permanent, and the New-Loan creditors con≈øidered by our Legi≈ølature of the mo≈øt meritorious cla≈øs, will appear in the ≈øtronge≈øt manner by referring to a re≈øolution of the Legi≈ølature upon this ≈øubject on the 27th December 1786, Minutes of A≈ø≈øembly, p. 97.

This re≈øolution took place upon a very pre≈ø≈øing occa≈øion‚ÄîCongre≈øs being much embarra≈ø≈øed, appointed a committee to di≈øclo≈øe to our Legi≈ølature the urgent ≈øtate of their affairs, and to reque≈øt an immediate grant of the impo≈øt to enable them to comply with the engagements of the Union.‚ÄîThe Legi≈ølature after paying all the attention due to the importance of the occa≈øion, re≈øolve in words as ≈øtrong as language can expre≈øs, that
their engagements to their own citizens prevent them without a breach of good faith from complying with the reque≈øt, at the ≈øame time informing Congre≈øs of their unfeigned regard for the honor of the United States, and of their unremitted exertions to do all in their power to ≈øupport it. (The report is as follows.)

"The report of the committee to whom was referred the report of the committee of the late Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, appointed to confer with the honorable Mr. Monroe and Mr. King, read December 15th, was read the ≈øecond time, and adopted as follows, viz.

"The committee, to whom was referred the report of a committee of the late Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, appointed to confer with the honorable Delegates on their mi≈ø≈øion from Congre≈øs, beg leave to report‚Äî
"That they have examined the object of the ≈øaid report with the attention due to its importance:

"That they cannot help con≈øidering the debt of the United States in one aggregate point of view, and are of opinion that the principles of ju≈øtice require like payment of every part, whether the ≈øame be due to foreigners or citizens:
"That there appears to have been due to the citizens of this commonwealth a ≈øum which ≈øhe has undertaken to pay them, and which probably amounts nearly to her proportion of the whole debt.

"That the appropriation of funds for that purpo≈øe is of ≈øuch nature, that the report now referred to your committee (and which was adopted by the la≈øt A≈ø≈øembly) declares, "an immediate compliance with the recommendation would involve a breach of the faith of this ≈øtate, pledged to the public creditors, citizens thereof, unle≈øs at the ≈øame time ≈øome further and other funds were provided for payment of the intere≈øt due and which ≈øhall become due to them:"
"That in the opinion of your committee, the magnitude of the appropriation ju≈øt mentioned renders the provi≈øion alluded to in the report impracticable.

"That in the opinion of your committee, it would

Could any doubt exi≈øt re≈øpecting the con≈øtruction of the 13th ≈øection, it mu≈øt be removed by the 18th, page 97, which con≈øidering all certificates ≈øituated like the New-Loans, as ≈øub≈øcribable under the 13th ≈øection makes the nece≈ø≈øary regulations to prevent any inconvenience that might otherwi≈øe en≈øue.

The Secretary of the Trea≈øury in his in≈øtructions to Mr. Smith the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans for this State, declares they are ≈øub≈øcribable, and directs arrangements in con≈øequence. In his letters to Mr. Smith, he con≈øtantly con≈øiders them ≈øub≈øcribable. If an inconvenience were to ari≈øe to the State in con≈øequence of their ≈øub≈øcription, this would not de≈øtroy their ≈øub≈øcribability. That ari≈øes from the a≈ø≈øumption of Congre≈øs and not from any arrangement of the State. The loan is opened to the State creditors and the con≈øent or refu≈øal of the State has no concern with it. Congre≈øs may a≈ø≈øume what debts they plea≈øe, and the creditor may transfer to them all debts of a transferrable nature. This is a matter entirely between Congre≈øs and the
creditor in which the State cannot interfere more than in the transfer from citizen to citizen. In the ≈øettlement of accounts between the United States and this ≈øtate, the intere≈øt commences, and either party may allow or reject ≈øuch items as are improper, but this can have no effect upon the original a≈ø≈øumption, which concerns merely Congre≈øs and the ≈øtate creditor.

One object in view by the a≈ø≈øumption was to withdraw the creditor, from the precarious and frequently inadequate relief of State provi≈øions. The≈øe creditors were certainly of this de≈øcription, and in no ca≈øe except in others ≈øimilarly circum≈øtanced could Congre≈øs a≈ø≈øume certificates with ≈øo much ≈øafety, as they had i≈ø≈øued for debts originally liquidated and adju≈øted by the United States.

I hope then it has been ≈øatisfactorily proved, that the New-Loans were in their fir≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhment State debt; placed on a permanent footing, and highly favoured; that their de≈øtruction was not de≈øigned by the Act of March 1789; that at ≈øucceeding periods they have been con≈øidered as State debt and ≈øub≈øcribable by the Legi≈ølature it≈øelf, of cour≈øe the ≈øub≈øcriptions made have been conformable to law.
We now come to the po≈øition which forms the e≈ø≈øence of the ≈øecond article, viz. that the New-Loans were not nor could in any way be contemplated as objects of redemption by the Act of April 1792.

This Act was de≈øigned to di≈øcharge the certificates of the State, and her other obligations which the public intere≈øt required and which it was now in the power of the State to perform. Our Legi≈ølature had always conceived it to be more advantageous to the State to redeem her certificates in the ca≈øes where ≈øhe had it in her power thro' the medium of the United States in preference to paying them off and making that payment a credit in her accounts with the Union. By the fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcription the State redeemed all the certificates that were ≈øub≈øcribed, and only paid in return that portion of intere≈øt which the United States did not, which payment was to continue only until the United States paid it. The difference in value between the certificates received and the money paid by the State in redemption, which was the only lo≈øs ≈øu≈øtained by this mode, (for if they were of equal value it would only amount to a mutual exchange of equal intere≈øts) was of le≈øs con≈øequence, than paying off the whole at once, and that payment remaining a dormant claim upon the Union, until the final adju≈øtment of accounts and provi≈øion for the balance ≈øhould call it into activity. Moreover upon ≈øtriking the balance of this account the State had no rea≈øon to pre≈øume that ≈øhe would be more favoured in the di≈øcharge of it, than the citizen creditors had been in the payment of their debts, but that certificates would i≈ø≈øue to her in the ≈øame proportions, they had already i≈ø≈øued to them. The Act therefore of April, 1792, after appropriating the 3 per cent. ≈øtock as a redeeming fund, and directing certain debts to be paid from the proceeds of the ≈øale; contemplates in the ≈øixth ≈øection a further provi≈øion to be made by Congre≈øs, and directs that all

This Act of April 1792 directing all certificates to be paid that were ≈øub≈øcribable of cour≈øe redeemed them. The New-Loans have already been proved to be ≈øub≈øcribable to this loan; and are therefore within the provi≈øions of this Act. That they came within the view of the Legi≈ølature at the time, and were de≈øigned to be redeemed, will appear from the following con≈øiderations. The Legi≈ølature knew they were in circulation. The exten≈øion of the fir≈øt loan was contemplated in this Act, as the mea≈øure mo≈øt probable, which they knew would include them. In fine, every argument that applies to prove the nece≈ø≈øity of redeeming any part of the public debt, applies with equal force in favor of the redemption of the New-Loans.

The third article charges him with not con≈øulting with the Governor, nor the Regi≈øter-General; nor di≈øcriminating the certificates on the ab≈øtracts, by which he declared them a≈ø≈øumable, nor on the certificate by which he declared them redeemable, by which means

Both loans were opened with the concurrence and approbation of our Legi≈ølature, who promoted ≈øub≈øcriptions of ≈øtate debt by laws enacted for the purpo≈øe. After the clo≈øing of the loan; in all the conferences which took place on the ≈øubject of New-Loans, by the direction of the Governor, and which were reported to him, the defendant continues of the ≈øame opinion; no exception is made to its propriety, and all matters re≈øted in this way, till the opening of the ≈øecond loan.

Before the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of April 1792, the defendant oppo≈øed that plan of redemption and propo≈øed another to the Governor in which New-Loans are expre≈øsly provided for. With the form of the ab≈øtracts the defendant had no concern, That was ≈øettled by the officers of the United States. As all the certificates a≈ø≈øumable were equally ≈øo; there could be no occa≈øion to di≈øcriminate on the ab≈øtracts, their ≈øeveral kinds. There could have been no de≈øign in the defendant to conceal any circum≈øtance relating to the New-Loans from the Regi≈øter-General as they had had a conver≈øation on the ≈øubject, in the cour≈øe of which they both concurred in opinion that the New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable and redeemable, and the Regi≈øter-General afterwards pa≈ø≈øed the accounts knowing them to contain New-Loans.

His own ≈øub≈øcription being openly made in his own name, confutes the idea of any clande≈øtine de≈øign, and ≈øtrongly ≈øhews his thorough conviction of being right in his opinion. Had he ≈øuppo≈øed the contrary and wi≈øhed to deceive, how ea≈øy would it have been to divide the ≈øum into ≈ømall parcels, and procure other per≈øons to ≈øub≈øcribe for him in their own names. No checks of office have been broken. No official con≈øultation is required by law in any in≈øtance; nor can there legally, be any interference of the Governor

div.p: I HAVE the honor of being of coun≈øel for the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania who are the exclu≈øive Repre≈øentatives of the People of this State, and they found it their indi≈øpen≈øible duty to execute their con≈øtitutional right of bringing before the Senate, in this in≈øtance, the exclu≈øive Judges, a public officer who has long ≈øuperintended the finances of the State, under a ≈øerious charge.

div.head: FIRST ARTICLE
div.p: Was read by Mr. Rawle in a ≈øhort and abridged manner, retaining only the principal data, ≈øuch as facts, and dates; omitting the u≈øele≈øs appendages of amplification.

The general charges are thus opened with the ≈øtatement of a fact re≈øulting from the plain and obvious text of the law and finally reducible to this ≈øingle point: Whether there exi≈øted a Legi≈ølative power in the country.

body.p: "IN con≈øequence of the doubt, which you have ≈øugge≈øted, I am directed by the Governor to inform you, that when he a≈ø≈øented to the idea of the State debts being received on the ≈øales of ≈øtock, it was upon this principle, that it ≈øhould be con≈øidered and e≈øtimated as ca≈øh, at its nominal value; beyond which nominal value, and the rates in particular ca≈øes pre≈øcribed by the Act of A≈ø≈øembly, he is not authori≈øed, upon the redemption, nor, con≈øequently, through the medium of a commutation to liquidate the demands upon the public.

div.head: THE FOURTH ARTICLE.
div.p: This article charges the Comptroller-General with a breach of the Con≈øtitution, here no ≈øhelter can be found in the ambiguity or contradiction of the law, it is a direct violation of a ≈øingle clau≈øe in a plain and explicit in≈øtrument; accordingly the endeavour is not to oppo≈øe but to e≈øcape the charge.

A≈øtoni≈øhing to hear, that a warrant expre≈øsly to be paid out of a fund created by the Act of the 10th April 1792, and actually ≈øo paid by the Trea≈øurer, and ≈øo reported to the Legi≈ølature by the Governor‚Äîis to be protected from reprehen≈øion by quartering it on another fund previou≈øly appropriated by law to other objects, and altho' his warrants are expre≈øsly drawn and paid out of the fund provided by the Act of 10th April 1792, they were drawn out of the fund e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Act of the 7th April 1791‚Äîand not out of the fund provided by the Act of 10th April 1792.

By the Act of the 26th March 1789, ¬£.10,000 were ≈øet apart for claims and improvements; that this has always been con≈øidered a peculiar fund, and appropriated to tho≈øe ca≈øes which did not belong to any particular cla≈øs, and as ≈øuch I ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øentiments of the Comptroller-General upon it, in an official ≈øtatement under his own hand.

The≈øe claims (the defendant ob≈øerved) were likely to beget "improper applications," nothing in this provi≈øion relative to the Act of April 1791: No New-Loans could be redeemed under that law, nor any claim on that fund.
But an unexpected effort is made to defend, which requires further con≈øideration, the charge is, that he cau≈øed money to be drawn from the Trea≈øury without a previous appropriation by law.

Not a ≈øingle in≈øtance can be produced which will ≈øhew, that where a warrant has been drawn on a fund, to which it was not applicable, the ≈øame ≈øhould be paid out of the twelfth appropriation of the 7th April 1791. body.p: "WE have the honor to inclo≈øe a ≈øtatement of the certificates granted for unfunded depreciation debt, agreeably to Act of 4th April 1792, which have been i≈ø≈øued ≈øince the fir≈øt January 1793, and are, with, &c.

div.p: ‚òû The ≈øtatement con≈øi≈øted of ≈øix certificates amounting in the whole to ten thou≈øand five hundred and ≈øeventy-eight dollars and ten cents.

That the plan of finance (which ≈øee page 280) was not laid for others, when only ¬£.20,000 was e≈øtimated to be out, that he purcha≈øed to ≈øo great an amount, it mu≈øt be acknowledged that he was indu≈øtrious. That the Comptroller-General led the way is apparent; 1. Mr. Oldden a principal broker is at a lo≈øs to divine what u≈øe the defendant intended them for. 2. Mr. Boggs certifies New-Loans ro≈øe in price, and unable to know what for. But Me≈ø≈ørs. Evans, Hale and Stroud have been produced to prove that the New-Loan certificates have been taken back, after they were lodged for re-exchange. The la≈øt article is certainly of too ≈øerious and too plain a nature to be viewed with indifference.
