Lord Mansfield ob≈øerves, all evidence (Couper, 65,) is to be weighed according to what one party can produce, and is in the power of the other to contradict.

We are not to make te≈øtimony but to find it; if any imputation is thrown on Blair M'Clenachan, we did not ≈øelect him, but his te≈øtimony ≈øhould however have this effect, that it de≈øerves a better an≈øwer than hath been yet given to it by the Comptroller-General.

This impeachment hath not been precipitated, it is now almo≈øt twelve months ≈øince it commenced; the Comptroller-General has had full lei≈øure for the collection of official documents nece≈ø≈øary for him: Having already taken notice of a great part of his defence, it only remains to notice two circum≈øtances adduced by his coun≈øel.

1. His innocence is to be inferred from his open and avowed ≈øentiments at former periods relative to the nature of New-Loans; (Mr. Rawle then adverted to the Comptroller's letter, December 24, 1791, page 220-1-2, his letter to Mr. Hamilton, page 278, and his letter to Mr. Mifflin, page 223-4.)

It will not be pretended that he intended to mi≈ølead the Legi≈ølature or the Governor; and it will not be pretended that the nature of the ≈øtatement precluded the mention of the principal of the New-Loans: For, 1. It is an account of "claims," and he profe≈ø≈øes to have always con≈øidered this as a claim. 2. The principal of other claims was noticed by him, ≈øuch as funded and unfunded depreciation debt, pen≈øions, &c.

Yet while on this ≈øtrong ground, this important period of the 10th April 1792, it does not in all his corre≈øpondence appear that practical views, his avowed opinion, his morti≈øing and inlaying of New-Loans into the compo≈øition of the fund for redeeming State debts, ≈øo as to make all appear of one piece was ever communicated to any one; no intimation that the redemption
of New-Loans was practicable altho' that was the time to have avowed the ≈øentiment.
This was however (as Mr. Tilghman ≈øays) authori≈øed by the ≈øecret and avowed objects of ≈øpeculation.
2. That ≈øome of the Acts in que≈øtion, being lawful to others were lawful to the Comptroller-General.

This is important and attacks the ba≈øis of ≈øome of the articles of impeachment. I con≈øider it as applicable to his purcha≈øes of Oldden, and Biddle; his avowedly pur≈øuing what he profe≈ø≈øed to ≈øuppo≈øe the literal con≈øtruction of the law of April 10, 1792, in oppo≈øition to what he knew to be the meaning of the Legi≈ølature.
The intere≈øt of the commonwealth, the happine≈øs and ≈øucce≈øs of a republic depend on the de≈øtruction of this unworthy principle.

It is an axiom, nece≈ø≈øary for our pro≈øperity, and almo≈øt in≈øeparable from our exi≈øtence, that a public officer ≈øhould have no intere≈øt oppo≈øed to that of the public: Perverting public offices to private emolument was one of the principal cau≈øes of the downfall of one of the greate≈øt commonwealths in the world.

In the minutes of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives the following entry is recorded:

p.hi: Mr. Speaker, and Gentlemen of the Senate,

div.p: THE Senate of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania is called upon by the Con≈øtitution to execute one of their mo≈øt important functions, that is, A TRIAL BY IMPEACHMENT.

The Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives being the mo≈øt popular branch have exerci≈øed their juri≈ødiction in preferring the charges again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, the Comptroller-General: This important right devolves upon you, who≈øe part is the more difficult as you have to decide and are ≈øet as judges over this individual, your tribunal is the greate≈øt in the land; being thus con≈øtituted, you have to rea≈øon with capacity; the chain is compo≈øed of mixed bu≈øine≈øs, habits of intimacy, and principles of confidence between the two branches, and ≈øympathy for each other, a mere ≈øugge≈øtion of the danger is ≈øufficient to de≈øtroy the exi≈øtence of the danger.

Having premi≈øed this hint to you, his judges, permit me to ≈øay that the defendant has every thing that is valuable at ≈øtake, his reputation is at i≈ø≈øue by this accu≈øation; if rumour ≈øpread through every corner of the ≈øtate, if the public opinion, envenomed by prejudice, if reports of guilt and torrents of prejudice, rou≈øed and fomented by malice, and fo≈øtered by envy, are ≈øufficient to condemn a man, the defendant is already brought to judgment.

With regard to the fir≈øt of the≈øe qualities, it is evident they were i≈ø≈øued by Penn≈øylvania before the 1≈øt January 1790. And it is equally evident as to the ≈øecond. But it is ≈øaid, Suppo≈øe the Act were contrary to the Con≈øtitution, who ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øo‚Äîwhat judicature has authority to determine upon it? That point need not be much di≈øcu≈ø≈øed. But we are pre≈ø≈øed with the objection that this is to ≈øet the Judiciary above the Legi≈ølative. But this is by no means the ca≈øe. It only e≈øtabli≈øhes the preeminent authority of the people. It is ≈øaid that the people in ca≈øe of a violation of the Con≈øtitution have no remedy but another election. If this be true, there is no ≈øecurity that another election will be in their power. If this be true, the Legi≈ølature might have been ≈øpared the trouble and expence of an impeachment. To enforce his rea≈øoning on this point the gentleman added that he never heard that any power on earth had a right to adjudge a ca≈øe between a ≈øtate and its own citizens. I will dwell no longer on this ≈øubject. From our examination of it, it is equally evident that the New-Loans are ≈øtill a debt‚Äîand that the Legi≈ølature did not mean nor had the power to de≈øtroy it.

I now proceed to examine the other po≈øition contained in the fir≈øt article. They are, That John Nichol≈øon declared the≈øe certificates ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan of the United Sates, and that this was a mi≈ødemeanor. But no guilt re≈øults from this conduct, if it can be ju≈øtified or excu≈øed. We mean to do both, and contend, 1≈øt. That this debt was by law ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan. 2d. That if it was not, it was at lea≈øt his real opinion;‚Äîan opinion hone≈øtly entertained by him and many others.

New-Loans are within the de≈øcription of 13th ≈øection of the Act of Congre≈øs. Compare them with it. But it is ≈øaid it mu≈øt be a debt recogni≈øed by the ≈øtate. We an≈øwer, 1≈øt. That it never was di≈øclaimed by the ≈øtate; though unfunded, it was ≈øtill a debt undenied. 2d. To decline receiving certificates of a di≈øputed debt, was a proper rule in the Trea≈øury, as they had no power finally to decide on it; but their doubts or difficulties cannot affect the creditor's right. This a≈ø≈øumption by Congre≈øs was not made for the ≈øake of the ≈øtate but of the people. The hi≈øtory of the Act is well known. The amount of the Secratary's letter on this ≈øubject is, that the officers of the Trea≈øury, who are merely mini≈øterial, take a ≈øafe rule in receiving certificates on loan. But this does not preclude an enquiry. A man
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nus from the Supreme Court may be i≈ø≈øued to decide the que≈øtion; and if the certificates offered on loan, come within the de≈øcription of the Act, the Trea≈øury officers would be compelled to receive them.

Yet it may be remarked that he did ≈øo far decide upon it as to write to Mr. Smith the Loan-officer that he could not refu≈øe the New-Loans if the holders in≈øi≈øted on ≈øub≈øcribing them. (Mr. Bradford here commented upon ≈øeveral of the Secretary's letters which were read in evidence.)‚ÄîIt is true, that the certificates have been virtually rejected. The expre≈ø≈øion was a cautious one; but the rea≈øon of their being in this ≈øituation is, that Penn≈øylvania, who was the holder, took no ≈øteps to have them loaned, or the que≈øtion decided. The ≈øtate officers even de≈øired that they might not be received, and the opinion of the Attorney-General of the ≈øtate was, that they were not receivable.‚ÄîBe≈øides, in the late con≈øideration which the Secretary have to the Act of 1789, he ≈øays, that the circum≈øtances of its being pa≈ø≈øed after the ratification of the Federal Con≈øtitution did not occur to him.

Whether ≈øub≈øcribable or not, depends therefore wholly on the Acts of Congre≈øs.‚ÄîIt is evident, that the Act contemplates this very debt as a ≈øtate debt. The 18th ≈øection expre≈øsly provides for a difficulty which could ari≈øe in no other ca≈øe. (Here it was read and explained.) The very nature of the≈øe ≈øtate debts, was urged in Congre≈øs as a rea≈øon for the a≈ø≈øumption;‚Äîand there was a peculiar and evident propriety in a≈ø≈øuming them. But no difficulty was made on account of the Act of 1789. ‚ÄîIf the New-Loans were to be excluded, why not the ≈øame exception as that re≈øpecting the North Carolina certificates? Our delegates were as attentive to the intere≈øts of Penn≈øylvania as tho≈øe of other ≈øtates; and one of them was a member of the A≈ø≈øembly in 1789. The Act of Congre≈øs was not pa≈ø≈øed in a ha≈øty manner. It lay over a whole ≈øe≈ø≈øion a ‚Ä¢ d there ‚Ä¢ as time enough for con≈øideration.

But it is objected that this provi≈øo ≈øhews that the New-Loans could not be ≈øub≈øcribed becau≈øe the ≈øtate had authori≈øed no one to ≈øurrender the Continental certificates which were exchanged for them. To this two an≈øwers may be given and both of them ≈øatisfactory. 1≈øt. This debt was ≈øub≈øcribable under the general independent clau≈øe of the Act. But if a different con≈øtruction could be put upon the Act, is it ≈øo plain a point that the oppo≈øite opinion mu≈øt be imputed to di≈øhone≈øt motives and not to conviction of judgment? Is it a mi≈øtake, that can „Äà‚óä„Äâ expiated only by a political auto de ≈øe? The ≈øecond, third and fourth articles are ≈øo intimately connected that the whole may be reduced to this; that the defendant certified certain certificates to be redeemable which were not redeemable, with a corrupt and di≈øhone≈øt view.

The fir≈øt que≈øtion therefore is, Were the New-Loan certificates redeemable by the Act of the 10th April 1792? The article under con≈øideration declares that they were not; and on the ≈øoundne≈øs of this opinion all the re≈øt of the three articles depend.

The Senate will be plea≈øed to remember that we contend that whatever was ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan was made redeemable by that Act. We admit that they are not within the ≈øecond ≈øection of that Act; but they are manife≈øtly included in the ≈øixth. The words of that clau≈øe are remarkably ≈øtrong: "The holder or holders of any certificate ≈øub≈øcribable to the ≈øub≈øcription
≈øo to be renewed, ≈øhall be entitled," &c.‚ÄîHence ≈øub≈øcribability and redeemability became convertible terms. The Legi≈ølature put them≈øelves in the power of Congre≈øs. Whatever ≈øtate debts Congre≈øs ≈øhould chu≈øe to a≈ø≈øume, entitled the holder to the benefits of that Act. No other con≈øtruction can rationally be put upon this clau≈øe. But it has been urged that the ≈øixth ≈øection was not intended to include any debts not included in the ≈øecond.

Permit me here to remind this honorable body, that a mode of con≈øtruction has been introduced which is ≈øubver≈øive of all legal certainty as well as of per≈øonal ≈øafety. The danger of this has created doubts concerning the propriety of erecting ≈øuch a court for the trial of impeachment; and it has been made a great political que≈øtion whether one branch of the Legi≈ølature ≈øhould ever decide on charges exhibited by the other. But why do I dwell on this ≈øubject?‚ÄîI am ≈øpeaking to the Senate of Penn≈øylvania.

Judging therefore by the expre≈ø≈øion of the ≈øixth ≈øection, no doubt of the redeemability of the certificates could remain. But ≈øeveral objections are made to this; and they ≈øeem to be all contained in the report of the committee on that bu≈øine≈øs. The fir≈øt is, That no funds were provided by the Act for the redemption of the≈øe certificates. But the fallacy of their argument is proved by the ca≈øe of the Unfunded Depreciation certificates. That the Unfunded Depreciation were included was a general opinion. The Regi≈øter-General and Mr. Powel, the late re≈øpectable Speaker of the Senate, were the fir≈øt to put this con≈øtruction on the Act. To this day there is no di≈øapprobation of it,‚Äîno ≈øuit
brought;‚Äîand well, ‚Äîfor where is the court that would ≈øu≈øtain it?‚ÄîIf then Unfunded Depreciation are redeemable, ≈øo are New-Loan certificates.

But to do away the force of this, we are favored with the ≈øecret meaning of the author of the Act. Although we were in darkne≈øs before, now truly we are enlightened‚Äî the film is purged‚Äîa new ray of light breaks in upon us‚Äî and knowing what the drawer of the Act intended, we ≈øee as it were face to face!‚ÄîSin, if ≈øuch principles of con≈øtruction are to prevail in a criminal pre≈øecution, the will of a Turki≈øh Cadi would be as ≈øafe a rule of conduct as the laws of Penn≈øylvania‚ñ™

Secondly, It is urged that the ≈øixth ≈øection can only be regarded as a provi≈øo or exception to the ≈øecond. If the Legi≈ølature intended it as ≈øuch, how ea≈øy would it have been, to have added after "certificates? the word "herein before ≈øpecified." This would have confined its operation to the certificates mentioned in the ≈øecond ≈øection. But ≈øi voluit non dixit.‚ÄîThe ≈øixth ≈øection as it now ≈øtands is a di≈øtinct independant clau≈øe If it operates as ≈øuch on the Unfunded Depreciation, why not on the New-Loans? "Becau≈øe, ≈øay they, the≈øe are not a ≈øtate debt." Here we are thrown back upon the old que≈øtion.

But it has been hinted that whether in ≈øtrictne≈øs it were a debt or not, yet it was not ≈øo con≈øidered by the Legi≈ølature in 1792. What is the proof of this? Their Acts contain no ≈øuch thing‚Äîand if an appeal is made to the private opinions of the members, I repeat it, we

Thus it appears that none of the rea≈øons urged in ≈øupport of the con≈øtruction which the articles put upon the Act, will apply. We mu≈øt therefore re≈øort to the plain language of the Act. Sir, this eagerne≈øs to put a little profit by the rife and fall of ≈øtock into the pocket of the ≈øtate is di≈øreputable. Upon the whole it appears that the≈øe New-Loans were a debt‚Äîthat its exi≈øtence was not affected by the

Mr. BRADFORD in continuation.

p.hi: Mr. Speaker, and Gentlemen of the Senate,

div.p: Having, ye≈øterday, di≈øcu≈ø≈øed the legal po≈øitions contained in the fir≈øt and ≈øecond articles of impeachment, I am now prepared to examine the fact charged in tho≈øe articles. It is, That the defendant declared New-Loan certificates to be ≈øub≈øcribable and redeemable, and cau≈øed them to be redeemed, with corrupt views, and in wilful violation of his duty.

We have endeavoured to prove that he was right in his con≈øtruction of the law; but if it be admitted that he was wrong in that, ≈øtill he is excu≈øable, and no guilt is imputable to him, if his conduct flowed from conviction of judgment and not from corruption of heart. It is therefore of importance to ≈øift his conduct thoroughly, and to ≈øee what were his real opinions and motives. The que≈øtion then is, Did John Nichol≈øon act thus knowing or believing it to be wrong? I am willing to put the cau≈øe on this ≈øimple i≈ø≈øue without holding the oppo≈øite coun≈øel to the proof of all the aggravations charged in the articles. It may however be proper to take ≈øome ≈ølight notice of the≈øe, as they have been pre≈ø≈øed again≈øt the defendant.

To begin, then, with the fir≈øt article: It is ≈øtated that he declared the≈øe certificates ≈øub≈øcribable‚Äî" under colour of his office‚Äîand in violation of the confidence repo≈øed in him."‚ÄîIt appears that he made this certification in very few in≈øtances; and that this was done at the reque≈øt of Mr. Smith or of individuals, who wi≈øhed to
transfer or ≈øell their ab≈øtracts before the certificates due on them, would i≈ø≈øue from the Loan-office. This was an accommodation to tho≈øe who reque≈øted it, but it was not an official act. No Act of Congre≈øs nor of the ≈øtate, either required or forbid it. Mr. Nichol≈øon did not certify it officially; he did not affix his official ≈øignature; he merely ≈øub≈øcribed the initials of his name. This was not obligatory on the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans, nor did he ab≈øolutely depend upon it. It is in proof that he gave a receipt importing that the certificates were ≈øtill ≈øubject to examination; and in this examination he was directed by the Secretary of the Trea≈øury to depend on no one but him≈øelf and his own clerks.‚ÄîBeing therefore tru≈øted neither by the United States or the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania, re≈øpecting this matter, the defendant's conduct could be no violation of official duty. But to ≈øay "that if it was an official act it was a breach of duty and if it was not an official act, he exceeded his powers and thus violated the confidence repo≈øed in him" ‚Äîis a very convenient argument! This is to put the defendant on the bed of Procru≈øtes: If he is too long, lop him; if he is too ≈øhort, ≈øtretch him.

2d. It is charged that it was done "in order to promote his own emolument." This cannot be true, for he did not certify the certificates, pre≈øented by him≈øelf, to be a≈ø≈øumable; and in tho≈øe ca≈øes where he did certify, no emolument was or could have been in view. But this circum≈øtance of it≈øelf cannot aggravate the charge. To promote our own intere≈øt, is an hone≈øt end, if pur≈øued by hone≈øt means. If the certification was wilfully wrong, whether it was done for his own or another's emolument, he ought to ≈øuffer; nay, it would be inexcu≈øable to promote the greate≈øt charity on earth, by di≈øhone≈øt means.‚ÄîBut it will pre≈øently be ≈øeen that he acted hone≈øtly; and that he ≈øincerely believed what he certified to be true. It was an opinion which he entertained ≈øo early as the 30th September 1790 ‚Ä¢ efore the loan opened, and ≈øo late as December 1791, after it was clo≈øed.

3d. It is charged to be a "mi≈ødemeanor as contrary to the Act of 1789." We have already di≈øcu≈ø≈øed that point, and ≈øhewn that it was not contrary to that Act; but if it were, yet, if the heart was free it could he no mi≈ødemeanor.

4th. La≈øtly, it is ≈øaid to be manife≈øtly to the ri≈øk and injury of the commonwealth as he well knew. This is the point‚Äîthe ≈øting of the accu≈øation. If this be true, we do not a≈øk his acquittal; and I ha≈øten to ≈øhew he did not know or believe that he was injuring the commonwealth.

In taking a view of the defendant's conduct, I am led to notice the repre≈øentation that has been given of it by the gentlemen who preceded me. I acknowledge the beauty of the painting‚Äîthe ≈øtrength of the figures and the glowing elegance of the colouring; but I cannot perceive that a likene≈øs to the original has been at all regarded. It is, in truth, a fancy picture, which ≈øhews the ≈økill of the painter; but it is not a portrait, which exhibits the ju≈øt features of the cau≈øe. It may impo≈øe on an inattentive ob≈øerver; but I tru≈øt that ≈øo delu≈øive a repre≈øentation will have no effect on this court, to whom all the facts are di≈øtinctly known, and who will form their judgment from an impartial view of the whole.

That the conduct of the comptroller did not proceed from the di≈øhone≈øt motives will appear, fir≈øt. From its being founded on an early opinion‚Äîconceived at a time when no advantage could be derived from it‚Äîan opinion fortified by that of the mo≈øt re≈øpectable characters, and re≈øulting from a thorough view of the ≈øubject. Secondly. From all the circum≈øtances of the tran≈øaction which taken ≈øeperately or together evince the rectitude of his intentions.

The Senate will con≈øider that proof of his holding the≈øe opinions at a time when no private or intere≈øted views could po≈ø≈øibly actuate him, mu≈øt be deci≈øive. I will endeavor to trace the proofs of this in order of time.

(Mr. Bradford then went into a minute examination of the evidence, and to prove the early and continued opinion of Mr. Nichol≈øon that New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable, he made ≈øeveral ob≈øervations, 1≈øt. Upon the letter of the Comptroller 30th September 1790, p. 271-2. 2d. His letter to the Governor 24th December 1791. p. 220-1. 3d. His letter to Secretary Hamilton 29th December 1791, p. 227. 4th. Upon the conference between him and the Secretary, p. 288. 5th. His report to the Governor 29th December 1792, p. 223-4. 6th. His plan of finance and his ob≈øervations thereon, p. 284.)

Being ≈øatisfied that the≈øe certificates were ≈øub≈øcribable he could not avoid believing that they were redeemable, becau≈øe the≈øe were in fact convertible terms. As ≈øoon as the Bill or Act of 1792 was publi≈øhed for con≈øideration, he informed Mr. Evans of his opinion on this point, in which that gentleman concurred; and in a conference with Mr. Donnald≈øon and Mr. Gallatin, it was agreed by them all, that whatever certificates were ≈øub≈øcribable were al≈øo redeemable. Hence it follows, that Mr. Nichol≈øon's opinion of their being redeemable was not a new opinion but ≈øub≈øtantially the ≈øame with that which he had entertained long before, and at a time when no po≈ø≈øible intere≈øt could influence him.

Although he perceived ≈øo early as the middle of March that the New-Loans would, if the bill pa≈ø≈øed, become redeemable, he was ≈øo far from de≈øiring to avail him≈øelf of the advantages it pre≈øented, that we find him ≈øolicitous to prevent its pa≈ø≈øing into a law. He even remon≈øtrated again≈øt it to ≈øeveral members of A≈ø≈øembly; and declared that he thought the words comprehen≈øive enough to embrace bills of credit. But the repre≈øentations which he made to Mr. Gallatin and others were not attended to‚Äîthe Act was pa≈ø≈øed; and the door being opened, he had as good a right to enter as any other per≈øon.

From that time until June, when he certified ≈øome of the≈øe certificates to be a≈ø≈øumable, we have no proof
of his opinion on this ≈øubject being expre≈ø≈øed; but his conduct ≈øhews that it was firmly fixed;‚Äî≈øo firmly that he ri≈øked his property and reputation upon it. He purcha≈øed this ≈øpecies of certificates with a determination to ≈øub≈øcribe them; nay, to ≈øub≈øcribe them under circum≈øtances, which made the hopes of profit dependant upon the ≈øoundne≈øs of his opinion; for he affected no concealment, and if he had, it would have been unavailing. He knew al≈øo that if he was wrong in his con≈øtruction of the law, he would be expo≈øed to the lo≈øs of character.

In July, Mr. Donnald≈øon who had heard the opinion of New-Loans being ≈øub≈øcribable, circulated out of doors, con≈øulted the Comptroller about it. Mr. Nichol≈øon avowed the opinion, and ≈øatisfied the Regi≈øter-General of its ju≈øtne≈øs; and ≈øo fully that he did not think it nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øult any other officer, but pa≈ø≈øed the accounts and ab≈øtracts, although he knew them to comprehend New-Loans. He certified them to the Governor, and would have gone farther, if the warrants i≈ø≈øued upon them had not been ≈øtopped in his hands.‚Äî Why then is not the Regi≈øter included in the impeachment? Becau≈øe it is evident that he acted from conviction of judgment. Why not extend the ≈øame charity to the Comptroller; for it is not pretended that the under≈øtanding of the Regi≈øter is more cloudy or weak than that of Mr. Nichol≈øon.

La≈øtly, we find the Comptroller avowing the ≈øame opinion to the Secretary of the Commonwealth, who found him pa≈ø≈øing the account of Judge Addi≈øon which related to New-Loan certificates. His expre≈ø≈øion was, "I am ≈øure I am right, and that it is the regular con≈øtruction of the Act."

Thus it appears that long before as well as after the Act, he con≈øtantly avowed one unvaried opinion on this ≈øubject, and under circum≈øtances which prove that it could be no other than the re≈øult of a conviction of judgment.
Here it will be proper to notice a few objections.

1≈øt. It is ≈øaid, that the letter alledged to be written to the Governor on the 16th April 1792 did not include the New-Loans, and therefore that neither the Comptroller nor Regi≈øter con≈øidered them as redeemable.‚Äî Admitting that ≈øuch a letter was written, which is very doubtful on the evidence, it is ≈øaid to have been in con≈øequence of the requi≈øition of the Governor, who de≈øired a calculation might be made of the quantity of ≈øtock nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øold under the Act of 1792.‚ÄîThe calculation that was then made could only be founded on the 2d ≈øection, which did not include the New-Loans. The Act of Congre≈øs had not then pa≈ø≈øed; and the ≈øixth ≈øection of the law had then no operation, and it was therefore unnece≈ø≈øary to include the≈øe certificates in the calculation. For the ≈øame rea≈øon the Unfunded Depreciation were not included, although Me≈ø≈ørs. Gallatin, Donnald≈øon and Nichol≈øon concurred in opinion that they would be redeemable if Congre≈øs ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume them. Here, again, we may a≈øk, why do we acquit the Regi≈øter-General and not the Comptroller al≈øo?

Again: It was hinted, that whatever the language of the Act might have been, yet he knew the real intention of the Hou≈øe, which was explained to him by Mr. Gallatin. The an≈øwer is, that Mr. Gallatin could only give his own opinion; the intention of the Legi≈ølature is to be collected from the law; the Act ≈øpeaks for it≈øelf. Nothing more need be ≈øaid on this point.
From this review, the inference is clear, that the defendant was fully and hone≈øtly of opinion, that the≈øe certificates were both ≈øub≈øcribable and redeemable.

I have ≈øaid that this opinion was ≈øtrongly fortified by that of the mo≈øt re≈øpectable characters.‚ÄîIt is true this is no proof of his con≈øtruction of the law being right; but it forms a ≈øtrong ground of excu≈øe if he was mi≈øtaken, to ≈øhew that others were mi≈øtaken with him. If it was an error, it certainly was an error which had the appearance of truth.

Among tho≈øe who entertained this opinion we find the Secretary of the Trea≈øury, who≈øe di≈øcernment and
penetration will be doubted by no one. It was his duty to decide in the fir≈øt in≈øtance upon this que≈øtion. He had called upon the Loan-officer for all the laws relative to it, and he afterwards declared to him, "That the holders of the New-Loans have a right to ≈øub≈øcribe them; that he might endeavour to per≈øuade them to re-exchange their certificates, but if they per≈øi≈øted that he could not refu≈øe them." He intimates the ≈øame opinion to the Governor in his letter, 21≈øt December 1791, and the conference with the Comptroller was founded upon it. At this time, it is evident, he mu≈øt have examined the Act of 1789, though he does not recollect that it was before him; and if he afterwards di≈øtru≈øted his former opinion, he explained it by adding, that it did not occur to him that the Act of 1789 was pa≈ø≈øed after the ratification of the Federal Con≈øtitution.‚ÄîBut the que≈øtion is, What was the Secretary's opinion at the time he had the conference with the Comptroller, not, what it appears to be at pre≈øent?

The Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans entertained the ≈øame opinion of their ≈øub≈øcribability; ≈øo did Mr. Wolcot, as may be fairly inferred from his letter. The Governor al≈øo is officially apprized of the ≈øame opinion, and tho' he does not expre≈øs his concurrence, yet his conduct was founded on a belief that the Comptroller was right in his con≈øtruction of the law. Indeed it ≈øeemed ≈øo obvious a con≈øtruction, that few who examined the Act, doubted it. Almo≈øt all, whom he conver≈øed with, agreed with him. Mr Evans was convinced of the ≈øoundne≈øs of the opinion, and determined to adventure in a purcha≈øe of the≈øe certificates. Mr. Donnald≈øon was convinced, though not deluded. Of the ≈øame opinion were Mr. Boggs, Mr. David Rittenhou≈øe, Judge Addi≈øon and others. The la≈øt mentioned gentleman examined the Act which Mr. Dallas ≈øhewed to him in the Council-chamber, and he was ≈øo fully ≈øatisfied, that he received the amount of his certificates from Mr. Nichol≈øon, who advanced the money, in order to accommodate him.‚ÄîWhy then ≈øhould it be deemed criminal
in the Comptroller to yield his a≈ø≈øent to what convinced ≈øo many?

Second. The hone≈øty of his intentions appears from all the circum≈øtances of the tran≈øaction.‚ÄîIf he had been con≈øcious of any unju≈øtifiable views he would have attempted concealment; but his conduct was open and fair. He concealed nothing but what was proper to be concealed; and as ≈øoon as the ≈øub≈øcription was made he was carele≈øs who knew it.

In the fir≈øt place, it appears that he made the loan, and ≈øub≈øcribed in his own name. It would have been ea≈øy to have u≈øed another's, and to have concealed him≈øelf under the name of a friend. Again: He in≈øerted certificates in his ab≈øtract, which mu≈øt have di≈øcovered to the Regi≈øter-General and others, that they were New-Loans.‚ÄîThirdly. He did not attempt to hurry it through the offices. It lay there the u≈øual time and went through the u≈øual train of bu≈øine≈øs.‚ÄîBe≈øides, he knew that the ≈øub≈øcription of New-Loans mu≈øt be known not only to all the officers of the Trea≈øury of the United States, but al≈øo to the ≈øtate, when an arrangement for delivering up the Continental certificates became nece≈ø≈øary. He al≈øo certified the ab≈øtracts of others, who had no motives for concealment and would no doubt mention the tran≈øaction. In this ca≈øe, if his con≈øtruction of the law was not tenable, he would be obliged to refund. The clum≈øy fraud, if it had been a fraud, could not fail of being detected, and if it were detected, his hopes would be blown up, and mu≈øt have proved fruitle≈øs.

To the in≈øinuation that all this was done for the purpo≈øe of getting money into his hands for a time, which he could not finally keep, I have nothing to ≈øay. His circum≈øtances were not ≈øo mi≈øerably dependant as to make this pitiful ≈øcheme po≈ø≈øible.‚ÄîIn ≈øhort, he mu≈øt have been de≈øtitute of common ≈øen≈øe if he had acted thus openly and incautiou≈øly, without a perfect conviction that he was legally as well as morally right.
I ≈øhall now di≈ømi≈øs the fir≈øt and ≈øecond articles, and proceed briefly to examine the third and fourth.

I con≈øider the third article as a mere ≈øtatement of evidence, and if the two former articles cannot be ≈øupported, neither can this, which is urged to prove his corrupt views and his endeavours to avoid di≈øcovery and detection. For this purpo≈øe it is charged, 1. That he did not con≈øult the Regi≈øter. To this the an≈øwer is plain, that no law obliged him to con≈øult that officer; and why ≈øhould he have con≈øulted him when he had no doubts on the ≈øubject? Be≈øides, it was unnece≈ø≈øary; for ≈øoon after the law pa≈ø≈øed, he and the Regi≈øter ≈øettled the principle, that whatever was ≈øub≈øcribable was redeemable.‚ÄîAgain: It is ≈øaid, 2. That "he did not con≈øult the Governor;" and to this it has been replied, that the law directs him to con≈øult the Governor only in tho≈øe ca≈øes where the officers differ in opinion. It may be added that he did in fact appri≈øe the Governor of it when he informed him that the New-Loans were a ≈øub≈øcribable debt.‚ÄîIt is charged, 3. "That he did not di≈øcriminate in his certification nor in his accounts," &c. As to this certification to the Loan-officer, it was not an official act, and the ≈øtate has nothing to do with the form of it; and as to the account rai≈øed and tran≈ømitted to the Governor, it is a deci≈øive an≈øwer that they were rendered in the manner which had been ≈øettled in April 1791. The≈øe accounts originated in the Regi≈øter-General's office and were ≈øent up to the Comptroller merely for concurrence. Yet the purity of the Regi≈øter's views is not impeached, nor is he included in the accu≈øation.

But, Sir, the ab≈øurdity of the charge is evident, for this conduct could not have been adopted for the purpo≈øe or avoiding detection, becau≈øe the ≈øpecies or certificates contained in the ab≈øtracts were di≈øcoverable from the ab≈øtracts them≈øelves: 1. By the different dates of intere≈øt. And, 2. By the reduction of the principal ≈øum, which took place in no other ≈øtate certificates.

La≈øtly, it is ≈øaid that the checks of office were thereby de≈øtroyed. What checks are there pointed out by law or former u≈øage, which have not been ob≈øerved? There are none; and the Regi≈øter-General, even after he was informed that the ab≈øtracts comprehended New-Loans, pur≈øued the ≈øame method as before. There are no grounds for this flim≈øy charge, which ≈øeems to be thrown in merely to ≈øwell the account! (Mr. B. made ≈øome further ob≈øervations on the evidence, and then proceeded to the fourth article.)

The fourth article depends upon the third‚Äî"In the above delu≈øive manner," &c.‚ÄîIt is but another mode of ≈øtating the ≈øame thing.‚ÄîIf he be acquitted of the third charge, he cannot be convicted of this.‚ÄîThe article goes on and ≈øays, that "he certified that the New-Loans were redeemable and payable." He had a right to do ≈øo, if by law they were redeemable‚Äîhe is excu≈øable in doing ≈øo, if he really thought them to be redeemable.‚ÄîAs to the funds, the Act of 1792 is not referred to, but that of April 1791. (Mr. B. then made ≈øome ob≈øervations on this Act to ≈øhew that this fund for claims might be applied to the redemption of the New-Loans.) There was no other fund than this for the redemption of the Unfunded Depreciation. Yet the Governor did not ≈øcruple to i≈ø≈øue warrants for the payment of the≈øe, though it was evident from the amount of the intere≈øt ≈øtated in the accounts that it could ari≈øe from that ≈øpecies of certificates only.

Here again I may be permitted to a≈øk, why is not the Regi≈øter-General included in the accu≈øation, ≈øince he joined in this certification to the Governor as well as the defendant? Since both acted alike, why this di≈øcrimination? I am per≈øuaded that both are equally innocent.

But I quit this article, which is of no importance if the defendant ≈øhould be convicted of the other charges ‚Äîand if he is acquitted of them, he cannot be affected by this.‚ÄîThey depend one upon the other, in a manner that reminds us of the Indian philo≈øophy. The
world, ≈øaid the Bramins, re≈øts upon the back of a great elephant‚Äîthe elephant on the back of a huge tortoi≈øe‚Äî and the tortoi≈øe on‚Äîthey did not know what. So the fourth article ≈øtands on the back of the third‚Äîthe third on the ≈øecond‚Äîthe ≈øecond on the fir≈øt‚Äîand the fir≈øt on ‚Äînothing at all.

We now come to charges of a different nature from tho≈øe which have hitherto pa≈ø≈øed in review before us. The fifth and ≈øixth articles are, however, ≈øub≈øtantially the ≈øame, and charge the defendant with availing him≈øelf of certain official advantages for the purpo≈øe of ≈øpeculating in certificates. To the fir≈øt of the≈øe we might have ≈øafely demurred, and admitting the fact, have relied on the law that it is not impeachable. But this would have heen u≈øele≈øs, ≈øince the Senate being judges both of law and fact, will acquit the defendant, unle≈øs the facts proved are the proper ≈øubject of legal pro≈øecution.

Permit me to remind the Senate that impeachments mu≈øt be founded on the breaches of exi≈øting laws. Indulgence may be ≈øhewn to the form, but none to the ≈øub≈øtance of the charge: And an impeachment cannot make that criminal here which would not be ≈øo before the ordinary tribunals of ju≈øtice. (Mr. Bradford here quoted 4 Black. Com. 256.2. H. P. C. 250, and Woodi≈øon's lectures.) Indeed the learned gentlemen, although one of them talks of "doing ≈øub≈øtantial ju≈øtice," will not openly contend that any thing is impeachable which is not ab≈øolutely illegal.

This honorable body therefore will recollect that they are not now to judge by the rules of expediency. That is the province of a Legi≈ølature not of a Court. Some things are lawful which many may think inexpedient; but while the citizen only exerci≈øes his rights, he is amenable only to the tribunal of public opinion. True liberty con≈øi≈øts in being always permitted to do that which the laws do not forbid; and a republican government has been well defined to be a government of laws and not of men. We are, therefore, not to di≈øcu≈øs
in this place the propriety or impropriety of the defendant's conduct; but its lawfulne≈øs or unlawfulne≈øs. We are not to enquire whether in any in≈øtance he has over≈øtepped the extreme delicacy of official conduct, but whether he hath overleaped the mounds of the law. Delicacy is one thing, crime is another; and we judge by very different rules re≈øpecting them. To mark the preci≈øe limits of the proper and the improper is the bu≈øine≈øs of critici≈øm and ta≈øte; and the deci≈øion will depend upon our education, habits, feelings and temper. ‚ÄîBut the law is the only ≈øtandard by which we can mea≈øure the conduct of a citizen criminally accu≈øed.

There are men of ≈øo ≈øoft a contexture, that far from in≈øi≈øting on their rights, they make the expedient the rule of their conduct. They will not even eat meat, if thereby they ≈øhould offend a weaker brother. They ≈øhrink like a ≈øen≈øitive plant from the touch of cen≈øure ‚Äîand their minds are accu≈øtomed to take the varying hue of public opinion. But men of more republican firmne≈øs will ≈øtand on their rights. They will judge for them≈øelves of the proper and improper; and relying with confidence on the conclu≈øions of their own minds, they are ≈øatisfied if they find the laws do not prohibit their conduct.‚ÄîJudging therefore by the≈øe principles, the defendant mu≈øt be acquitted; for what law made it unlawful for him to purcha≈øe certificates in the manner this article ≈øtates?‚ÄîWhether ≈øuch official advantages ≈øhall be allowed or not, is a matter of po≈øitive regulation. Some ≈øtates allow their officers to ≈øpeculate in articles, in which their official ≈øituation gives them manife≈øt advantages: Some forbid them; and the general government prohibits it more generally than the ≈øtates. Thus in Penn≈øylvania the auctioneers were allowed to purcha≈øe at their own auctions until l783, when it was forbidden. The officers of the Cu≈øtoms by the laws of the ≈øtate mght have traded; by tho≈øe of the United States they cannot. The Secretary of the Trea≈øury and even the clerks in the office cannot ≈øpeculate in certificate; but in all the department
of our Trea≈øury it is different. So the officers of our Land-office may deal with great advantage in land; and it is clearly lawful becau≈øe no Act forbids it.‚ÄîIf the conduct of any officer is in the opinion of the Executive manife≈øtly improper though not illegal, the remedy is by removal not by impeachment.

But in the ca≈øe before us there were no official advantages that de≈øerve any con≈øideration. He could have bought the≈øe certificates as conveniently at a brokers as from tho≈øe who came to the office; and a ≈ømall advance would have poured them into his hands. He is charged with purcha≈øing them of many; but only two in≈øtances of ≈øuch purcha≈øes are proved; that from Oldden and that from Biddle. If this be criminal, by what Act is it made ≈øo?‚ÄîHe has broken no law of the ≈øtate, and therefore no guilt is imputable to him.

We now proceed to the ≈øixth article, which is nothing more than the fifth new-vamped. It charges the ≈øame facts but ≈øuppo≈øes that the certificates bought were really the property of the ≈øtate. This legal po≈øition is wholly unfounded. Mr. Dexter ≈øtated the offer to exchange as an executed contract‚Äîand as a complete transfer of the certificates to the ≈øtate, before an actual exchange took place. But his rea≈øoning on this point is fallacious. The certificates were lodged merely for examination, and the indents, required to complete the exchange, were not offered. How then could they become the property of the commonwealth?

Let us bring this point to the touch-≈øtone of the law. Could the ≈øtate have ≈øued Mr. Oldden for the indents? No, for an option is given him only on condition of his payment of the indents. The Act of 1789 permits, but does not compel an exchange. Again: Could Biddle or Oldden have maintained a ≈øuit again≈øt the ≈øtate for the Continental certificates without an actual tender of the indents? Surely not; for it is ≈øettled, that where two concurrent acts are to be done at the ≈øame time, one party mu≈øt do all that on his part is to be done before he can maintain a ≈øuit again≈øt the other.‚Äî
The property therefore remained as before. The holders, who lodged them, might have wre≈øted them from the Comptroller in an action of trover; and they would have been liable in his hands, to the debts of the individual.

Be≈øides, it was the uninterrupted practice to re-deliver them, if required, after they had been lodged in the office. In proof of this we have the ca≈øes of Thomas Hale in 1791, Danniel Stroud in 1793 and Col. Porter.

If the gentlemen be right in their law, all the≈øe per≈øons were plundering the commonwealth, becau≈øe they took back their certificates‚Äîand yet they do not ≈øeem con≈øcious of any impropriety! But really this refinement on the charges is unworthy of a ≈øtate pro≈øecution!

It has been ≈øaid "that if the Comptroller delivered back the≈øe certificates to tho≈øe who lodged them, he was guilty of perfidy." Well Sir! the Comptroller officially informed the Governor that S. Mark had withdrawn his certificates and parted with them to others. Here is an avowal of "this perfidy" to the Executive Magi≈øtrate who is ≈øo far from di≈ømi≈ø≈øing or puni≈øhing the Comptroller that he does not expre≈øs any ≈øurprize at the information. If this be a crime you cannot convict the defendant without involving the Governor in a degree of the ≈øame guilt.
There being, therefore, no ground to ≈øay that certificates in that ≈øituation were the property of the ≈øtate, it follows that the 6th article does not differ from the fifth.

But we are told that re≈øpon≈øibility of officers is the great ≈øecurity of Republics. Sir, there is a re≈øpon≈øibility of character and a re≈øpon≈øibility of puni≈øhment. The former we will an≈øwer in another place; the latter ari≈øes only from a breach of the laws. Shew us then the Act of A≈ø≈øembly that we have broken; if there be none, ≈øhew us at lea≈øt ≈øome adjudged ca≈øe which makes ≈øuch kind of dealing a crime. If there be ≈øuch a ca≈øe, it will ≈øweep like the ≈øcythe of time; it will cut down
great and ≈ømall, and many fair and unblemi≈øhed characters will come within its reach and may be brought before this honorable court.
If there be circum≈øtances here that require further di≈øcu≈ø≈øion they ≈øhould be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed el≈øewhere. I wave any further enquiry‚Äîfor the Senate cannot decide upon them.

I ha≈øten to the la≈øt article‚Äîand rejoice that at length I ≈øee land. The amount of this is, that he plundered the ≈øtate‚Äîthat he filched from the ma≈øs of public property a certain certificate which had been exchanged with the commonwealth. If this be true, he mu≈øt be a wretch indeed! he would not de≈øerve the honor of an impeachment. Such a charge brought again≈øt any man ought to be well ≈øupported; but brought again≈øt a man of unblemi≈øhed character, the proof ought to be ≈øtrong indeed. It ought to be ≈øupported by a number of witne≈ø≈øes, or at the lea≈øt, by the lucid te≈øtimony of one man ≈øpeaking po≈øitively to the fact, on who≈øe memory and recollection the firme≈øt reliance might be placed. But what is the number of witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt the defendant?‚ÄîOne. What the impre≈ø≈øions on his memory? They re≈øemble the traces on the ≈øand of the ≈øea-≈øhore.

The charge is, That Mr. M'Clenachan exchanged this certificate with the ≈øtate,‚Äîand as it was afterwards ≈øub≈øcribed by the defendant‚Äîthe inference is that he embezzled it.‚ÄîIt mu≈øt therefore be fir≈øt proved ≈øatisfactorily that Mr. M'Clenachan did exchange it. Let us examine this.

It is probable that he had ≈øuch a certificate ≈øo late as September 1790;‚Äîand it is certain that Mr. Nichol≈øon had it in July 1792. He ≈øays he did not ≈øell it to Nichol≈øon; but whether he exchanged it or not he cannot tell, for he ≈øold to others. Such certificates as were un≈øold he carried to the Comptroller to be exchanged. When the witne≈øs cannot ≈øwear that he delivered the certificate in que≈øtion to the defendant, can you, gentlemen
upon your oaths ≈øay that he did? Here is not the ≈øhadow even of pre≈øumptive proof!

Even in the ca≈øe of a mi≈øerable felon indicted for larceny, it mu≈øt be fir≈øt proved that a larceny was committed, before he ≈øhall be put to make any defence. If the owner ≈øhould ≈øay, I cannot ≈øay it was ≈øtolen‚Äî" I had ≈øuch articles"‚Äî"I ≈øold to others."‚ÄîThe candor, of the Attorney-General would induce him to direct an acquittal. Principles e≈øtabli≈øhed for the ≈øafety of all mu≈øt not be violated. They require proof in this ca≈øe as well as in that ju≈øt ≈øtated: but Mr. M'Clenachan cannot recollect what became of the certificate in que≈øtion.

But it is ≈øaid altho' the evidence is not very per≈øpicuous yet it is ≈øufficient to oblige the defendant to ≈øhow how he came by it. No! They aver the fact. They cannot ≈øtir a ≈øtep till they have proved the exchange: But if any fact can be di≈øtinctly ≈øeen thro' the thick mi≈øt‚Äîthe palpable ob≈øcurity which the te≈øtimony of this witne≈øs has ≈øhed upon the tran≈øaction, I am ≈øure it is not the fact required. The witne≈øs will not ≈øwear that.

But it is urged "That if Mr. Nichol≈øon bought this certificate, it is capable of proof." Indeed! then if Mr. M'Clenachan exchanged it, it is al≈øo capable of proof. "But the latter kept no account of his certificates!" and what proof have we that the former did. Why, it is ≈øaid, he is a regular man‚Äîhe keeps a diary! I appeal to you gentlemen if that was fairly urged; ≈øince we offered to produce it and they would not ≈øuffer it to be read. But that was a diary of his official, not of his private, tran≈øactions. It commenced in March 1792. How then could it a≈ø≈øi≈øt us in tracing a certificate ≈øub≈øcribed to the loan which clo≈øed in 1791?

Again it is ≈øaid, "If the per≈øon exi≈øts upon earth who ≈øold it to the defendant he may be produced." At pre≈øent it is ≈øufficient to a≈øk, What if he does not exi≈øt upon earth? Who can keep his witne≈ø≈øes alive? In what a terrible ≈øituation would many be if ≈øuch modes of proof are to prevail. Thou≈øands would be unable
to trace the certificates they hone≈øtly bought. They pa≈øs from hand to hand. Often no note made of the ≈øeller's name or of the purcha≈øe. In ≈øuch ca≈øe your own oath will not be received; and a purcha≈øe of this kind will be incapable of proof.
The danger of obliging a defendant to produce ≈øuch proof even when there are ≈øtrong pre≈øumptions again≈øt him is con≈øiderable. What would Mr. Nichol≈øon have done, had Hans Hamilton been dead?

Once more it is ≈øaid that Mr. M'Clenachan delivered him many certificates. We an≈øwer that we bought many. The an≈øwer is equal to the proof.‚ÄîLa≈øtly, it was ≈øaid, "What other proof could be produced?" I reply, that they ought clearly and po≈øitively to prove the exchange or to forbear the charge. There is no extreme difficulty in making ≈øuch proof if ≈øuch were the fact.

This is a ≈øufficient an≈øwer at pre≈øent. The time may come when this matter ≈øhall be fully under≈øtood. Here, in a criminal pro≈øecution, it would not be proper for him to an≈øwer upon oath; but in the civil ≈øuit, he will ≈øubmit to interrogatories. They may prove his heart to the bottom and I tru≈øt they will find it hone≈øt.

But what is the manner in which the te≈øtimony on this article has been taken?‚ÄîThe longer I live the more I perceive the nece≈ø≈øity and advantage of viva voce te≈øtimony in criminal pro≈øecutions.‚ÄîHad the witne≈øs been examined openly before you, the doubt or the certainty with which he ≈øpoke would have evidently appeared. But when his an≈øwers are reduced to writing they appear to the be≈øt advantage, and we can only judge from the expre≈ø≈øion. Yet even this exhibits a recollection feeble and uncertain. Mr. M'Clenachan is known to be a man of the mo≈øt perfect integrity and uprightne≈øs. He will not ≈øwear what he does not remember; and in his examination the burden of the ≈øong is, I cannot recollect‚ÄîI cannot tell." (Mr. B. then read the an≈øwers to ≈øhew how very frequently the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions occurred.)

Can we then be ≈øure, even when he ≈øtates a fact, that he has not forgotten all the circum≈øtances attending it which ≈øerve to explain or qualify it? If every que≈øtion that leads to an explanation is an≈øwered with, "I cannot tell," or refu≈øed to be an≈øwered at all, what can we rely on? All that we can be ≈øure of is, that he carried a bundle of certificates to the Comptroller's office and left them with him, even without counting them, having, as he ≈øays, the mo≈øt unbounded confidence in Mr. Nichol≈øon's integrity. That the certificate in que≈øtion was one of them, we have not the ≈øhadow of proof.‚Äî Shall the defendant then be convicted on ≈øuch flim≈øy evidence‚Äîthe imperfect te≈øtimony of an unrecollecting individual? There is no proof of the exchange‚Äî there is not even a probability‚Äîthere is a bare po≈ø≈øibility. Even that po≈ø≈øibility is an≈øwered by our producing the ab≈øtracts of the certificates exchanged by Mr. M'Clenachan. In the≈øe, the certificate in que≈øtion does not appear.‚ÄîWe might therefore venture to ≈øay that it is not po≈ø≈øible.
Again≈øt ≈øuch evidence a ≈øimple denial of the charge is enough; but when it is aided by a fair fame and upright character, formed by a life of unblemi≈øhed integrity, every ≈øu≈øpicion vani≈øhes.

When I ≈øpeak of character, I mean the reputation he enjoyed before the jealou≈øies and cruel ≈øu≈øpicions which the manner of conducting this bu≈øine≈øs has excited again≈øt him, exi≈øted. The≈øe however will not injure him here. We call no witne≈ø≈øes to prove his character becau≈øe it is well known. I appeal then to you, gentlemen, who have per≈øonally known him‚Äîto you who have known him long‚Äîto you who have known him intimately‚Äî who have looked as it were into his bo≈øom and ≈øeen the bottom of his heart‚ÄîI a≈øk you, if ye have not always found him an upright citizen‚Äîan hone≈øt man! Put this into the ≈øcale again≈øt that which is charged with the the accu≈øation‚Äîand ye will find that the proof again≈øt him is as du≈øt upon the balance.

Here then let us pau≈øe; and from this point as from the eminence of truth, look back upon the field over which we have travelled. Where are the traces of this "fraud, di≈øhonour and perfidy," which have been ≈øo freely charged? Where are the "≈øpoils of his country" with which he has been loaded? Where do we perceive the arts, the tricks, the deceit, the undue concealment of which we have heard? Where is the peculation charged? Where the delu≈øions by which he accompli≈øhed it? I ≈øee them not; they exi≈øt only in the creative imagination of the ≈øpeaker (Mr. Dexter) not in the evidence. I ≈øee a conduct open, but firm, and founded on the ba≈øis of the law. I ≈øee an hone≈øt mind acting from conviction of judgment: I ≈øee him exerci≈øing the rights of an independant citizen, and finally facing this accu≈øation with that intrepidity which is the characteri≈øtic of innocence.

We rely therefore with confidence upon your ju≈øtice:‚Äîthat we ≈øhall be judged, not by opinion but by the law and the te≈øtimony; not by reports circulated out of doors, but by the te≈øtimony given here in court.

We feel not the weight of the accu≈øation; but we cannot be in≈øen≈øible to that of our accu≈øers.‚ÄîThe accu≈øation of the Repre≈øentatives of Penn≈øylvania, cannot but in≈øpire prejudice. To prevent the effects of that prejudice, the Con≈øtitution contemplated this honorable Court, and placed the accu≈øed ≈øafe under the independence and magnanimity of this high tribunal; a tribunal, ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øuperior to that awe which the mo≈øt numerous and influential branch of the Legi≈ølature might otherwi≈øe in≈øpire.

As this is the fir≈øt impeachment, we are now to make an experiment intere≈øting to republican government. We are to ≈øee if the citizen is as ≈øafe here as before the ordinary tribunals of ju≈øtice. It is to decide, whether one order of the repre≈øentatives may ≈øafely be the judge when the other is the accu≈øer; and whether under any circum≈øtances it be advi≈øable to depart from a trial by a jury of our peers.‚ÄîAs for us, we have no doubt but
that this Judicial authority is ≈øafely depo≈øited. We have no doubt but you will weigh with caution and decide with firmne≈øs‚Äîthat your ears will be open to the voice of truth but deaf to the clamours of ≈øu≈øpicion. So doing, Mr. Speaker, may you and this honorable Court receive that be≈øt of all rewards, the approbation of your own con≈øciences. Adjourned.

div.p: Mr. WILCOCKS ro≈øe, and ≈øpoke as follows‚Äî

p.hi: Mr. Speaker, and Gentlemen of the Senate,

div.p:
I COME forward before you, engaged by the committee of managers of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives to conduct this cau≈øe; I come forward to ≈øupport the charges
again≈øt the Comptroller-General of the ≈øtate of Penn≈øylvania. This cau≈øe is very important in it≈øelf, from the nature of the charges, the high authority of the tribunal, and the intere≈øt of the party. I tru≈øt neverthele≈øs that this la≈øt con≈øideration will not influence the tribunal, but that if ≈øtrong ample evidence be produced, the conviction of the defendant will be the con≈øequence, public ju≈øtice require that a meritorious and innocent per≈øon who ≈øhould receive an injury ≈øhould be acquitted: The ≈øame principles demand the puni≈øhment of the guilty, as an acquittal in the re≈øpect would be improper. If the Comptroller-General ≈øhall be found infringing the laws of his county, the weight of re≈øpectability will not, it is to be expected, ≈øupply the want of evidence.

Such State pro≈øecutions can only exi≈øt in free governments. It is therefore wi≈øely and judiciou≈øly interwoven in the Con≈øtitution of Penn≈øylvania, it is the duc ‚Ä¢ of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives to impeach; it is the bu≈øine≈øs of the Senate to try the impeachment.

We find the ≈øame Con≈øtitution denies the Supreme Executive the power of pardoning. The Senate in ca≈øes of conviction is therefore in ≈øome degree ve≈øted with a di≈øcretionary power to puni≈øh. The ≈øame Con≈øtitution has certain limits which cannot be pa≈ø≈øed‚ñ™ but within the extremities of it are certain di≈øcretionary powers. The puni≈øhment of the officer ≈øhould be proportionate to the nature of the offence or mi≈ødemeanor. What if an officer is found unworthy of confidence and unfit to ≈øerve his country? In the fir≈øt place he can be removed from office; in the next place; if it it is deemed proper, he may be rendered incapable to hold any office of profit or tru≈øt during life. (Mr. Wilcocks then read the article in the Con≈øtitution re≈øpecting impeachments, ≈øee page 210 of this.)

Thus we ≈øee limits which cannot be pa≈ø≈øed, but within the≈øe limits are di≈øcretionary powers according to the different degrees of offences; the Senate has full power to exerci≈øe the ≈øevere or linient kind.

This cau≈øe hath been ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lly and repeatedly travelled ever, I feel repugnance at taking up ≈øo much of your time, as the going over it again would require. I will however endeavour to touch on the merits of the principal parts, and will confine my≈øelf to tho≈øe points mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentially connected with the pro≈øecution.

The two fir≈øt articles can be con≈øidered in one point of view; the ≈øeveral Acts of Congre≈øs and A≈ø≈øembly to which each of the≈øe articles refers, makes it proper to cla≈øs them together, as the ob≈øervations and rea≈øonings will bring them into one point of view at the ≈øame time (He then read the ≈øub≈øtance of the two fir≈øt articles.)

As to the facts contained in the≈øe two articles, they are plainly proved, or openly acknowledged and avowed. It appears from an in≈øpection of all the ab≈øtracts except his own large one, that they are certified to be genuine and a≈ø≈øumable in the hand writing of the Comptroller-General. It hath been remarked on by every gentleman engaged as coun≈øel for the defendant, but not much relied on, that his own ab≈øtract was not certified genuine and a≈ø≈øumable; I am clearly of opinion, that it need not be much relied on; for if one ≈øingle in≈øtance can be proved, in which he criminally certified New-loan certificates to be genuine and a≈ø≈øumable, it is ≈øufficient to ≈øupport the charges.

They ≈øay he certified none of his own ab≈øtracts. When the circum≈øtances come to be con≈øidered, all his ab≈øtracts are in his own hand-writing, and contain all the information to the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans that he could de≈øire. Advert to the two fir≈øt articles, he is not charged that he certified on the face of the ab≈øtracts; but he is charged with recognizing, certifying and declaring New-Loans genuine and a≈ø≈øumable, If there is any ≈øpecies of common law proof, that he certified to the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans, it is ≈øufficient to ≈øupport the charges; then why will it not appear as well from the ab≈øtracts being made out in his own hand-writing. He was early called upon by Thomas Smith, the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans, for checks to prevent counterfeits and impo≈øition;
Mr. Nichol≈øon ≈øends two certificates to him (≈øee letters page 271-2.) What can be more ≈øatisfactorily proven, than that the commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans thought them a≈ø≈øumable, when the ab≈øtracts appeared in his own hand-writing?

With regard to the certification to the Governor (≈øee letter, page 356) it was certainly official. This will not be di≈øputed here as it hath been el≈øewhere, where they contend that he certified as John Nichol≈øon, and not as Comptroller-General. If neither the laws of the Union, or of Penn≈øylvania enjoined it on him, this is a very ≈øingular and ≈øtrange doctrine indeed!

In thus certifying it is very true, that he acted in his official capacity. Nineteen twentieths of the agency of the public officers ace not pre≈øcribed by law, ≈øo in the departments of the Land-office, Finance or any others, there are various in≈øtances in all of them to be di≈øcovered, which are not particularly mentioned in the laws; the Acts generally point out only the outlines of the different offices. To act contrary to the cour≈øe of the offices, or to devi≈øe ways and means in oppo≈øition to the rotine of the offices, are offences again≈øt the≈øe Acts, equally obvious as if ≈øpecially and expre≈øsly pointed out by law.

Independently, therefore, the Comptroller-General could not act in any other than in his official character. The commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania was deeply intere≈øted in that Act; ≈øhe wi≈øhed to act fairly and ≈øecurely with the United States. If the law is not expre≈ø≈øive enough, ≈øhall nothing be done? Every officer was to act according to the duties of his re≈øpective department and when called upon to act with zeal in his official capacity.

We therefore find Penn≈øylvania deeply intere≈øted in the due execution of the Act of the 10th of April 1792, which made redeemable the debts which were ≈øub≈øcribable. It was of great con≈øequence to Penn≈øylvania that none ≈øhould be improperly ≈øub≈øcribed.

How can the Comptroller-General deny his official agency? That officer and the Regi≈øter-General, in their joint communication to the Governor (≈øee letter, page 217, 218) are conclu≈øive on this head, wherein they point out the mode of conducting this bu≈øine≈øs with the Commi≈ø≈øioner of Loans: "Examine the ≈øame as to their being genuine certificates and a≈ø≈øumable," &c.
How then can the Comptroller-General ≈øay, that he was not acting in his official department?

I now come to the con≈øideration of the que≈øtion, whether the New-Loans were ≈øub≈øcribable as State debts to the loan opened by the Act of Congre≈øs of the 4th of Augu≈øt 1790. It hath ever been impre≈ø≈øed on my mind, that independent of the Act of Penn≈øylvania of the 27th March 1789, New-Loans were not ≈øub≈øcribable to the loan of Congre≈øs.

After the adoption of the pre≈øent Con≈øtitution, Congre≈øs found her≈øelf ea≈øy in her ≈øituation and perfectly competent to the ≈øatisfying all her dome≈øtic debt; and then contemplated the ≈øituation of the different ≈øtates; among them ≈øhe ≈øaw a number of individuals labouring under debts created by the war; ≈øhe contemplated the taking of ≈øuch, as in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, the United States were not ≈øubject to be called upon, nor liable to a demand on them. This was the motive the General Government had for opening the loan.

The gentlemen have mentioned the de≈øcription of State Debts receivable in this loan, and then a≈øk if the New-Loans are not comprehended under this de≈øcription! It is true they are, but tho≈øe are not the only prerequi≈øites; for in the ≈øame ≈øection we find, they mu≈øt be i≈ø≈øued for ≈øervices or ≈øupplies: The≈øe were the e≈ø≈øential requi≈øites, and the New-Loans being only granted for others, they could not be within the meaning of the Act.

Now, ≈øuppo≈øe for a moment that the New-Loans were receivable, what would be the effect? Penn≈øylvania was to have the benefit of ≈øub≈øcribing 2,200,000 dollars; nay, let us ≈øuppo≈øe twice the ≈øum if you plea≈øe,
for there was then near twice the ≈øum out, the ≈øub≈øcription of the New-Loans would exclude the proper State debt of Penn≈øylvania. This would burthen the commonwealth, which the law was de≈øigned to a≈ø≈øi≈øt. How would Penn≈øylvania be ca≈øed then? Her condition would not be meliorated, for New-Loans are in effect no more than Continental certificates, only in another name.

The 18th ≈øection of the law of Congre≈øs was introduced not to invite the New-Loan holders to ≈øub≈øcribe, but from an apprehen≈øion that they would be offered, and to guard again≈øt the con≈øequences. This clau≈øe (18th ≈øection) hath been, and I ≈øuppo≈øe will again be urged, that the≈øe New-Loan certificates will be received. They might by po≈ø≈øibility, or by mi≈øtake be ≈øub≈øcribed, but then all intere≈øt is to cea≈øe until the Continental certificates be delivered up. Can it be ≈øuppo≈øed that Congre≈øs would a≈ø≈øume them, when double intere≈øt might have been paid on the ≈øame ≈øum?

New-Loans were never a money debt of Penn≈øylvania, neither were they ≈øub≈øcribable or redeemable under her laws. The con≈øideration of this part leads me to think that Congre≈øs never meant to include them in the a≈ø≈øumption.
But a more important que≈øtion ari≈øes, that is, Can they be contemplated as ≈øub≈øcribable after the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of 1789?
I apprehend New-Loans were never a money debt to be paid on or before the year 1796. This will appear from the Act of 1786.

The New-Loan was a certificate of a contract or engagement between the commonwealth and the public creditors, her citizens. The intent of which was that Penn≈øylvania engaged to pay the intere≈øt half yearly, and the creditor pledged with her his certificate as a ≈øecurity, the provi≈øion was intended as a temporary relief, and to continue until Congre≈øs ≈øhould be able to di≈øcharge her own engagements, and then if Penn≈øylvania cho≈øe ≈øhe might authori≈øe an exchange of New-Loans
for Continental certificates, and the public creditors have re≈øort to Congre≈øs.

Our attention hath been called to the Act of December 18th, 1780, for the depreciation of the the pay of the army; and it is a≈øked, why ≈øhould not Penn≈øylvania a≈ø≈øume the one as well as the other? It was in order to ≈øhew when Penn≈øylvania contemplated a permanent debt ≈øhe knew how to di≈øtingui≈øh between the depreciation certificates and tho≈øe i≈ø≈øued in 1786. The depreciation certificates were i≈ø≈øued at the earne≈øt ≈øolicitation of Congre≈øs; this commonwealth agreed to a≈ø≈øume the depreciation certificates, Congre≈øs being unable to pay the debt, called upon the individual ≈øtates to pay it, promi≈øing at the ≈øame time, that they would repay them.

Here then, are circum≈øtances and inducements to do the one, and not the other. All ≈øhe did was to calculate the ≈øum due to each per≈øon for the depreciation of his pay in the army, the Act makes a provi≈øion for the redemption both of principal and intere≈øt, and re≈øerves the right of paying them off in ≈øpecie, or in any other current money equivalent.

I will now proceed to con≈øider the nature of New-Loan certificates. Previous to the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of 16th March 1785, it is obvious to the recollection of every per≈øon, that the war was then over, the Federal Confederation ≈øhewed it≈øelf inadequate to the purpo≈øes of good government; Congre≈øs had a great foreign and do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tic debt, and not able to call on the individual „Äà‚óä„Äâ for re≈øources and revenues. "THE pro≈øpect which has for ≈øome time exi≈øted, and which now is happily realized, of a ≈øucce≈øsful termination

Although the≈øe recommendations ≈øpeak them≈øelves the principles on which they are founded, as well as the ends which they propo≈øe, it will not be improper to enter into a few explanations and remarks, in order to place in a ≈øtronger view the nece≈ø≈øity of complying with them.

The fir≈øt mea≈øure recommended is, effectual provi≈øion for the debt of the U. S. The amount of the≈øe debts, as far as they can now be a≈øcertained, is 42,000,375 dollars, as will appear by the ≈øchedule No. 1. The amount of the annual intere≈øt, as will appear by the paper la≈øt referred to, is computed to be 2,415,956 dollars. "In devi≈øing the≈øe funds Congre≈øs did not overlook the mode of ≈øupplying the common Trea≈øury, provided by the articles of Confederation; but after the mo≈øt re≈øpectful con≈øideration of that mode, they were con≈øtrained to regard it as inadequate and inapplicable to the form into which the public debt mu≈øt be thrown. The delays and uncertainties incident to a revenue to be e≈øtabli≈øhed and collected form time to time by thirteen independent authorities, is at fir≈øt view irreconcileable
with the punctuality e≈ø≈øential in the di≈øcharge of the intere≈øt of a national debt‚ñ™ Our own experience after making every allowance for tran≈øient impediments, has been a ≈øufficient illu≈øtration of this truth. Some departure, therefore, in the recommendations of Congre≈øs, from the Federal Con≈øtitution, was unavoidable; but it will be found to be as ≈ømall as could be reconciled with the object in view, and to be ≈øupported be≈øides by ≈øolid con≈øiderations of intere≈øt and ≈øound policy.

"The fund which fir≈øt pre≈øented it≈øelf on this, as it did on a former occa≈øion, was a tax on imports. The rea≈øons which recommended this branch of revenue, have heretofore been ≈øtated in an Act, of which a copy, No. 2, is now forwarded, and need not be here repeated. It will ≈øuffice to recapitulate, that taxes on con≈øumption are always lea≈øt burden≈øome, becau≈øe they are lea≈øt felt, and are borne too, by tho≈øe who are both willing and able to pay them; that, of all taxes on con≈øumption, tho≈øe on foreign commerce are mo≈øt compatible with the genius and policy of free ≈øtates; that from the relative po≈øitions of ≈øome of the more commercial ≈øtates, it will be impo≈ø≈øible to bring this e≈ø≈øential re≈øource into u≈øe without a concerted uniformity; that this uniformity cannot be concerted through any channel ≈øo properly as through Congre≈øs, nor for any purpo≈øe ≈øo aptly as for paying the debts of a revolution, from which an unbounded freedom has accrued to commerce.

"In renewing this propo≈øition to the ≈øtates, we have not been unmindful to the objections which heretofore fru≈øtated the unanimous adoption of it. We have limited the duration of the revenue to the term of 25 years; and we have left to the ≈øtates them≈øelves the appointment of the officers who are to collect it. If the ≈øtrict maxims of national credit alone were to be con≈øulted, the revenue ought manife≈øtly to be con≈øi≈øtent with the object of it, and the collection placed in every re≈øpect under that authority which is to di≈øpen≈øe the former, and is re≈øpon≈øible for the latter. The≈øe relaxations
will, we tru≈øt, be regarded on one hand as the effect of a di≈øpo≈øition in Congre≈øs to attend at all times to the ≈øentiments of tho≈øe whom they ≈øerve, and on the other hand, as a proof of their anxious de≈øire that provi≈øion may be made in ≈øome way or other for an honorable and ju≈øt fulfilment of the engagements which they have formed.

"To render this fund as productive as po≈ø≈øible, and at the ≈øame time to narrow the room for collu≈øions and frauds, it has been judged an improvement of the plan, to recommend a liberal duty on ≈øuch articles as are mo≈øt ≈øu≈øceptible of a tax according to their quantity, and are of mo≈øt equal and general con≈øumption; leaving all other articles, as heretofore propo≈øed, to be taxed according to their value.

"The amount of this fund is computed to be 915,956 dollars. The e≈øtimates on which the computation is made, are detailed in paper No. 3. "The re≈øidue of the computed intere≈øt is 1,500,000 dollars, and is referred to the ≈øtates to be provided for by ≈øuch funds as they may judge mo≈øt convenient. Here again the ≈øtrict maxims of public credit gave way to the de≈øire of Congre≈øs to conform to the ≈øentiments of their con≈øtituents. "With a view to the re≈øource la≈øt mentioned, as well as to obviate di≈øagreeable controver≈øies and confu≈øions, Congre≈øs have included in their pre≈øent recommendations, a renewal of tho≈øe of the 6th day of September, and of the 10th day of October, 1780. "The la≈øt object recommended is, a con≈øtitutional change of the rule by which a partition of the common burdens is to be made. The expediency and even nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øuch a change, has been ≈øufficiently enforced by the local inju≈øtice and di≈øcontents which have proceeded from valuations of the ≈øoil in every ≈øtate where the experiment has been made.
