Legi≈ølature thought as he did in this re≈øpect; and that therefore, it would have been madne≈øs in the extreme for him, to object to what he him≈øelf propo≈øed in his own plan of finance, and which he not only highly approved of, but had every rea≈øon for ≈øuppo≈øing to be equally approved of by others.
I will not, Sir, attempt any further an≈øwer to this objection, le≈øt in combating ≈øuch ground, I may be led into an intemperate warmth.

It is ≈øaid, Sir, that "The Governor could not have been of the opinion, that the New-Loan debt was redeemable at the Trea≈øury of Penn≈øylvania, or that it exi≈øted at all, ≈øince in none of his addre≈ø≈øes to the Legi≈ølature, one or more of which have been read, has he mentioned this debt to be provided for, although he has particularly enumerated all that were to be provided for." This argument, though much relied on, will be found to be altogether fallacious. The New-Loan debt was not redeemable at all, until the pa≈ø≈øing of the redemption law of the 10th of April 1792, nor then, unle≈øs the loan of the United States ≈øhould be again opened‚ÄîIt was not again opened until the 8th of May 1792, and of cour≈øe no provi≈øion for its redemption, could be required before that time. The addre≈ø≈øes which have been read, were all anterior to this period‚ÄîTheir object was to enumerate the amount of the debts which were redeemable, and of cour≈øe demandable at the Trea≈øury, and to call upon the Legi≈ølature, to furni≈øh the nece≈ø≈øary means; but as the New-Loan debt was not then redeemable nor demandable, at the Trea≈øury, it would have been ≈øtrange indeed, if our vigilant Governor, had ≈øo far forgotten him≈øelf, as to call for means to be provided, for redeeming a debt, which at that time was not redeemable at all!

Of a ≈øimilar nature is another objection which has been made; "That in no in≈øtance have the committee of ways and means propo≈øed any provi≈øion for the redemption of the New-Loan debt," from which it is inferred, that it had been aboli≈øhed, or if not aboli≈øhed,
that it was not redeemable." To this the an≈øwer mu≈øt certainly be ≈øatisfactory, that the reports of this committee were, like the addre≈ø≈øes of the Governor, made before the New-Loan debt was redeemable, and of cour≈øe the propo≈øing of ways and means for its redemption would have been folly in the extreme‚ÄîIt is the bu≈øine≈øs of that committee, as appears from its very name, to propo≈øe ways and means, for di≈øcharging ≈øuch debts as are redeemable, but it would be a great departure from its duty, to propo≈øe a law for any other purpo≈øe, unle≈øs under a particular reference from the Hou≈øe. It is the bu≈øine≈øs of that committee, to find out ways and ways for the redemption of funded debts, not unfunded ones!

Equally un≈øub≈øtantial is another objection, which has been made; namely, "That the defendant could not believe the New-Loan debt to be redeemable, becau≈øe his own ≈øtatement, made at, or ≈øoon after the pa≈ø≈øing of the Act of the 10th of April 1792, mentioned ≈øo ≈ømall a ≈øum, as a propo≈øed e≈øtimate, of what would be nece≈ø≈øary for the redemption of the public debts, as ≈øhews that it was not intended to provide for the di≈øcharge of the New-Loan debts." Nor was it; and this I freely admit, without allowing that there is any weight in the objection. The≈øe e≈øtimates bear date the 28th and 30th of April 1792 (page 224-5) and mention a "≈øum e≈øtimated to be nece≈ø≈øary for the redemption of the State debt, according to law." But the New-Loan debt was not redeemable until the 8th of May following, when the Act of Congre≈øs for opening the ≈øecond loan was pa≈øt, and therefore, when the≈øe e≈øtimates were made, the New-Loan debt was not payable "according to law," nor would it ever have been payable under the then exi≈øting laws, had that loan not again been opened. If this is not a complete an≈øwer to the objection, I hope the following one will be‚ÄîIt will be remembered that the ≈øecond ≈øection of the Act of the 10th of April 1792 provided for the payment of certain debts therein enumerated, and we have admitted that the New-Loan debt was not one of them, although it
was, as we ≈øay, within the provi≈øion of the ≈øixth ≈øection and eventually became payable under the 12th appropriation of the Act of April 1791. The 2d ≈øection of the Act of April 1792 provided funds for the debts enumerated in that ≈øection, and in order thereto, it enabled "The Comptroller-General and Regi≈øter-General, under the direction of the Governor, to fell ≈øo much of the three per cent. ≈øtock as ≈øhould be nece≈ø≈øary to pay and redeem the debt in that ≈øection mentioned." On the 13th of April 1792 (page 232) Mr. Dallas by order of the Governor, wrote to the Comptroller-General and Regi≈øter-General as follows‚Äî"The Legi≈ølature contemplates the payment of certain debts on the fir≈øt of July next, by the ≈øale of three per cent. ≈øtock, at a certain rate, with a power however, to ≈øu≈øpend the ≈øale until the ≈øtipulated price can be obtained, you will be plea≈øed therefore, to take that Act into immediate con≈øideration, and report what arrangements will be nece≈ø≈øary in your opinion, for carrying the redemption of the debt into effect."

The three per cent. ≈øtock was not directed to be ≈øold for the payment of the New-Loan debt, nor was provi≈øion made for the payment of that debt on the fir≈øt of July next, nor at all, unle≈øs the loan ≈øhould be again opened; the Governor could only call for an e≈øtimate of what would be nece≈ø≈øary to di≈øcharge the debts, which were payable on the fir≈øt of July; the e≈øtimate furni≈øhed was confined to that object, and could not be extended to any other; the three per cent. ≈øtock could not be ≈øold to ≈øatisfy any other object. When gentlemen are driven to ≈øuch objections as this, their ≈øituation mu≈øt be de≈øperate indeed!

Oh! but ≈øay the gentlemen, "The defendant did not inform Mr. Gallatin as he ought to have done, that the New-Loan debt was redeemable under the Act of April 1792." If I admit for a moment, that there was ≈øomething ≈øo peculiar in the character of Mr. Gallatin, as to entitle him to more information than
other members could ju≈øtly claim, let us ≈øee how well the objection is ≈øupported by facts.

We find Mr. Dallas's letter to the defendant of the 21≈øt of March 1792, that he found on con≈øulting Mr. Gallatin, and ≈øome other gentlemen on the defendant's plan, that it would not at that time meet with any chance of ≈øucce≈øs, "though its principles appeared to be good," Mr. Gallatin was therefore informed of the defendant's opinion while the bill for the redemption law was pending, and if he thought it wrong, he ought to have ≈øaid ≈øo, and guarded again≈øt it.‚ÄîLet us now ≈øee what took place after the law was pa≈ø≈øed?‚ÄîIt was pa≈ø≈øed as we have ≈øeen on the 10th of April 1792 ‚Äîthe Hou≈øe probably ro≈øe on that or the next day, as no law was pa≈ø≈øed after that day, in the ≈øame ≈øe≈ø≈øion; and as Mr. Gallatin tells us, that he remained in town but about eight or ten days after the ri≈øing of the Hou≈øe, the conver≈øation which I am about to mention, mu≈øt have taken place within that time‚ÄîIt is related by Mr. Donnald≈øon, who ≈øwears "That ≈øhortly after the Hou≈øe ro≈øe, Mr. Gallatin, the defendant and him≈øelf, had conver≈øation together, in which they all agreed, that the Act of the 10th of April 1792, embraced the Unfunded Depreciation debt, and the defendant then ≈øaid, it would extend to the old bills of credit if Congre≈øs ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume them, upon which Mr. Gallatin ≈øaid the 6th ≈øection was more exten≈øive than he had intended. And Mr. Gallatin tells us, that on reading the 6th ≈øection he agreed with the defendant in his con≈øtruction of it as to its including the Unfunded Depreciation debt‚ÄîIf this was ≈øo, it could not be a provi≈øo to the ≈øecond ≈øection, ≈øince it is admitted on both ≈øides, that that ≈øection does not include that debt; of cour≈øe we have here the opinion of Mr. Gallatin in our favour, be it of the importance or not, which upon another occa≈øion has been contended for. Mr. Gallatin does not at pre≈øent recollect any thing having been ≈øaid about the old bills of credit being redeemable, if Congre≈øs ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume them, but Mr. Donnald≈øon, who
≈øpeaks affirmatively, ≈øwears that the defendant did ≈øay, that they would be within the ≈øixth ≈øection if Congre≈øs ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume them, and that Mr. Gallatin then ≈øaid, the ≈øixth ≈øection was more exten≈øive than he had intended, which certainly looks very much like a≈ø≈øenting to what the defendant had ≈øaid‚ÄîMr. Donnald≈øon does not, it is true, remember, that the New-Loan debt was ≈øpoken of, and the defendant has been pretty ≈øeverely handled for not mentioning that al≈øo; but to this it may be an≈øwered, that Mr. Gallatin having heard of ≈øome objections to the Act, went to learn what they were, and to endeavour to obviate them‚ÄîThis being the ca≈øe, the defendant mentioned only ≈øuch things as he deemed exceptionable, and it would have been wonderful indeed, if he had mentioned as an objection to the Act, that it might eventually provide for the redemption of the New-Loan debt, when he him≈øelf had ju≈øt before propo≈øed a plan, which provided for its immediate redemption, and which he had every rea≈øon for believing, was approved of by the Governor and the members of both branches of the Legi≈ølature. To ≈øhew that he has been candid and uniform in every thing relative to this bu≈øine≈øs, it is but ju≈øtice to remember, that while the Act of April 1792 was depending before the Legi≈ølature, he thought it his duty to give it every decent oppo≈øition, and that he did ≈øo, by mentioning his objections in the fulle≈øt manner to many members of each branch of the Legi≈ølature, and more e≈øpecially as it would in its then form, if the re≈øolutions then under the con≈øideration of Congre≈øs had been adopted in their full extent, have put the ≈øtate in the power of the United States, by making her liable to redeem whatever Congre≈øs might chu≈øe to a≈ø≈øume. To prevent this, his plan enumerated the ≈øpecific articles of redemption, and ≈øurely nothing could be better calculated than this, to pre≈øerve the rights of the State, and to preclude all opportunity for ≈øpeculation‚ÄîTo the honorable Mr. Thomas be objected "to the bill as it ≈øtood, (page 287) becau≈øe it would admit of con≈øtructions
that would open a door for ≈øpeculation, and for ≈øpeculations injurious to the State." To the honorable Mr. Montgomery he mentioned nearly the ≈øame thing; (page 290) and if after this, the Legi≈ølature cho≈øe to leave the door open, every man had a right to enter at it, and none more ≈øo than he, who had advi≈øed that it ≈øhould be ≈øhut.
If the law left it open, the law gave a free pa≈ø≈øport of entrance to every man, and it is an affront to common ≈øen≈øe to ≈øuppo≈øe that for availing him≈øelf of it, any man can be puni≈øhable!

We are told, Sir, "That at all events the defendant was highly culpable for certifying to the Governor in favour of the holders of the old Unfunded Depreciation certificates, becau≈øe Mr. Gallatin had told him that it was not his intention when the law of April 1792 pa≈ø≈øed, that they ≈øhould be redeemable." Be it ≈øo; but if it is, what is the con≈øequence? Was the defendant to con≈øtrue the law agreeably to what a ≈øingle member of a ≈øingle branch told him was his meaning at the time, or according to what appeared on a view of the law, to have been the meaning of all the members of both branches and of the Governor! Mr. Gallatin's conduct, and where he happens to be right, I have no objection to quoting him, forms a ≈øufficient an≈øwer to this objection‚ÄîIt is in evidence, that he ≈øaid, he had not intended that the ≈øixth ≈øection of the Act of April 1792 ≈øhould be more exten≈øive than the ≈øecond ≈øection; but that on peru≈øing it, he found that it was, and that it included the Unfunded Depreciation certificates.‚ÄîHe al≈øo tells us, that finding this to be the ca≈øe, he procured the redemption of one for his friend Ephraim Dougla≈øs‚ÄîHe adds with much good ≈øen≈øe, that if he had known that agreeably to the true con≈øtruction of the law, the New-Loan debt was redeemable, he ≈øhould, let the intention of the Legi≈ølature be what it might, have done the be≈øt that he could for his friend‚ÄîAll this is pa≈øt over as perfectly innocent, ≈øo far as it re
‚Ä¢ ates to the conduct of one of the members of the Legi≈ølature,
who is the author, and the fautor of this pro≈øecution, and yet, the defendant is held up as a great criminal, for certifying to the Governor in favour of the holders of the old Unfunded Depreciation certificates, although that member, and the Regi≈øter-Genetal had agreed that it was right! although that member had procured a certificate of this kind in favour of his friend; and although it was fir≈øt done, in favour of the Speaker of the Senate at the time of pa≈ø≈øing the law, and afterwards in favour of able law judges!

But, ≈øay the gentlemen, "Let the defendant's opinion have been one way or the other, it was imprudent in him to ≈øub≈øcribe the New-Loan debt, without fir≈øt informing the Governor of his intentions." The Governor may perhaps be a very proper per≈øon to con≈øult in a ca≈øe of prudence, but if he is ≈øo, and if, which I am far from admitting, prudence required that he ≈øhould have been con≈øulted; is a mere act of imprudence a ≈øufficient ground for an impeachment? If it is, I am afraid that a thou≈øand articles would be maintainable again≈øt the be≈øt man among us, and that even ≈øome of the managers might ≈øtand high on the li≈øt of criminals! If the accu≈øers are obliged to have recour≈øe to this ground, the defendant ≈øhould not have been impeached for violating the laws of the State, but for tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing the rules of prudence!

But, ≈øay the pro≈øecutors, "Whatever may have been the defendant's opinion, the commonwealth has ≈øu≈øtained much damage by the ≈øub≈øcription of the New-Loan debt, and that he is therefore re≈øpon≈øible." Even if this po≈øition were true, it could at mo≈øt but apply in a civil action and not in a criminal pro≈øecution, where the rule is, actus non ≈øit reus ni≈øi mens ≈øit rea. But I deny the truth of the a≈ø≈øertion altogether. Twenty ≈øhillings in the pound were ju≈øtly due? Penn≈øylvania by the Act of March 1786 was ≈øolemnly pledged to pay twenty ≈øhillings in the pound, and that right and ju≈øtice required that this ≈øum ≈øhould be paid, is acknowledged by the Act of April 1791 for making up
the lo≈øs to the full amount of that ≈øum, to ≈øuch of her creditors as ≈øhould ≈øub≈øcribe to the loan of the United State Again, Sir, if by law the New-Loan deb ‚Ä¢
was redeemable, no damage could ari≈øe from its redemption, or if there did, it was damenum ab≈øque injuria. Adjourned.

However ≈øo far as relates to the tran≈øactions on Wedne≈øday, Thur≈øday and Friday, let it be remembered, that Mr. Wynkoop was each day placed in the chair, the committee of the whole attended as u≈øual in the Senate chamber, the Chairman reported attendance, and the managers reported further progre≈øs on Wedne≈øday, no further progre≈øs on Thur≈øday, Mr. Lewis being ≈øick; and further progre≈øs on Friday.

Mr. Inger≈øoll ob≈øerved, that he held a document in his hand which he intended to read, and wi≈øhed that the defendant and his coun≈øel would take notice, that they might make their defence accordingly.‚ÄîMr. Lewis de≈øired him t ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ead it. It was a notification publi≈øhed in Dun ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 's American Daily Adverti≈øer of June 8th 1792; the date of the notification was 16th May 1792; being the Governor's proclamation for the ≈øale of ≈øtock.
Mr. Lewis then proceeded‚Äî

In order ≈øtill further to ≈øhew, that the defendant conceived his con≈øtruction of the law to be right, and that he believed other gentlemen to be of the ≈øame opinion, permit me now to remind the honorable Senate, of the evidence of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury. He ≈øwears that "all the difficulties on which he ≈øo often wrote to the Governor; on which the Governor ordered the conference, and on which the conference was held and conducted, entirely aro≈øe on the ≈øuppo≈øition, of the New-Loan debt being ≈øub≈øcribable, and that they could not have exi≈øted, but on this point being acceded to." That in the conference Mr. Nichol≈øon appeared to be of this opinion, and the Governor afforded abundant rea≈øon to ≈øuppo≈øe that he was of the ≈øame opinion.

After hearing this evidence, no man can doubt of what the opinion of the Secretary of the Trea≈øury was; ‚Äîno man can doubt what the opinion of the Governor was, no man can doubt what the opinion of the defendant was, nor, but that he believed the≈øe gentlemen to be of the ≈øame opinion, ≈øince if they had not, as the Secretary tells you, the difficulties could not have ari≈øen, nor could the conference have been nece≈ø≈øary. The defendant mu≈øt have perceived this as clearly as the Secretary did, and unle≈øs, which is not pre≈øumable, he ≈øuppo≈øed the Governor to be de≈øtitute of common ≈øen≈øe, or totally regardle≈øs of all ≈øen≈øe of duty, he could not imagine that he would have called for reports, talked of calling the Legi≈ølature, or directed a conference without being of the ≈øame opinion.

But, again, Sir, it appears, that Judge Addi≈øon had applied to have a New-Loan certificate ≈øub≈øcribed and redeemed, and that the defendant from mere kindne≈øs undertook to get it done for him‚ÄîThat while that application was depending, Mr. Dallas objected to the defendant, that it was not authori≈øed by law, and this was the fir≈øt time of ≈øuch an idea being ≈øugge≈øted by any one. The defendant an≈øwered him, that he was ≈øure he was right; and what clearly proves that he
thought ≈øo is, that as Judge Addi≈øon was going out of town, the defendant, after this objection had been made, paid him the full amount of his certificate, as if it had been actually redeemed, and this too, without any deduction for his trouble, or a≈øking for an indemnity. Can there be a ≈øtronger proof than this of con≈øcious integrity? Or can it believed, that if he thought the matter at all doubtful, he would have voluntarily taken the ri≈øk upon him≈øelf? This ≈øurely ≈øhews, that he con≈øidered Mr. Dallas's pre≈øent opinion, ≈øo contrary to what it had formerly appeared to be, as not worthy of the lea≈øt regard, when oppo≈øed by a conviction in his own mind of the propriety of a contrary one, and that too, ≈øupported by opinions entitled to much more re≈øpect.

I have already given an an≈øwer ≈øo much at length, to the objection "That the defendant did not, as he ought to have done, con≈øult the Regi≈øter-General or the Governor," that I ≈øhall only take notice of it at pre≈øent, for the ≈øake of drawing a well warranted conclu≈øion in favour of the defendant. The active, virtuous and di≈øcerning mind of the Regi≈øter-General is too well known to be que≈øtioned, and it is al≈øo well known, that circum≈øtances have occurred, which leave no room for the ≈øuppo≈øition, that he has much partiality for the defendant; or if he had, it will not be in≈øinuated, that he would be ≈øwayed by it on the pre≈øent occa≈øion. He tells you, Sir, as I have already ob≈øerved, that the defendant did tell him and Mr. Gallatin, that the old Unfunded Depreciation certificates, were redeemable under the Act of April 1792, and that on peru≈øing it they were both of them of that opinion ‚ÄîHe tells you, that from the certifications made to the Governor, and which pa≈ø≈øed through his office, in the ca≈øes of the old Unfunded Depreciation debt, it might, both from the amount of the intere≈øt, and the time of its commencement, be ea≈øily known, that the certifications related to that debt, and could not po≈ø≈øibly relate to any other. Thus far then, there was no want of due communication, both to the Regi≈øter General and
to the Governor. It al≈øo appears, that the defendant had in his letters and reports repeatedly informed the Governor, that the New-Loan debt was ≈øub≈øcribable, and if it was ≈øub≈øcribable, no man can doubt of its being redeemable. Here then the objection again fails ‚ÄîBut in addition to all this, the Regi≈øter-General tells you, that after knowing of the objection made by Mr. Dallas, and after con≈øidering the law, he was of the ≈øame opinion with the defendant, and joined with him, in making ≈øeveral certificates to the Governor, in ca≈øes of the New-Loan debt, in order that warrants might i≈ø≈øue for its redemption at the Trea≈øury, and that as he had no doubt at all about the law, he did not think it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak to the Governor on the ≈øubject‚ÄîHence it appears, that there is not the lea≈øt ground for any part of the objection‚ÄîOh! but ≈øay the gentlemen, th ‚Ä¢ defendant did not in his certifications to the Governor, in ca≈øes of the New-Loan debt, de≈øcribe it in ≈øuch manner, as that it could be known, that the certifications related to that debt." To this I an≈øwer, that the certifications were exactly, as appears in evidence, agreeably to the form ≈øettled and e≈øtabli≈øhed by the different officers, as proper to be ob≈øerved under the Act of April 1792, and that they did not differ, from the form made u≈øe of on other occa≈øions; and further, that the Regi≈øter-General u≈øed the ≈øame form in ca≈øes of the New-Loan debt which the defendant did.

But we are told that "That this bu≈øine≈øs originated with the defendant; that he tran≈øacted it privately, and that it was unfair in him, not to inform others of the ≈øame ≈øpeculation!" This objection puts me in mind of a ≈øtory, which I have heard related by my friend General Wayne. Early in life, he was engaged in ≈øurveying lands in Nova-Scotia. On one Sunday morning, he ≈øaw a large flock of wild ducks in a pond near to his cabbin, and immediately took up his gun, in order to get a ≈øhot at them.‚ÄîAn Indian who ≈øaw the ducks, and wi≈øhed to have the ≈øpeculation to him≈øelf, came running to the General, and a≈øked him, what he was going to
do?‚ÄîUpon the General telling him, that he intended to have a ≈øhot at tho≈øe ducks, the Indian exclaimed with uplifted hands;‚Äî≈øhame! ≈øhame! for you white men, to ≈øhoot on the Sabbath;‚Äîwe poor ignorant Indians are not ≈øo bad as you, for we would not do ≈øo.‚Äî Struck with this ≈øeemingly ≈øerious admonition from a ≈øavage, the General almo≈øt concluded to return back and lay a≈øide his gun‚ÄîWhile the Indian was detaining him, and endeavouring to prevail upon him to do ≈øo, he heard the report of a gun, and ≈øaw ≈øeveral of the ducks knocked over; upon which the Indian, leaping from the ground, and laughing very heartily, exclaimed again; ‚Äîyou white people think we ≈øavages are fools, but you are not ≈øo cunning as we are‚ÄîThat is my ≈øquaw, who has ≈øhot the ducks, and I came to keep you back, till ≈øhe ≈øhould get the fir≈øt ≈øhot!‚ÄîI believe, Sir, that this is pretty much the ca≈øe with mo≈øt people, who ≈øee an opportunity for a fair ≈øpeculation, and that but few are ≈øo ≈øilly, as to cry roa≈øt beef, until they them≈øelves are ≈øatisfied.‚Äî We find that Mr. Nichol≈øon objected to the bill, becau≈øe it would afford an opportunity for ≈øpeculation. It did not enumerate all the articles of redemption, as his plan of finance did; ≈øeveral of the≈øe articles, might be unknown to the people at large, while they would be well known to ≈øome. This would give to a few, advantages for ≈øpeculation, which many would not have. This the defendant had endeavoured to prevent, but could not; and if the law left a door open for ≈øpeculating in the New-Loan debt, the defendant ≈øhould at mo≈øt have been impeached for ≈øpeculating according to law! not again≈øt it.

As a further an≈øwer to this objection, we have proved, that many other people knew the ≈øame thing, and ≈øpeculated in the ≈øame way, and that among them, were men of unblemi≈øhed character. Upon hearing this, the gentlemen immediately ≈øhift their ground and ≈øay, that "The bu≈øine≈øs originated with the defendant, and that be led others into it, to the great injury of the commonwealth." How is this objection reconcilable with
the la≈øt one? If he did the bu≈øine≈øs privately, and did not inform others of it, how could he lead others into it? Or if he led others into it, how is it po≈ø≈øible, that he did not inform others of it?‚ÄîIn ≈øhort, the accu≈øers advance contrary po≈øitions, either of which if true, is a refutation of the other, and yet they contend, that he is guilty on both grounds!

div.head: FIFTH AND SIXTH ARTICLES, which charge,

"The SENATE and HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania.
div.p:
"THAT, whereas John Nichol≈øon was a per≈øon meriting and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the confidence of the freemen of this commonwealth and their repre≈øentatives appointed Comptroller-General, and, in that official capacity, intru≈øted with many of its mo≈øt important pecuniary concerns; but hath ≈øince the ≈øaid appointment, conducted in ≈øuch a manner as to forfeit that confidence, and thereby rendered him≈øelf unfit to be continued in the afore≈øaid office: We, therefore, con≈øidering our≈øelves as the con≈øtitutional guardians, as well of the property as of the rights of our fellow-citizens, do earne≈øtly recommend
to you, that the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon be removed from his office."
After which the Addre≈øs was tran≈ømitted to the Senate for their concurrence.

div.head: SENATE, FRIDAY, April 11, 1794.
div.p: John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of the commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, at the bar, (with two of his coun≈øel.)The Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives did not attend on this occa≈øion, as they had been accu≈øtomed to do, and although their committee were directed (page 200) they did not officially report the final determination of the Senate thereon.
"The Speaker of the Senate ≈øaid‚Äî

"JOHN NICHOLSON, it has been re≈øolved, That if two-thirds of the Senators pre≈øent ≈øhould not find you guilty on any one of the articles of accu≈øation and impeachment, exhibited again≈øt you by the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, the Speaker of the Senate ≈øhould declare the ≈øame and di≈øcharge you.

"And the que≈øtion, on the ≈øaid articles, having been ≈øeparately put, and two-thirds of the Senators pre≈øent not having found you guilty on any one of them, It is declared, That you are not guilty of all or any of the mi≈ødemeanors charged upon you in the ≈øaid articles of accu≈øation and impeachment, and you are accordingly di≈øcharged."
After which Mr. Nichol≈øon waited on the Governor and re≈øigned the office of Comptroller-General, which he had held for twelve years.
The Senate, after their determination of the acquittal of the Comptroller, having re≈øumed the con≈øideration of Legi≈ølative bu≈øine≈øs:‚Äî
"Mr. Kennedy called for the addre≈øs to the Governor, pre≈øented, for concurrence, by the Clerk of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives and read ye≈øterday; and the ≈øame was again read; whereupon,
"It was moved by Mr. Kennedy, ≈øeconded by Mr. Schmy≈øer,

"On the que≈øtion to concur the addre≈øs, the yeas and nays were called for by Mr. Schmy≈øer and Mr. Kennedy, and,

"Ordered, That an extract of the foregoing re≈øolution be pre≈øented to the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives."
The Addre≈øs was pre≈øented to the Governor on the 14th by a joint committee of both Hou≈øes, the circum≈øtances were as follow:‚Äî

"And they al≈øo pre≈øented "The addre≈øs to the Governor," on the ≈øubject of the removal of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General, from his office, to which the the Governor was plea≈øed to deliver an an≈øwer in writing, which Mr. Hanna read in his place, and pre≈øented the ≈øame to the chair.

"Whereupon, the ≈øame was read as follows, to wit,
"GENTLEMEN,
"MR. Nichol≈øon has ≈øuper≈øeded the nece≈ø≈øity of a removal by re≈øigning the office of Comptroller-General, which re≈øignation I accepted on Tue≈øday la≈øt.
THOMAS MIFFLIN.
"April 14th, 1794.
"Me≈ø≈ørs. HANNA and HAINES, a committee of Legi≈ølature of Penn≈øylvania."

On Monday the 21≈øt April, the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives took up the bu≈øine≈øs of Mr. Nichol≈øon, and di≈øpo≈øed of the ≈øame in the following manner, with an apparent view to get rid of it, the adjournment being fixt for the next day.

"The report of the committee to whom was referred the report of the committee appointed during the rece ‚Ä¢ of the late Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives to examine the official tran≈øactions of the Comptroller-General, read April 11th in≈øtant, was read the ≈øecond time.
"And the following re≈øolution being under con≈øideration, viz.

"Re≈øolved, That the Attorney-General be directed to in≈øtitute a ≈øuit again≈øt John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General
for the whole amount of the certificates i≈ø≈øued to ≈øatisfy certain claims of clothing made in the name of ≈øundry officers, including both the principal and intere≈øt paid by the ≈øtate.

"And the following re≈øolution being under con≈øideration, viz.
"Re≈øolved, That a committee be appointed to bring in a bill to provide for the effectual ≈øtatement of the accounts of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General and E≈øcheator-General."
"It was,

div.head: Same Day.
div.p: "Mr. M'Lene on behalf of him≈øelf and others a≈øked and obtained leave to enter on the Journal of this Hou≈øe prote≈øt again≈øt the re≈øolution for taking up, by ≈øpecial order, for a ≈øecond reading a re≈øolution which was moved and ≈øeconded for the appointment of a committee to draught an addre≈øs to the Governor, for the removal of John Nichol≈øon from the office of Comptroller-General, of this commonwealth, and pre≈øented the ≈øame to the chair, which is as follows, viz.

"A prote≈øt again≈øt the Re≈øolution for taking up, by ≈øpecial order, for a ≈øecond reading, a re≈øolution which was moved and ≈øeconded for the appointment of a committee to draught an addre≈øs to the Governor for the removal of John Nichol≈øon from the office of Comptroller-General of this commonwealth.
"WE DISSENT, becau≈øe,

"AT the time of the ≈øaid re≈øolution being agreed to, the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon ≈øtood impeached by the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, in their name, and in that of all the People of Penn≈øylvania, of certain high crimes and mi≈ødemeanors in the di≈øcharge of his official duties; and as no judgment had been rendered, the ≈øaid impeachment was ≈øtill depending, and within the power of the Senate: We therefore con≈øider the adoption of the re≈øolution at that time as an infraction of the law, no le≈øs oppre≈ø≈øive to the defendant than dangerous to the ≈øecurity of individuals; as derogatory to the ju≈øtice and dignity of this Hou≈øe, and as highly di≈øre≈øpectful to the Senate and Governor of the Commonwealth.

"As an infraction of the law, no le≈øs oppre≈ø≈øive to the defendant than dangerous to the ≈øecurity of individuals, becau≈øe their ≈øafety and ≈øecurity depend on the pure and impartial admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice; and every thing which has a tendency to prejudice the public mind or to bias the Judges while a cau≈øe is depending, poi≈øons the ≈øprings of ju≈øtice, warps their ≈øteady and even cour≈øe, and undermines the mo≈øt valuable bulwark of ≈øecurity, which innocence can have. Hence it is that all publications, touching a cau≈øe depending, which are calculated to give a bias either way, are highly criminal.

"If anonymous publications are con≈øidered as of this dangerous tendency, we conceive that a ≈øolemn vote by the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, "in their name, and in that of all the people of Penn≈øyvania," mu≈øt be of a tendency equally dangerous. It is true, it may not have all the intended effect, yet ≈øince that is owing to the virtue and firmne≈øs of others, it affords no apology for the imprudence of ≈øuch a mea≈øure. Whatever might be the motives, its tendency certainly was to prejudice the public mind while a pro≈øecution was depending, and to bear down and oppre≈øs the accu≈øed, by a≈ø≈øailing the minds of his judges with all the weight and influence of the mo≈øt numerous branch of the Legi≈ølature; and, as if this was really intended, care was taken to introduce
the re≈øolution, with a declaration that John Nichol≈øon had, by conduct unworthy of his tru≈øt, forfeited and lo≈øt the confidence of the citizens of Penn≈øylvania; thereby rendering it highly improper that he ≈øhould any longer continue to enjoy any office of tru≈øt or profit in this commonwealth. As publications of this nature by an individual, while a pro≈øecution was depending, would be highly criminal; and as the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives had fulfilled their con≈øtitutional duty by impeaching and pro≈øecuting the Comptroller; and as it remained for the ≈øenate to di≈øcharge their con≈øtitutional duty by determining on that impeachment, and for the Governor to di≈øcharge his con≈øtitutional duty by di≈øplacing the Comptroller, or continuing him in office, at lea≈øt till judgment ≈øhould be given by the Senate, we can conceive no apology for pa≈ø≈øing the re≈øolution at that time. For the≈øe rea≈øons we cannot but con≈øider the re≈øolution as an infraction of the law, no le≈øs oppre≈ø≈øive to the accu≈øed than danegerous to the ≈øecurity of others.

"We al≈øo con≈øider it as derogatory to the ju≈øtice and dignity of this Hou≈øe. Derogatory to its ju≈øtice for the rea≈øons already mentioned; and to its dignity, from the ardor and precipitancy with which it was hurried through the Hou≈øe. We ≈øay ardor and precepitancy, becau≈øe, during the debate, a communication was received by the Speaker, from the Clerk of the Senate, that on the next day judgment on the impeachment would be pronounced, and yet without waiting even till the me≈ø≈øage was read, or announced from the chair, the re≈øolution was by ≈øpecial order taken up, read a ≈øecond time, and pa≈ø≈øed in oppo≈øition to all endeavours for a ≈øhort delay. This we believe to be unexampled in Legi≈ølative bodies; and it appears to us to be the more exceptional, ≈øince a decent regard for the opinions of men ≈øeemed to require that the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, being the accu≈øers and pro≈øecutors of the Comptroller, ≈øhould have manife≈øted their moderation and impartiality, by declining to u≈øurp the province of judging on their own charges, at lea≈øt until con≈øtitutional judges had determined on them. On the
contrary, as no time for con≈øideration or enquiry was allowed, there is too much rea≈øon to believe that the proceeding will be viewed by impartial men, as partaking more of ≈øudden or di≈øappointed re≈øentment, than of that ju≈øt and dignified di≈øplea≈øure which becomes the Repre≈øentatives of a great Republic.

"We have ≈øaid of judging on their own charges, becau≈øe it is rea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe the an≈øwer, conveyed by the re≈øolution, is founded on the matters charged in the articles of impeachment. It is true it is expre≈ø≈øed in ≈øuch general and indefinite terms, as to render it impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øay whether it is grounded on them or indeed on any thing el≈øe, ≈øince it contains no ≈øpecification of facts, nor the lea≈øt hint of any particular matter to which it relates; but as the Comptroller has not been called upon to an≈øwer any other charges than tho≈øe which are mentioned in the articles of impeachment, nor had an opportunity of being heard in his defence, we are unwilling to ≈øuppo≈øe any member of this Hou≈øe capable of condemning him without a charge, and unheard on any other grounds.

"We have ≈øaid that we con≈øider the adoption of the re≈øolution at that time as highly di≈øre≈øpectful to the Senate and to the Governor. As highly di≈øre≈øpectful to the Senate, ina≈ømuch as it relates to a pro≈øecution depending before them, and is expre≈ø≈øed in terms calculated to influence their deci≈øion. The time, the manner and the extreme hurry with which it was ha≈øtened forward, mu≈øt carry to the minds of the Senate too ≈øtrong evidence of a ≈øuppo≈øition prevailing in this Hou≈øe, that the Senate or ≈øome of its members, were not to be tru≈øted with a deci≈øion, until they were influenced by a ≈øolemn re≈øolution that "John Nichol≈øon had, by conduct unworthy of his tru≈øt, forfeited and lo≈øt the confidence of the citizens of Penn≈øylvania, thereby rendering it highly improper that he ≈øhould any longer continue to enjoy any office of tru≈øt or profit in this commonwealth."

"And when we take into con≈øideration the time of pa≈ø≈øing the re≈øolution, we cannot but con≈øider it as equally
di≈øre≈øpectful to the Governor, ≈øince it ≈øtrongly implies either that he had neglected his duty by not having already di≈øplaced the Comptroller, or that „Äà‚óä„Äâ was apprehended he would neglect it in future by continuing him in office. While we admit the rights of the Hou≈øe to addre≈øs the Governor, to remove an unworthy officer, we are far from agreeing that the Governor was to blame in not removing the Comptroller after the charges were brought again≈øt him, and while they were depending; ≈øince this would have amounted to a declaration on his put, that the Comptroller was unworthy of tru≈øt and confidence, before either his innocence or guilt had appeared on a fair trial. If after a deci≈øion by the Senate the Governor had continued the Comptroller in office, this I loo≈øe had thought him unworthy of it, there might have been a propriety in addre≈ø≈øing for his removal; but to do this at a time when the Governor could not with propriety di≈øplace him, when it was known that the difficulty would on the next day be removed, appears too much like converting the right of addre≈ø≈øing into a vehicle of general and unqualified cen≈øure, both upon the officer who may have incurred the di≈øplea≈øure of the Hou≈øe, and upon the Governor for not adding his weight to that di≈øplea≈øure or cen≈øure, by di≈øplacing the accu≈øed before his modern ‚Ä¢ o or guile had been e≈øtabli≈øhed on a fair trial. Under this view of the matter, we cannot but con≈øider the proceedings again≈øt which we prote≈øt, as an u≈øurpation of incon≈øtitutional and arbitrary power, and an attempt to di≈øfranchi≈øe a citizen, by voting him unworthy of any office of tru≈øt or profit.
"Under the≈øe impre≈ø≈øions, we prote≈øt again≈øt the re≈øolution referred to, and have recorded our rea≈øons in ju≈øtification of our conduct.

div.head: The next day.
div.p: "Mr. Benjamin Morgan, in behalf of him≈øelf and others, a≈øked and obtained leave to enter their Reply to the Prote≈øt of the minority of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives again≈øt taking up by ≈øpecial order for a ≈øecond reading a re≈øolution for the appointment of a committee to draft an Addre≈øs to the Governor for the removal of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of this commonwealth, on the Journal of the Hou≈øe; and pre≈øented the ≈øame to the chair, which is follows, viz.

"Reply to the Prote≈øt of the minority of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives again≈øt taking up, by ≈øpecial order, for a ≈øecond reading, a Re≈øolution for the appointment of a committee to draught an addre≈øs to the Governor for the removal of John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of this commonwealth.

"THAT at the time of pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid re≈øolution, the Senate had decided on the Articles of Impeachment again≈øt the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon, Comptroller-General of this common wealth; and although they had neither pronounced judgment nor convicted the ≈øaid John Nichol≈øon on any of the articles exhibited again≈øt him, yet ≈øo large a proportion as ten out of ≈øeventeen, (the whole number of Senators pre≈øent) having declared him guilty on two of the mo≈øt ≈øerious of the ≈øaid articles, it would have been highly improper in the Legi≈ølature not to have made u≈øe of every lawful means, to prevent him from continuing a moment longer in office. Had they acted otherwi≈øe, it would in their apprehen≈øion have been an unpardonable breach of the confidence repo≈øed in them by their con≈øtituents; nor could they have expected their vote on the ≈øaid re≈øolution would have any ≈øuch influence on the deci≈øion of the Senate, as is ≈øugge≈øted in the ≈øaid prote≈øt; the ≈øaid deci≈øion having previou≈øly taken place; and though not directly communicated to the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, mu≈øt have been as well known to the minority as it was to the other members of that Hou≈øe. On this ground alone, we con≈øider
the ≈øaid vote and re≈øolution not only ju≈øtifiable but nece≈ø≈øary, even had there been no other cau≈øes of removal than tho≈øe contained in the Articles of Impeachment.

"Independently however of any thing contained in the ≈øaid articles, we con≈øider the Comptroller's refu≈øal to produce to the committee of inve≈øtigation, appointed by the la≈øt Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, any of the books, vouchers or papers relative to the certificates i≈ø≈øued to the Penn≈øylvania line for the arrears of their pay, a ≈øufficient cau≈øe of removal; and were any thing wanting to aggravate his conduct in this in≈øtance, it was ≈øufficiently ≈øupplied by his ≈øub≈øequent refu≈øal to comply with the peremptory orders of the Governor on the ≈øame ≈øubject.

"There is ≈øome difficulty in reconciling the different objections offered by the prote≈øting minority; the principal part of which re≈øt on the ≈øuppo≈øed influence the re≈øolution would produce in the deci≈øion of the Senate, when that minority ≈øtate in their prote≈øt it≈øelf, that before any vote had been taken on the ≈øaid re≈øolution, an official communication was received from the Senate, informing the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives that on the next day judgment would be pronounced on the impeachment, which could only be the con≈øequence of a deci≈øion having previou≈øly taken place.
